column2: The most popular exhibit at the New York World's Fair is the General Motors Futurama depicting the geometric streets and highways of the world of tomorrow, according to the results, announced yesterday, of a special survey conducted last week among Fair visitors by the American Institute of Public Opinion.

At the annual meeting yesterday of the Plymouth Oil Company stockholders authorized an increase in the board of directors to eleven members from nine. A.R. Budd of Pittsburgh and W.M. Griffith of Sinton, Texas, were elected additional directors.

ALBANY, May 16.--Governor Lehman today signed the so-called Catholic Bus Bill which provides free transportation to school children attending private and parochial schools as well as public institutions.

Detailed plans of organization and administration of the proposed Division of Public Service Training for City College were disclosed yesterday by the Board of Higher Education. The board, at its meeting Monday night, approved the establishment of the additional division, ...

Dr. Nelson P. Mead, acting president of City College, announced yesterday the names of thirteen members of the college faculty who were advanced to assistant, associate and full professorships and whose new status will become effective on Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, May 16.-- An amended plan for the voluntary reorganization of the Federal Water Service Corporation has been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and will be the subject of a public hearing beginning on June 1, the commission announced today. Under the new plan the company name will be changed to Federal Water and Gas Corporation.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 16.--William T. Grant, head of the Grant chain of department stores, has offered his large colonial residence and its four-and-a-half acres of ground here to St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church of North Pelham for use as a branch chapel, it was learned today. The property is assessed at $121,000.

CHICAGO, May 16.--Having comported themselves after the manner of lambs in Boston, the Dodgers transformed themselves into roaring lions as they descended upon the Cubs' handsome Wrigley Field den today.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--Navy Department plans for the construction of an experimental dirigible about half the size of the Akron, Macon and Shenandoah were vetoed by President Roosevelt after statements by a private concern participating in bids on the projected ...

QUEBEC, May 16.--Precautions unprecedented in Canada and exceeding any taken in England will be provided to safeguard in the next month King George VI and Queen Elizabeth as they journey from coast to coast of this Dominion and back again.

While a chilly breeze whipped the flags of many nations, representatives of Brooklyn lodges of the Knights of Columbus, the Elks and the Knights of Pythias assembled last night in the Court of Peace at the World's Fair to celebrate the second day of Brooklyn Week, set ...

Unless the city's offer of $175,000,000 for the B.M.T. is accepted holders of the utility's securities "run a chance of getting only $78,000,000," the estimated security value of the system as of March 31, 1938.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 16 (AP).--The Argentine Foreign Exchange Control granted to General Motors Corporation today the first import permits under a new government-sponsored plan to increase shipments of automobiles from the United States in return for which importers would freeze dollars here by purchases of Treasury bonds.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--Spokesmen for the American Federation of Labor complained to the Senate Committee on Education and Labor today that the National Labor Relations Board delayed certifying craft unions as proper collective bargaining units so as to favor the ...

ALBANY, May 16.--The Housing Bill was amended twice on the floor of the Senate today and is now in a form which should insure its passage at this session, despite an undercurrent of hostility to it which was revealed during debate.

Mist Marjorie Handy gave a luncheon yesterday in the Louis Sherry Room of Sherry's. Her guests included the Misses Alice Fleitmann, Florence Wardwell, Anne Wright, Margery Abbett, Florence Tucker, Helen Macdonald, Dona Walton, Barbara Baker, Katherine Thatcher, Constance Mitler, ...

Joseph (Big Joe) Ison and Alexander Pompez, whose testimony helped to convict James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, received suspended sentences yesterday from Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora for their parts in the policy racket. Each had pleaded guilty to the same indictment on which Hines was convicted.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP).-- Ben Grey, who received $55,000 from the Associated Gas and Electric Company in 1937 for work in public relations, was described today at a hearing of the Securities and Exchange Commission as a short man with a blond mustache whose job it was "to mix with the right people" in Washington.

Fred Snite is off on his long journey to the Shrine of Miracles at Lourdes. The good-will of every one who knows his story will go with him, for he has come to symbolize a steadfast courage in trial and stout-heartedness in adversity.

PARIS, May 16.--Minister of Merchant Marine Louis de Chappedelaine appeared this afternoon before the Chamber of Deputies' merchant marine committee to say that, regardless of its cause, the spread of the recent fire aboard the liner Paris was due to serious negligence that ought not go unpunished.

LONDON, May 16.--The government majority in the House of Commons tonight beat down a Labor proposal that 20-year-old lads called up for compulsory military service should receive the right to vote in Parliamentary elections. The vote was 241 to 140.

The stimulus to general business expected from the New York World's Fair is already being felt, according to Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation, who yesterday repeated his Forecast that the volume of new business produced by the exposition would reach $1,000,000,000.

In the first transfer of the property in twenty-four years, the three-family dwelling at 472 Palisade Avenue, Weehawken, N.J., has been sold by Ella and Matilda Reifenberger to John Becker through the Joseph J. Garibaldi Organization, brokers. The structure is on a plot 25 by 100 feet. Abe Warren acted for the buyers in the deal.

Apparently reflecting a strong anti-Hitler sentiment, the study of German is declining at a rapid rate in the New York City school system, Dr. Theodore Huebener, acting director of foreign languages, disclosed yesterday in his annual report.

TRENTON, Wednesday, Jan. 17.-- Former Mercer County Democratic Chairman Leo J. Rogers, one of forty-seven candidates for election yesterday to the new five-member City Commission, had taken a commanding lead early today with returns from a fifth of the eightythree voting districts tabulated.

If Senator Harrison succeeds in getting Congress to enact the chief changes he has recommended in our present tax laws, he and his colleagues will have taken substantial steps toward placing our whole Federal tax program on a sounder basis.

ST. LOUIS, May 16.--The Giants' first grand offensive movement of the year was getting off to a magnificent start today when something back-fired in Colonel Bill Terry's motors and the entire enterprise came down with a crash as the Cardinals bagged the opening clash of the three-game aeries, 7 to 6.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., has under consideration the refunding of its $125,000,000 funded debt, it was disclosed officially yesterday, although details of the plan have not been worked out.

The Mayors visiting New York for the sessions of the United States Conference of Mayors, after devoting yesterday morning to discussions of the national housing program, taxation of municipal securities and long-range plans for construction of highways and airports, ...

By a vote of 25 to 1, with its proposer, Councilman Joseph Clark Baldwin 3d, casting the sole affirmative vote, the City Council yesterday rejected a proposed local law that would have barred from the streets all peddlers except those selling direct from the manufacturer products that had won the approval of the city Health Department.

Only when better housing is provided in Manhattan will the downward population trend in this borough be stopped, Alfred Rheinstein, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Chelsea Association for Planning ...
ALBANY, May 16.--Governor Lehman today appointed Maurice P. Davidson of New York to the State Power Authority to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Frank P. Walsh.

HARLAN, Ky., May 16.--Harlan County C.I.O. leaders sought President Roosevelt's intervention today in the coal mining crisis here and told him that they had warned the county's civil authorities that if troops and machine guns were not removed from the highways within twenty-four hours the men "would take them themselves."

ALBANY, May 16.--The Legislature moved today toward cleaning up the Republican fiscal program by sending to Governor Lehman the bill for a tax on cigarettes and by announcing the pending restoration to the budget of three items which had been discarded in the original Republican fiscal program.

A joint meeting of the board of directors of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony was held yesterday afternoon at the home of Marshall Field, chairman and president, with the governing board of the auxiliary board, the junior advisory board and the junior committee of the auxiliary board.

ST. JOHNS, Nfld., May 16.--Carl Backman, slim young Swedish aviator, was out over the Atlantic tonight following the air trails blazed by a select group of fliers with solo ocean crossings to their credit.

As the Atlantic Squadron of the United States Fleet prepared to sail this morning after an eighteenday stay to open the New York World's Fair and with a record of more than half a million visitors, Rear Admiral Alfred W. Johnson, commanding the squadron, issued a statement last night thanking New York City for a welcome "the like of which has never been equaled."

Captain John McRostie, master of the Cunard White Star liner Samaria, brought his ship into New York yesterday afternoon and saw her made fast at Pier 56, Hudson River, at West Fourteenth Street, for the last time. When he docks his ship in Liverpool on May 29 he will retire from the sea after forty-five years of service.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--President Roosevelt accepted the resignation of Richard C. Patterson Jr. as Assistant Secretary of Commerce, sent a letter to the Temporary National Economic Committee asking it to endeavor to solve the problem of getting stagnant capital into productive ...

In 1921 World War physicians and surgeons of the western armies decided to organize an International Congress of Military Medicine to preserve for peace as well as war the medical, surgical, pharmaceutical and sanitary lessons learned at the front. Nine meetings have been held in European capitals.

Ten teams remained in the field as the six-day bicycle race continued at Madison Square Garden last night. Twelve combinations left the starting mark when the race began on Monday night, but injuries cut the roll of contestants to a number inordinately small for so early in the grind.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--Lumber, as the most widely used material in home building, shares in the benefits of the continued impetus given small-home building by both private and public projects and by the insured mortgage system of the Federal Housing Administration.

SHANGHAI, May 18 (AP)--Japanese authorities rejected today a demand by the Municipal Council of the International Settlement of Kulangsu Island, off the port of Amoy, for withdrawal of Japanese who invaded the foreign area there Friday.

Seventy-seven students in Columbia College have won King's Crowns, tokens given to leaders in the twelve non-athletic extra-curricular activities on the campus, it was announced yesterday by Benjamin A. Hubbard, director of King's Crown.

The need for more insurance advertising, particularly from the angle of selling the agent to the public, was emphasized yesterday before the life group session of the Spring meeting of the Insurance Advertising Conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--Eight corporations listed with the Securities and Exchange Commission engaged primarily in the manufacture of containers and closures of other than paper and wood had a combined operating profit in 1937 of $53,000,000, or 11.5 per cent of sales, the commission reported today.
Directors of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation have declared an extra dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock in addition to the regular quarterly payment of 25 cents a share.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--Another investigation of alleged monopolistic practices by oil companies operating in ten Middle Western States will be made by a grand jury at Danville, Ill., Thurman Arnold, assistant attorney general in charge of anti-trust prosecutions, announced today. Witnesses have been summoned to appear on June 5.

RANCHO SANTE FE, Calif., May 16 (AP).--Mrs. Gertrude Minturn Pinchot, first wife of Amos R.E. Pinchot, New York lawyer and publicist, and sister-in-law of former Governor Gifford Pinchot of Pennsylvania, died in her home here today at the age of 67.

WASHINGTON, May 16--As he digs tentative postholes for his 1940 dreamfences, James A. Farley is laboring in the dark. He wants the Democratic Presidential nomination, and he comfortably suspects he might find himself the nominee for Vice President with Secretary of State Hull at the head of the ticket.

The United States liner Washington, due to sail today for the Channel ports, will have among her prominent passengers Alexander W. Weddell, Ambassador to the new Spanish Government in Madrid; C.V. McLaughlin, assistant secretary of labor; James A. Wilson, ...

The Dollar Savings Bank yesterday disposed of four tenement houses in the Bronx to a group of operators who acquired the properties for cash over four individual first mortgages aggregating $53,300. The liens run for ten years at an average interest rate of 4 per cent, exclusive of amortization.

St. John's Prep broke a tie with St. Michael's Diocesan High and gained sole ownership of the Brooklyn C.H.S.A.A. baseball lead by downing the latter, 5 to 2, at Carey Field yesterday. The victory was the sixth in as many league starts for the Redmen.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 16. --In a setting far more beautiful than anything that has previously been attempted, the eighth annual Atlantic City horse show opened tonight in the vast Auditorium, to continue through Saturday evening.

QUEBEC, May 16.--The steamship Empress of Australia, bearing the King and Queen of Great Britain, dropped anchor at 11:30 tonight off the Town of St. Jean on the Ile d'Orleans, about twelve miles downstream from this citadelcrowned ancient capital of French Canada.

Four hundred members and guests of the Scarsdale Woman's Club who visited the Fair yesterday were told by Dr. Gerald Wendt, Director of Science and Education at the exposition, that "one of the most important problems of the future will be to give dignity to leisure."

HARRISON, N.Y., May 16.--It was a case of last shall be first in the Metropolitan Golf Association's opening one-day tourney of the season at the Green Meadow Club today, for Tommy Goodwin of Winged Foot, last to start out, came in the winner.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 17.--Cornell's baseball team defeated Syracuse, 11 to 1, today, for an even break in their series this year.
Reaching a record high, the Board of Education, through its WPA nutrition project, is now supplying daily free hot lunches to 119,000 needy New York school children, it was announced yesterday.

The government won the preliminary skirmish in the judicial bribery and corruption case centering on Martin T. Manton, former senior judge of the Second Federal Circuit Court of Appeals, when Federal Judge W. Calvin Chesnut denied yesterday all demurrers and motions to quash five indictments and rejected a demand for a bill of particulars.

WASHINGTON, May 17.--The Japanese challenge of the status of international settlements in China was met today by the landing of United States, British and French naval forces in the international area on the island of Kulangsu in the harbor of Amoy.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 17.-- Yale defeated Army, 17--10, in a loosely played baseball game today. Nine pitchers in all paraded to the mound, the Elis showing five and the cadets four.

CHICAGO, May 17.--Keenly competitive pice-cutting, particularly in the tire lines, featured the midsummer flyer catalogues of Sears Roebuck Co. and Montgomery Ward Co., which went into the mails today.

A decline in gold imports here yesterday, and in engagements of the metal abroad for shipment to the United States, was reported by the Federal Reserve Bank.

Strong endorsement of the proposed New York State Food, Drug and Cosmetic bill, now before Governor Lehman, was voiced yesterday by James F. Hoge, counsel to the Proprietary Association, at the conclusion yesterday of the annual convention of the organization at the Hotel Biltmore.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 17. --The Balkan Entente opened its economic conference here today.

A considerable liberalization of the navy's public relations policy is forecast by a recent order of Admiral Claude C. Bloch, Commander in Chief of the United States fleet, made public yesterday by local naval officials.

Mrs. Payne Whitney, owner of the Greentree Stable, won the first steeplechase stake of the Belmont Park meeting yesterday with her Sailor Beware and continued the only perfect record of the New York racing season.

BOSTON, May 17 (AP).--Big Jack Wilson weakened in the tenth inning today, and the Chicago White Sox touched him for four hits that led to a 6-to-3 victory over the Boston Red Sox in the second game of the series.
PRAGUE, May 17.--Nations still maintaining legations here received notices today from the German authorities that diplomatic privileges and extraterritorial rights would be rescinded May 25.

Pancho Villa, a Mexican steer, weight 950 pounds, was listed as a dangerous character by the World's Fair police yesterday, after he had started a personal revolution that spread from the Cavalcade of Centaurs to the adjacent territory of Corona.

Retail collections last month were off 1.23 per cent from 1938, according to the twenty-store index of the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc., issued yesterday. The average percentage for the month was 45.85, compared with 47.08 a year ago. Five stores had increases and fifteen had decreases.
Fifth Avenue strollers were greeted yesterday by a sight reminiscent of a Continental scene as flower sellers offered their wares from the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Net income of Raybestos-Manhattan, Inc., for the three months ended on March 3 amounted Lo $316,401, after providing $174,361 for depreciation and $77,169 for Federal and State income taxes, it was announced yesterday. The income is equal to 50 cents a share ...

The pattern of the bond market yesterday was strikingly similar to that of Tuesday's session. United States Government obligations continued to push forward to new record high levels, while domestic corporation bonds again yielded under the mild pressure of liquidation.

The advantages to consumers of electric power in adoption of the State Power Authority's program for the development of its proposed Niagara-St. Lawrence system are stressed in the eighth annual report of the Authority, made public yesterday.

Elwood Cooke of Portland, Ore., has been named by the United States Lawn Tennis Association to sail with Robert L. Riggs of Chicago to compete in tournaments abroad.

ST. LOUIS, May 17.--History, only twenty-four hours old, almost repeated itself today when the Giants, of to another flying start on Melvin Ott's sixth homer of the year, once again buckled with the homestretch just in sight.

The falling tendency in stock prices set in motion on Tuesday was continued yesterday. There was no great pressure upon the market, but neither was there any sign of a rally. Closing quotations were down good-sized fractions in most cases, with losses of a point or two fairly common.
The Brielle boats are bringing in the largest catches of mackerel in years, and the anglers who are in search of excitement are rigging fly rods and tying on small blocktin squids for these fish.

MADRID, May 17.--With the publication today of the official announcement that Friday of this week had been designated as "Victory Day," decorations for Generalissimo Francisco Franco's triumphal entry into the city began to appear on buildings and shops in the business center.
In many respects "The Brown Danube" is the best of the long series of inconclusive attacks upon the Nazi regime in Germany.

Children should be allowed to read any amount of "trash" as long as it is exciting, William Lyon Phelps said yesterday at a luncheon of the American Booksellers Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Dr. Phelps enumerated ...

CHICAGO, May 17.--Wheat prices declined 5/8 to cent a bushel in the early trading today. Scattered liquidation in small lots developed in the May, while there was some pressure on the new crop months because of rains in Western Kansas and a forecast for showers in the Canadian Northwest.

MEDIA, Pa., May 17.--Forsaken, brown mare owned by James G. Leiper Jr., came through with a spectacular finish to win the three and one-half mile timber race for the Bayard Taylor Plate at the opening of the Rose Tree Hunt Club Spring meet today.

Mayor La Guardia laid last night the groundwork that may lead to the destruction of the German-American Bund in this city when he sent copies of a forty-two-page report listing more than forty violations of the relief tax laws to District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey ...

CHICAGO, May 17.--Steady to firm furniture prices and exhibition emphasis on early and contemporary American and French provincial styling seem assured for the June furniture market here, a check of tenants at the American Furniture Mart and Merchandise Mart indicated today.
LONDON, May 17.--Business remained quiet in the stock markets today but the better tone which developed late yesterday again was in evidence.

ATBANY, May 17.--Following two futile last-minute conferences to whip unwilling Republican Senators into line, the Republican State leaders tonight dropped their efforts to pass the 2 per cent retail sales tax for relief at the current session.

A double victory by Harry Jensen of La Salle Academy featured the Manhattan-Bronx-Westchester division Catholic High Schools Athletic Association field event championships held yesterday at the Mount St. Michael High School field in the Bronx.

CHICAGO, May 17.--Officials of the Board of Trade, as well as government officials, were confronted today with what some described as a "possible squeeze situation" in connection with rapid and wide price fluctuations in May wheat contracts.

With the opening last night of the restaurant overlooking the Court of Peace from Presidential Row North, the Italian Pavilion at the World's Fair became virtually 100 per cent operative. It was crowded all day.
Three hotels on the upper West Side erected in 1914 and 1915 by the late Edward W, Browning were leased yesterday by his estate to Joseph West Son, operators of a chain of hotels.

TRENTON, May 17.--With Mrs. Mina Edison Hughes of Llewellyn Park, widow of Thomas A. Edison, among the witnesses, Governor Moore signed today a resolution adopted by the Legislature to name the new Raritan River bridge west of the Victory Bridge at Perth Amboy in honor of the late inventor.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP).--A congressional group heard from Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh today an assertion that the United States had been oustripped by Germany in military aviation but was in no dnger of aerial attack from abroad.
Several leases involving full-floor units of space were listed among the commercial rentals reported yesterday.

The voluntary hospitals in New York State, including those in this city, are facing such serious financial difficulties that they require added support through emergency taxation or other means, speakers declared yesterday at the annual convention of the Hospital Association of New York State at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

ALBANY, May 17.--The Assembly passed and sent to the Governor today the Nunan bill extending the present mortgage moratorium until July 1, 1940. Had it not been extended, it would have expired on Jan. 1, 1940.
Mrs. Wright Barclay entertained with a luncheon yesterday at Sherry's. The guests included Mrs. Joel Ellis Fisher. Countess de Montale.
Mayor La Guardia was elected president of the United States Conference of Mayors yesterday for a fourth consecutive term, over his vigorous objection.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., May 17. --Miss Grace Amory of the Women.'s National Golf and Tennis Club turned in a women's course record score of 35, 37--72, which is only one over men's par, to capture the low gross honors in the women's Long Island one-day golf tourney today at the Piping Rock Club.
A pawnbroker's business that came to Times Square in 1897 after seventy years on the Bowery soon will move for the second time in the 112 years of its existence.
David W. Frankel, operator, has purchased from the Guaranty Trust Company as trustee, the two-story taxpayer on the northwest corner of Bennett Avenue and 181st Street, Washington Heights.

WASHINGTON, May 17.--The greatest number of regular army, National Guard, reserve and civilian soldiery in the peacetime history of the United States will be on manoeuvres or in training within the continental limits of the United States this Summer.

The Union Dime Savings Bank, Sixth Avenue and Fortieth Street, will be eighty years old today. William L. De Bost, president, revealed yesterday that search into the bank's early records showed that the original by-laws permitted deposits from 10 cents to $5,000.

John D. Lore of 226 East Twentysixth Street was declared a veteran of the World War yesterday by Justice William T. Collins in Supreme Court and ordered reinstated with back pay to his $1,680a-year job as a pharmacist in the Department of Purchase.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 17.-- It was feared tonight that Carl Backman, Swedish aviator who took off alone yesterday from Newfoundland in an attempt to fly the Atlantic to his home in Leksand, Sweden, had been lost in the ocean.

QUEBEC, May 17.--Out of the Old World into the new there stepped today a King and Queen of Great Britain to receive the homage of their subjects in this oldest and largest Dominion of the British Crown.

CHICAGO, May 17.--Staging a sort of treadmill follies on one of the coldest and windiest days in the Windy City, the Dodgers and Cubs today played ball for four hours and forty-one minutes and wound up making no progress whatever.

Peter van den Toorn, director of the Holland-America Line in New York, announced yesterday that he had received confirmation from Rotterdam of the company's purchase of the Red Star Line, including the two 16,000-ton liners Pennland and Westernland.

City College scored its second victory of the season over Manhattan College yesterday, the Beavers beating the Jaspers by the one-sided count of 15 to 5 in a wild and woolly game on the Lewisohn Stadium diamond.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 17.--Germany has rapidly pushed her political influence in Bolivia under the Busch regime to the point where it appears probable that Bolivia will soon adhere to the German-Italian-Japanese Axis.

Being never too backward to seize victory by the forelock no matter how it is presented to them, the Yankees toppled the Browns for their seventh straight triumph at the Stadium yesterday, winning by on an error.

HARLAN, Ky., May 17.--Filled with armed and temper-frayed National Guardsmen and miners, Harlan County stood alone today, the last Appalachian soft coal region that has not signed a contract with the Congress of Industrial Organszations.
AMSTERDAM, March 17.--Taking in account the uncertain political outlook as well as yesterday's disappointing trend in Wall Street, the tone of today's Bourse was better than might have been expected.

Mortimer Hays was elected president of the New York City Chapter of the National Lawyers Guild last night for a one-year term to succeed Paul J. Kern, the first president of the chapter who had served three successive terms.

The experiment that began Tuesday in Rochester will be watched with much interest by all who are concerned either with relief methods or with the problem of our agricultural surpluses. Rochester is the city chosen for the first trial of the food-stamp plan for distributing surplus farm products to people on relief.

The New York Central Railroad reported increased freight revenues but decreased passenger revenues in April and in the first four months of 1939. Freight revenues were $16,225,425, against $15,335,536 in April, 1938, and passenger revenues were $4,535,800, against $4,605,871.

LONDON, May 25.--The bill creating the new Ministry of Supply and giving it sweeping powers to put British industry on a war basis if necessary was introduced in the House of Commons today by Edward Leslie Burgin, who has been designated as the new Minister.

Vigorously assailing policies of the Administration, Senator H. Styles Bridges of New Hampshire yesterday listed seven obstacles in the road to recovery in an address before the Association of Gas Appliance and Equipment Manufacturers at the second day of their convention at the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, May 25.--Acting on the theory that "he who fights and runs away may live to fight another day," members of two House committees flicked their fingers at the political monster known as the Townsend Old Age Pension Plan today and then went to House leaders for advice as to what to do next.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., May 25.--When interviewers visited the survivors of the Squalus disaster at the Portsmouth Navy Yard Hospital today they stopped at one bed and asked the occupant what he thought about the accident.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., May 25.-- The men that the sea gave back told their story today. In hospital beds, but sitting up and cheerful, in a big white ward in the Portsmouth Navy Yard Hospital, they told what their actions were, their thoughts and their feelings when the submarine Squalus sank off the Isles of Shoals on Tuesday.
Marked increases in prices were recorded yesterday in most sections of the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange and trading was broader and more active than it had been.

An unusual record was attained by Charley (Red) Ruffing yesterday at the Stadium as the Yankees resumed their winning ways at the expense of Del Baker's Tigers and stretched their lead in the American League flag race to five and one-half games.

BRIELLE, N.J., May 25.--Fair weather and a flat sea form a combination that draws hundreds of anglers to this fishing port for mackerel, and most of them return home with enough fish for all the neighbors.

A memorandum urging Governor Lehman to sign the Ostertag bill providing for the regulation of employment agencies, which has been passed by the Legislature, was made public here yesterday by the Advisory Committee of New York Employment Agencies.

Assailing the action of the City Council in reducing the Park Department's 1939-49 budget by $285,561 as resulting from the "cheapest political motives," Park Commissioner Robert Moses called upon Mayor La Guardia yesterday to veto the cut.

CHICAGO, May 25.--James A. Farley, Postmaster General and chairman of the Democratic National Committee, who arrived here today on the last leg of a 7,500-mile trip, declared that, as a result of his talks with party leaders in thirteen States, he felt that the Democratic party would elect the next President.
PORTSMOUTH, N.H., May 25.-- A bitter act in a tragic drama of the sea was played today on the canted deck of the foundered submarine Squalus, almost forty fathoms below the surface of the Atlantic.

A meeting of stockholders of A.G. Spalding Bros. has been called for June 22 to act on a plan for financial recapitalization providing for merger of the present New Jersey company into A.G. Spalding Bros., Inc., newly incorporated under Delaware laws.

The creation of an educational trust fund to spread the latest knowledge of surgery throughout the United States was announced yesterday at the closing session of the International College of Surgeons in the Hall of Special Events at the World's Fair.

Ignace Jan Paderewski, the distinguished 78-year-old pianist, collapsed from what was officially announced as "a slight heart attack" last night in a dressing room in the Madison Square Garden a few minutes before he was scheduled to give the twenty-first concert of his present American tour, for which an audience of 15,000 had assembled.

Less than one-fifth of the total cost of distributing goods from producer to consumer is taken by the wholesaler, according to figures made public yesterday by the Twentieth Century Fund from the results of its study of the cost of distribution in this country, which has just been completed.

A block of 100 lots in Flushing, Queens, part of the forty-sevenacre Queens Valley Gulf Club tract recently purchased by the GrossMorton Corporation, has been sold by the latter concern to the Morton-Praver Corporation for $100,000.

CHICAGO, May 25.--Liberal profit-taking developed today in wheat, following an early upturn which carried all deliveries on the Chicago Board of Trade into new high ground for the season.

ROME, May 25 (AP).--Officials today listed 3,132 Italians killed in Spain. Altogether Italian casualties totaled 13,987. It was said that 2,000 of the wounded were disabled permanently. There were 366 prisoners who presumably were liberated.

Activities in some fields of distribution, notably in buying and selling by the large-unit type of store in the grocery field, may set a standard in the future that will force a reduction of retail marketing costs, Saul Cohn, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said yesterday at the concluding session of the conference of the management division of the association at the Hotel Astor.

LONDON, June 1.--After a whole day of trying to read the riddle of yesterday's speech in Moscow by Premier Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff, British officials were still confident tonight that a pact with Russia could be achieved fairly soon.

Chiefly because there were only four Sundays in May as against five in the like month of 1938, advertising linage in eight New York newspapers fell back fractionally last month, according to an analysis yesterday based on Media Records figures.

A client of Earl I. Gallant and Nathan Messinger, attorneys, has purchased from the Northpel Realty Corporation the property known as 1,521 Inwood Avenue and 1,522 Macomb Road, the Bronx, for cash above a first mortgage of $78,000.

BOSTON, June 1 (AP).--Skillful riding by Ruperto Donoso carried William C. Stroube's Sirasia to a neck decision over Mrs. Emil Denemark's Savitar in today's allowance mile for 3-year-olds at Suffolk Downs.

CHICAGO, June 1 (AP).--In a thirty-three-hit game that saw every regular on both teams except the pitchers hit safely at least once, the Senators today gained their first 1939 victory over the White Sox. The score was 10 to 7. The clubs have met six times this season.
WASHINGTON, June 1.--President Roosevelt nominated Herbert E. Gaston today to be an assistant secretary of the treasury. His confirmation by the Senate is expected.

One must admire the high heart of youth which inspires such deeds as the attempt by Thomas H. Smith to fly the North Atlantic from Old Orchard Beach to Ireland in a little single-engined plane. That effort, like the similar attempt by Carl Backman a few weeks ago, now seems certain to have ended in disaster.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 1.-- Cary Grant will be starred by RKO in "Passport to Life," a romantic melodrama about a racketeer and a child.
Sidewalk superintendents, those enthusiastic kibitzers who find their chief source of entertainment in watching the progress of excavation and construction work, take their job seriously.

The sharp increase in money in circulation in the week ended on Wednesday in the amount of $75,000,000, which lifted the total to a new high on the present movement, featured the weekly statement of the Federal Reserve System.
CHICAGO, June 1.--Prices of wheat advanced about 1 cent a bushel in the early trading on the Board of Trade here today, but there was no snap to the market.

BERLIN, June 1.--Early German press comment on last night's speech of Vyacheslaff Molotoff, the Soviet Premier and Foreign Commissar, is considerably guarded and confines itself chiefly to registering the reaction in London and Paris.

SHANGHAI, Friday, June 2 (AP).-- Difficulties of two British diplomatic officers with Japanese Army authorities in North China and a Japanese-British dispute at Tientsin today increased tension between Japan and Britain in the Far East.

The home of the Netherland Club at 3 Gramercy Park, a four-story building erected about seventy-five years ago, will be converted into small apartments as the result of its sale yesterday by the club to Eugene Schoen, architect. The club will vacate at once and move to new quarters in the Holland Building, Rockefeller Center.

The United States, which has founded and maintained its liberty on a Constitution 150 years old, may serve as an example to other countries where freedom is less in evidence, Messmore Kendall, President-General of the Sons of the American Revolution, declared yesterday in dedicating Washington Hall at the World's Fair.

Check exchanges of the leading cities throughout the country for the five-day week ended on Wednesday amounted to $4,309,267,000, or 6.5 per cent over the $4,048,005,000 total of the similar five-day week a year ago, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Our friend L.M. Henderson, the shooting and fishing illustrator, just returned from the Schoharie, where he put in four days of trout fishing. According to his report, this stream should be placed in the realm of the "fly-fisherman's dream."

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 1.-- Charley Whitehead of Plainfield, 1938 titleholder, reached the quarter-finals of the New Jersey State amateur golf championship today at the Montclair Golf Club when he won his first two matches with comparative ease.

Edgar M. Leventritt, lawyer, with offices at 30 Broad Street, died on Wednesday at his home, 850 Park Avenue, after a long illness. Mr. Leventritt, who was a talented amateur pianist and a patron of chamber music, was 65 years old.

When Big Johnny Mize slid safely into second in the ninth inning of yesterday's tense battle at the Polo Grounds, Burgess Whitehead threw the ball to the ground and his hat in the air in protesting the decision.

Trinity Sunday will be observed tomorrow in all the churches. There will be the annual Trinity ordinations this morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral and tomorrow morning in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., June 2. --Nearly every box was filled late this afternoon at the annual Tuxedo horse show being held today and tomorrow in the local horse show ring. Robert Moses, officiating as sole member of the New York City Parkway Authority, will preside at noon today at exercises marking completion of the Rockaway improvement. Heavy trading in the Bronx was marked yesterday by a good demand for multi-family buildings. Investors played an active part in the buying spurt.

The Belgian exhibit of diamonds worth an estimated $20,000,000 was opened to the public at the World's Fair yesterday, and four diamond cutters from Antwerp began their demonstration of modern means of handling and preparing stones in what was called the diamond capital of the world.

Spurred by the opportunity to land in the first division today, the Dodgers will send Tot Pressnell to the mound when they resume their series with the Cubs at Ebbets Field. The Chicagoans are expected to counter with Bill Lee.

LONDON, June 2.--After a hesitant start, the stock markets became brighter in later dealings today and were able to end the account on a firm though quiet note. With business small, gilt-edge securities were fractionally down.

The Most Rev. Francis J. Spellman, newly installed Archbishop of New York, will perform the ceremony of ordination this morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral for the first time in his own archdiocese. The service will begin at 8 o'clock and will last nearly three hours.

The one hundred and thirty-third session of the General Synod of the Reformed Church in America will begin on Thursday and continue through June 13 in the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, Seventy-seventh Street and West End Avenue.

The city's tax books showing assessed valuations finally fixed for the fiscal year from July 1, 1939, to June 30, 1940, have just been opened for inspection by property owners, and hundreds of taxpayers are busy looking over the records to get an idea of what their payments for the year will be.

The tourney was conducted on the Fresh Meadow links in Flushing.

Clergymen of three faiths at the Temple of Religion, the World's Fair, yesterday afternoon urged closer association among peoples and creeds. The interfaith meeting closed the Richmond Week celebration.

Grover Cleveland Bergdoll, wartime draft dodger, who has been in Castle Williams, the United States army prison on Governors Island, since his return from Germany on May 25, saw his youngest child for the first time yesterday.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, June 4. --Puerto Rico will have no more Governors appointed by the President if Congress acts favorably on a statehood request covered in a memorandum drafted by a joint legislative committee and now en route to Washington.

CLEVELAND, June 4 (AP).--Bob Feiler and Lefty Grove each won ball games today as the Indians captured the first of a double-header from the Red Sox, 10 to 2, and then surrendered, 7 to 1, in the nightcap.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 4.--In a hard, bruising battle fought over soggy turf the United States quartet turned back Great Britain today by a score of 11 to 7. The better team for the day won this opening game for the International Polo Challenge Cup, but it won only after it had been to the wars.

Memorial plaques or bands fastened to trees by war veterans' organizations and individuals have been removed by the Park Department because they impaired the growth of the trees. This was disclosed yesterday in a statement designed to answer criticism.
TORONTO, June 4.--Production of gold in Quebec in April amounted to 78,440 ounces, worth approximately $2,745,400, compared with $2,815,785 in March, the Quebec Bureau of Mines reports.

WASHINGTON, June 4.--President Roosevelt was said in informed Congressional circles today to have made up his mind to appoint Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, as administrator of the new consolidated Federal lending agency which will come into existence July 1 under the first government reorganization plan.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $2,556,266,394 last month, according to a compilation issued by the Exchange. Average price a share of all listed stocks on May 31 was $30.29, compared with $28.51 at the end of April.

GARRISON, N.Y., June 4.--The Rev. Dr. E. Clowes Chorley announced to the congregation of St. Philip's Protestant Episcopal Church-in-the-Highlands here this morning that he would retire as rector, which office he has held for thirty years, on May 6, 1940. He is 74 years old.

BERLIN, June 3.--German business circles this week were more interested in the happenings on the Stock Exchange than in the news from Moscow, because, contrary to all appearances, the turnover was heavier than in years past, although the officially recorded transactions were few.

LONDON, June 4.--Sir Henry Norman, distinguished in many fields, particularly in wireless telegraphy, died today'at his dome in Ramster, Chiddingfold, Surrey, at the age of 80.

WASHINGTON, June 4.--Farmers of the nation in 1938 had a gross income of $9,220,000,000, of which $482,000,000 represented government payments under conservation programs. The balance consisted of $7,538,000,000 cash receipts and $1,200,000,000 representing the value of products retained for farm consumption.

Henry Smythe Jr., chairman of the Benjamin Franklin Commission of the Sons of the American Revolution, to allot at once the funds needed, not more than $500, to provide for the display of a bronze statue of Franklin, the work of the late Paul W. Bartlett.

NEWARK, June 4 (AP).--Rapping out a total of twenty-nine hits, the league-leading Rochester Red Wings today widened their margin by whipping the Newark Bears in both ends of a double-header, 7 to 4 and 8 to 2. It was the second time this year that Newark suffered a twin setback.

At 3 o'clock yesterday the old screwball maestro, Carl Hubbell, ambled out of the Giants' dugout amid the cheers of 17,097 fans, a gallant, inspiring figure, seeking his second victory of the National League campaign in his fifth start, a scuffle with the league-leading Cincinnati Reds.

The New York Black Yankees turned back the Philadelphia Stars in the feature game of a doubleheader at the Yankee Stadium yesterday by a score of 5 to 4. In the other half of the twin bill the Baltimore Elites subdued the Cuban Stars, 7 to 4.

Contending that the Christian faith could meet present-day needs if our generation would only let it, the Rev. S.E. Gerard Priestley yesterday urged individuals to forego pessimism and to adopt a religious attitude.

George, who has been active in fisheries research, and it would seem the scientist also feels the need for greater unity between these two groups that are so often in conflict.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 4. --Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York will preside tomorrow at the commencement exercises of the College of New Rochelle as 157 students receive their degrees. ABOARD ROYAL TRAIN, June 4.--Through the forests of Ontario tonight, the royal train with King George VI and Queen Elizabeth aboard sped eastward toward the United States, which they will enter by way of Niagara Falls on Wednesday night.
BOSTON, June 4.--Francis E. Thompson, president of the Moxie Company of Boston since 1904, died today at his home in Arlington after an illness of five months. He was 74 years old.

Plans for the adoption of an "American Declaration of Tolerance and Equality" at thousands of community patriotic celebrations throughout the country on Independence Day were announced yesterday by the Council Against Intolerance in America.

ON the eve of the annual vacation exodus, Charles Hanson Towne conveniently provides northbound automobilists a book describing his motor trip through New England last Summer, "Jogging Around New England." HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 5.-- Jean Muir, who has been absent from the screen for two years, has returned to Hollywood to undergo tests at Selznick-International for the leading feminine role in "Rebecca," which is expected to start next month.

LANCASTER, Pa., June 5 (AP).-- Frederick Theodore Frelinghuysen Dumont, who spent twenty-five years in the American Foreign Service prior to his retirement in 1934 died yesterday at his home near here. His age was 70.

WASHINGTON, June 5.--Almost unanimous opposition by House Republicans blocked passage today of an Administration proposal to create a government library at Hyde Park, N.Y., to house President Roosevelt's papers.

WASHINGTON, June 6.--The Commodity Credit Corporation today announced a plan whereby financial institutions may continue their investment in the approximately $180,000,000 of 1938-39 cotton loans they are carrying.

SARATOGA, N.Y., June 5.-- President Laurens H. Seelye of St. Lawrence University offered four "pictures" for recognizing American social democracy in the commencement address at Skidmore College today.

The right to initiate charges in court against an employer accused of violating the National Labor Relations Act was denied to unions in an opinion handed down yesterday by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, which held that such action was the function of the National Labor Relations Board.

Fall lines of floor coverings were opened yesterday by small-rug producers with prices unchanged from Spring levels. A few fluctuations, such as a reduction of about 18 cents a yard by Armstrong Cork Company on its Marbelle Linoflor, were ascribed to manufacturing variations.
The stock market slipped a little lower yesterday in the slackest day's trading since May 15. Led by United States Government issues, gilt-edged bonds advanced.

The budget reductions made by the Republican majorities at Albany have still to be tested, both for their constitutionality and for their practicability. Practically, some of them may turn out to be good sense.

The City Council relief investigating committee voted yesterday to cite William Hodson, Commissioner of Welfare, for contempt after he refused to answer questions regarding a special fund composed of receipts from the annual police and firemen's baseball game.

LEXINGTON, Ky., June 5.-- Claude W. Spears of Lexington, noted breeder of trotting horses and an amateur trainer and driver, fell dead from a sulky today when exercising a yearling at the track of the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders Association. His age was 61.

The State Teachers Pension and Annuity Fund of New Jersey will offer for sale on Friday $1,217,000 of various issues of New Jersey municipal bonds, which will mature serially from 1940 to 1944. The bonds to be offered bear interest rates ranging from 4 to 6 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 5.--President Roosevelt conferred with legislative leaders, sent to the Senate the nomination of Claude G. Bowers to be Ambassador to Chile and other nominations and vetoed the bill to prevent exportation of tobacco seeds.

WASHINGTON, June 5.--President Roosevelt today vetoed a bill to prohibit the export of American tobacco seeds. He explained that the measure would encourage bootlegging and invite retaliation in more important commodities.

Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen announced yesterday that he was considering the institution of removal charges against Kings County Judge George W. Martin. Judge Martin was acquitted Saturday night by a blue-ribbon jury of charges of bribery and conspiracy to obstruct justice in dismissing an abortion indictment against a Brooklyn physician.

The possible failure of the State Legislature to extend in 1941 the law fixing New York City's subway fare at 5 cents would be "a very nice way to increase the fare without anybody being responsible for it," Transit Commissioner Reuben L. Haskell said yesterday at a transit unification hearing before the commission.

The temporary officers who shepherded the recently formed Association of Customers' Men throughout its formative period, headed by Albert C. Beeson of Eastman, Dillon Co., were elected formally yesterday to the same offices for the forthcoming year at a meeting in the Hotel New Yorker attended by more than 300 members.

Fuller, president of the Curtis Publishing Company, tonight designated business and the consumer as "economic Siamese twins," both suffering from the machinations of government, whose unofficial emissaries sat among the dinner guests he was addressing at the Hotel Statler.

WASHINGTON, June 5.--The Federal Trade Commission submitted today to Congress a voluminous report setting forth the result of its study of the automobile industry ordered by resolution of the last session.
LOS ANGELES, June 5.--Henry Vernon Foster, president of the Foster Petroleum Company, of Bartlesville, Okla., died today at the Good Samaritan Hospital of a heart ailment. His age was 63.

An application by County Clerk Archibald R. Watson for $41,500 fees for services rendered by him as counsel to the receivers in the Fox Theatres Corporation bankruptcy was postponed indefinitely yesterday by Federal Judge John C. Knox out of "considerations of public policy."

LONDON, June 5.--The defense of Russia's northwestern frontiers appeared tonight to be the only important point of disagreement still preventing the conclusion of a fullfledged defensive alliance between Britain, France and the Soviet Union.

Cadwalader of Philadelphia, president of the American Neurological Association, told the sixtyfifth annual meeting in the Hotel Ambassador here today.

Imports of $22,620,000 of gold were reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank. Of this amount, $13,014,000 arrived from England, $7,491,000 from The Netherlands, $2,105,000 from Colombia and $10,000 from Guatemala.

VATICAN CITY, June 5.--The favorable reception given to his recent diplomatic soundings with several European governments has encouraged Pope Pius to continue his efforts for peace, it was learned in authoritative Vatican circles today.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 5.-- Miss Laddie Irwin, 20-year-old golf star of Upper Montclair, hung up a new women's competitive course record when she led in a field of 101 players to win the qualifying medal of the thirty-ninth annual women's metropolitan golf championship with a score of 37, 38--75 at the Cherry Valley links today.

WASHINGTON, June 5.-- The American Iron and Steel Institute, whose members employ 450,000 persons, or 90 per cent of the workers in the steel industry, proposed today seven amendments to the National Labor Relations Act designed to give "complete protection of those liberties" which Congress had sought to conserve in the Wagner act.

PINE BEACH, N.J., June 5.-- Except for the commencement exercises in which seventy-one first classmen will be graduated tomorrow morning, June Week activities at Admiral Farragut Academy came to a close today with the last parade of the cadet corps for the year and the middies' graduation ball tonight.

Anne O'Hare McCormick of the editorial staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES was named "the Woman of 1939" at ceremonies marking Business and Professional Women's Day at the World's Fair yesterday.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 5.--Consumer education is here to stay. Authorities whose ideas about its future development more nearly bisected than paralleled each other, established this essential fact today as a consensus of the conference on business-consumer relations.

LONDON, June 5.--Although prices in many sections were firm, the expected revival on the first day of the stock market's new account failed to materialize today. With general rains over an extensive area of the cotton belt where dry weather has been reported urgently needed, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved into new high ground again yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 5.-- The House today refused, for the second time in recent weeks, to consider limited Wages and Hours Act amendments under the restriction that no member was to be permitted to offer any changes in addition.

The large apartment building on an irregular plot, 139 by 114 feet, at 844 Ocean Avenue, corner of Dorchester Road, Brooklyn, has been sold by Jacob Schultz Sons to Covington Properties, Inc. Sale was for cash subject to a mortgage held by the Kings County Trust Company.

Fresh impetus appeared in the market for United States Government securities yesterday with the announcement that the Treasury will exchange five-year per cent notes for the 1 3/8 per cent notes due on Sept. 15.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, June 7. --R.M. Tinkler, a British former inspector of the Shanghai municipal police, died in Japanese custody today after an emergency operation for injuries suffered in a scuffle with a Japanese naval landing party.

JERUSALEM, June 6.--The Jewish city of Tel Aviv was virtually cut off from the outside world today when, by order of the British military commander of the Southern District, all Jewish motor traffic into or out of the city was prohibited until tomorrow night. Only medical and milk transportation is permitted.

WASHINGTON, June 6.--The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the granting of applications by the Philadelphia, Detroit and Pittsburgh Stock Exchanges to extend unlisted trading priviliges to certain stocks and the denial of similar applications in each case in regard to others.

The United States Maritime Commission, in Washington, suspended yesterday schedules of proposed cargo-lot shipments in the westbound intercoastal trade, which were filed some weeks ago by six members of the Intercoastal Steamship Freight Association.

MANCHESTER, England, June 6.--Sydney Wooderson showed 5,000 English foot-racing fans today that he's ready for his mile duel with Glenn Cunningham June 17 by running three-quarters of a mile in the world-record time of 2 minutes 59.5 seconds.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 6.-- Negotiations between Julie Haydon and Warner Brothers, by which the Broadway actress would appear as the maid in James Hilton's "We Are Not Alone," with Paul Muni and Flora Robson, were halted to day when Miss Haydon declined to commit herself to a term contract.

Plans for a new $2,233,000 vocational high school in Queens to seat 2,500 students were announced yesterday by Ellsworth B. Buck, vice president of the Board of Education and chairman of its buildings and sites committee.

WASHINGTON, June 6.--All over Washington the Union Jack is flying with the Stars and Stripes. At the Capitol, the Union Station and the length of Constitution and Pennsylvania Avenues, trees and lamp posts are blossoming with flags, unfurled today in readiness for the arrival on Thursday of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6.--The 6,786 yards of the Philadelphia Country Club's Spring Mill course got a thorough going over today as the advance guard tried out all the angles in preparation for the fortythird national open championship, which starts on Thursday.

Additional business firms that intend to participate in the Business and Industrial Subscription Plans of the Stadium Concerts have been announced by Mrs. Pierpont Morgan Hamilton, chairman of the 1939 Music Festival Committee of the Stadium Concerts.

WASHINGTON, June 6.--Constantin A. Oumansky presented his credentials to President Roosevelt today as Soviet Ambassador. He praised particularly President Roosevelt's appeal for peace.

ALBANY, June 6.--Governor Lehman signed today the Nunan bill implementing the provision in the new Constitution under which the State will provide for children attending denominational and private schools health and welfare services similar to those now afforded public-school pupils.

Expansion of ship-manufacturing facilities and other expenditures of the Bethlehem Steel Company are proposed to be financed by the sale of an issue of about $25,000,000 of mortgage bonds toward the end of this month, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 6.--President Roosevelt today postponed his trip to the Pacific Coast pending Congressional action on the new relief appropriation and a resolution extending the manufacturers excise taxes beyond June 30, their expiration date.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 7.--Edward J. O'Connell, Albany County Democratic chairman, died at his home here tonight. His age was 51 years.

Plumley, general manager of the Stamford plant of the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company, told a Senate Labor subcommittee today that he believed it necessary to employ "labor spies."

NEWARK, June 6.--The Essex County Symphony Society began its fourth annual festival of June concerts last night in the City Schools Stadium before the largest audience this series has ever attracted. Officials estimated the attendance at 23,000.

LONDON, June 6.--Although the stock markets today remained quiet, despite encouraging employment figures, a firmer tone developed in Some sections after early hesitation. The outstanding feature of the session was the sharp rise in Brazilian bonds on a statement that the Brazilian Government is considering the resumption of payments.

Behind a haze of smoke from his pipe, Professor Harry Allen Overstreet, head of the City College Department of Philosophy, relaxed in ha large chair after meeting his last class in forty years of teaching and spoke of the adult education movement as "the greatest thing that was happening in America today," and of its role in "staving off the catastrophe we're all afraid of."

CARIBOU, Me., June 6.--The only unsatisfactory feature of a fishing trip to Maine is the fact that you must leave sometime. Willard Galbert, our guide, began pointing out the fishing possibilities of the Allagash while we were returning from the Eagle Lake Thoroughfare to camp.
WASHINGTON, June 6.--President Roosevelt declined today to be drawn into a discussion of his plans for 1940 or his possible candidacy for a third term.

For enthusiasm it was a greeting unsurpassed by any during this royal tour.

Hof.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,558,800 barrels, against 3,585,250 in the preceding week, a decline of 26,450, according to the American Petroleum Institute. EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 6.-- Roy Macdonald Syme, 27-year-old lawnmower salesman and garageman, of 12 Meadow Street, will be presented with his wife to King George VI and Queen Elizabeth Saturday in the British Pavilion at the World's Fair, at the Queen's special request, it was learned today.

Ferrer of 10 East Sixty-sixth Street and the late Dr. Ferrer, took place yesterday noon in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola. The ceremony was performed by Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle.

Ted Peckham, young college graduate whose "escort service for lonesome women" at 116 East Fiftyeighth Street was reported to have developed into a lucrative enterprise, was found guilty yesterday in Special Sessions of operating the business without a city license.

PARIS, June 6.--Information from Budapest sent privately by Hungarians to relatives and friends here is to the effect that the present month will be fateful for the country. A military dictatorship is well within the bounds of possibility.

BERLIN, Md., June 6 (AP).--War Admiral struck his colors today. Owner Samuel D. Riddle announced through William Whaley, manager of his Glen Riddle Farms, that the 3-year-old champion of 1937 would be retired "within the next few days."

WASHINGTON, June 6.--The value of exports of merchandise, including re-exports, from the United States in April, as reported today by the Division of Foreign Trade Statistics of the Department of Commerce, was $230,947,000, compared with $274,472,000 in April, 1938. For the four months ended

WASHINGTON, June 6.--A beautiful palm tree unknown to science before President Roosevelt visited Cocos Island in the Pacific Ocean last year has been named Rooseveltia Frankliniana, the Smithsonian Institution announced today. The palm, described as very striking, constitutes an entirely new genus as well as a new species and similar palms discovered elsewhere in the future will carry the name Rooseveltia.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., June 6.-- Mayor Charles W. Kress of Binghamton was arrested early tonight on a bench warrant, following his indictment on eighteen extortion counts by a Broome County grand jury which has been investigating vice and gambling conditions in this city.

LONDON, June 6.--Wires have been fixed to the bow and stern of the ill-fated submarine Thetis, tomb of ninety-nine men, and other wires have been passed under her amidships, Earl Stanhope, First Lord of the Admiralty, told the House of Lords today.
NANTUCKET, Mass., June 6 (AP). --George D. Faweett, famed stage and screen actor, died tonight at the age of 77.

PARIS, June 6 (AP).--General Marie Gustave Gamelin today became supreme commander of France's defense forces.

Firemen responding to four alarms fought a blaze in the East New York section of Brooklyn for more than an hour yesterday afternoon before bringing it under control and spent two hours more at the scene before the fire was extinguished.
LONDON, June 6.--Augustus Schmidt, Minister of Estonia in London, met Viscount Halifax, the British Foreign Secretary, today.

Four firemen were overcome by smoke and two were cut on the hands.

SAN JUAN, P.R., June 6.--Nineteen hundred Spanish Republican refugees paused here a few hours today en route to Mexico to take up new homes and begin new lives. They were aboard the French steamer Sinai and had come from the concentration camp at ArgelesSur-Mer, France.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 6.-- With the most interesting and varied program in many years, the West Point Horse Show Association reached its majority today, the twenty-first annual exhibition opening with more classes and featured numbers than in the past.

WASHINGTON, June 6.--An attempt to write an automatic embargo on arms exports to belligerents into the Bloom neutrality resolution was defeated by the House Foreign Affairs Committee today. The measure is proposed to replace the existing Neutrality Act.
LONDON, June 6.--Detroit made a bid for the 1944 Olympic Games today, but delegates to the International Olympic Committee conference indicated the Motor City's chance won't come until 1948.

ABOARD ROYAL TRAIN, in Ontario, June 6.--The progress of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth through Canada took them late, today to Windsor, just across the Detroit River from American soil, which they will touch tomorrow night for the first time.
NAPLES, Italy, June 6.--Italy's conquering army from Spain paraded through Naples this morning to receive the tributes of the King, tha government and the people.

NEW HAVEN, Conn, June 6.-- Dr. Stephen J. Maher, distinguished authority on tuberculosis and discoverer of a formula for treatment of the disease, died of a heart attack at his home here today. He was 79 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 6.--Admiral William D. Leahy, retiring Chief of Naval Operations, was nominated today by President Roosevelt to be Governor of Puerto Rico. The action was taken soon after the White House had announced Mr. Roosevelt's acceptance of the resignation of General Blanton Winship, Governor of Puerto Rico for several years.

CHICAGO, June 6--While the wheat market showed a firm undertone today, there was much less outside interest than of late with a growing disposition shown to await new incentives and the government's report on the crop due after the close on Friday.

As a test for her new type of Diesel-electric propulsion, plant, the tug Sheila Moran of the Moran Towing Company was assigned yesterday to get the 43,450-ton liner Ile de France out of her dock, and to turn the large vessel around in the Hudson for her course out to sea.
CLEVELAND, June 6 (AP)--Five runs behind, the Indians rallied in the last two innings today, sent Eldon Auker to the showers and downed the Red Sox, 8-7, to take the series, three games to one.

DETROIT, June 6.--Baseball being a game wherein wonders never cease, the mighty Yankees, known far and wide and also euphoniously as the Bronx. Bombers, were held to a meager output of four hits today. This was the second time in two days that such a thing has happened.

Twenty Staten Island parks were inspected yesterday on a fifty-twomile tour by members of the Park Association of New York City and representatives of various civic bodies.

The Rev. Dr. Alexander Lyons, rabbi at large of the Eighth Avenue Temple, Brooklyn, who worked indefatigably for the promotion of good-will and cooperation between Christians and Jews, died of pneumonia Monday night in his home at 295 St. John's Place, Brooklyn, after an illness of eight days. He would have been 72 years old June 19.

WASHINGTON, June 6.--The five-to-two decision through which Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, N.J., was defeated in the Supreme Court yesterday spoke for itself, and the ruling of the court would strengthen the protection of civil liberties generally, President Roosevelt said at a press conference today.

WASHINGTON, June 6.--Excerpts purporting to be from an official hearing of the National Labor Relations Board tended to show today that a board attorney had sought to "propagandize" an employe on the witness stand to join the American Federation of Labor or the Congress of Industrial Organizations rather than to remain in an independent plant employe association.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 6.--Four major and various minor references to the role of advertising in the relations of the producer and the consumer featured the conference on that topic which closed here today.

Governor Leverett Saltonstall of Massachusetts presided at ceremonies which marked the formal opening of the Massachusetts section of the New England Building at the World's Fair yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice Joseph Force Crater, who disappeared in August, 1930, was declared legally dead yesterday by Surrogate James A. Foley, who also directed that the will be admitted to probate. The will leaves an estate of $30,000 to the widow, Mrs. Stella M. Kunz of 1 Bank Street.

Bills for the re-enactment of the city's emergency tax program, retaining the 1-cent tax on cigarettes but substituing a compensating use tax for the personal property tax to cover out-of-town purchases by New Yorkers, were submitted to the City Council yesterday by Newbold Morris, President of the Council.

WASHINGTON, June 6.--A lifesize statue of Will Rogers was unveiled today in the rotunda of the Capitol, the gift of Oklahoma to the nation. The games were last held in London in 1908.

BARCELONA, Spain, June 13 (AP). --A Yugoslav architect, twelve times sentenced to death by Spanish Republicans, faced possible execution by strangulation tonight by Nationalists who charged he built and decorated cells in which prisoners were tortured to blindness and insanity.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 13.--Nineteen eight-oared crews moved over a placid Hudson in double workouts today as the complete flotilla of seven colleges began final preparation for the regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association Saturday.

WASHINGTON, June 13.--Radu Irimescu, the Rumanian Minister, has been authorized by Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, to discuss with Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, any proposals his government may have in mind for a new settlement of its war debt to the United States.

Edward Sandford Martin, author and editor, who was a founder of The Harvard Lampoon in 1876, and who founded the magazine Life in 1883 and became its first editor, died yesterday morning in the Orthopaedic hospital after an illness of three months. His age was 83 years.

WASHINGTON, June 13.--A system under which all needy persons over 60 years of age would receive a maximum monthly pension of $60 was recommended to the executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations today by its committee on social security, of which Sherman Dalrymple is chairman.

LOS ANGELES, June 13--Long John Woodruff, Pittsburgh's star runner, may find his plans for the week-end changed for the third time in as many days.

Dismissal of 1,500 employes of the Federal theatre project in this city, reducing the number on the project to about 2,000, was announced yesterday after receipt of orders from Washington by Paul Edwards, New York director of the Federal arts projects. The dismissals are to be effective July 1.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University and head of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, will sail today on the Normandie to confer with European associates on a readjustment of the endowment's activities to meet changing international conditions.

The woman-trained horse with the nautical name, Belay, who had raced so gamely and well to take second in the Belmont Stakes, ran an amazingly fast mile and a sixteenth at Aqueduct yesterday in 1:43 2-5 to serve notice that he was a worthy 3-year-old.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, June 13 (AP).--The Scotch took one canny glance at the entry list for the British open golf championship tonight and quickly made America's Sam Snead, who blew a chance to win the United States open on the last hole, and Henry Cotton, the English stylist, joint favorites at 12 to 1. The championship will be played July 3-8.

BERLIN, June 13.--The British Government's plan to create a Ministry of Information aroused great indignation today in Germany, which has a Ministry of Popular Enlightenment and Propaganda under Dr. Joseph Goebbels.

Mayor Hague of Jersey City took his Supreme Court defeat at its face value, as a good Mayor and a good citizen ought to do, and on Monday evening gave ample police protection to the meeting of the American Civil Liberties Union in Journal Square.

Two men and two women who are alleged to have defrauded the Prudential Life Insurance Company of $10,000 by having a healthy man take a life insurance examination for two policies aggregating that sum in the name of a man fatally ill with cancer and heart disease were arrested yesterday in Brooklyn.

PARIS, June 13.--All of the 907 German-Jewish emigres on board the Hamburg-American liner St. Louis who were barred from Cuba, will find temporary refuge in European countries when their ship returns within the next few days.

ELINOR WYLIE and Lawrence of Arabia are silhouetted against the pages of Kathleen Coyle's new novel, "Immortal Ease."* To say this can be no indiscretion. The Laurentian parallel to the novel's hero, Lloyd Emmot, is apparent long before he changes his name, to become known, at the height of his chiaroscuro Arabian celebrity, as Colonel L.E. Folgates of Yaffa.

Precinct 110-A, where New York City policemen are quartered in the World of Tomorrow, has adopted the black-out technique to confuse midges, Douglass-twin-motor mosquitos and other winged things that rise from the outer rim of the meadow after dark.
Department stores in the metropolitan area will begin on Monday the sale of automobiles as part of their varied merchandise, it was disclosed yesterday.

FORT LEE, N.J., June 13.-- Burned beyond recognition, the body of a middle-aged man, apparently a murder victim, was found this morning, one leg wired to a tree, in dense woods along the edge of the Palisades in Palisades Interstate Park, about 300 feet north of Ben Marden's Riviera restaurant.

CHICAGO, June 13.--The American Library Association asked the Senate today to deny confirmation of Archibald MacLeish, the poet, as Librarian of Congress, because "he lacks the essential qualifications of a librarian."

NEWARK, N.J., June 13.--The trial of Frank Matt, Belleville coal and ice dealer, on a charge of jury-fixing in the recent Newark land conspiracy trial of Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein and eight other defendants, ended in a mistrial tonight after the jury was unable to reach a verdict in five and threequarter hours of deliberation.

ALBANY, June 13.--Governor Lehman signed today the Todd bill opening the door for equal representation of the sexes on all political committees. The present law provides for equal representation on the State committees.
BOSTON, June 13.--The sense of patriotism and public trust synonymous with the office will dissuade Franklin D. Roosevelt from seeking a third term in 1940, Alfred M. Landon asserted Today.

The Southern Railway has approached holders of its $50,000,000 of 6 and 6 per cent development and general mortgage bonds, due in 1956, with a view to retiring the bonds under a plan of conversion, it was disclosed yesterday at the office of the company. The annual interest of $3,150,000 on these bonds has been a burden to the road in recent years.

Joseph Paterno of Riverdale, former immigrant newsboy who became a leading builder of New York apartment houses, died yesterday of pneumonia in Doctors Hospital. He was 58 years old.

Mayor La Guardia's campaign to prevent the stoppage of work on future low-cost housing developments because of jurisdictional disputes between labor unions appeared nearer to a successful conclusion yesterday after a meeting of the Building and Construction Trades Council in its auditorium at 176 Madison Avenue.

The new Cunard White Star liner Mauretania, which sails on Saturday on her maiden voyage from Liverpool to New York, will receive her first official greeting from the City of New York on the following Wednesday, when Mayor La Guardia will speak to the liner in a broadcast radio-telephone conversation.

Fordham University, founded ninety-eight years ago by New York's first Archbishop, will welcome back as an alumnus the sixth Archbishop of the diocese this afternoon in the person of the Most Rev. Francis J. Spellman of the class of '11, who will confer 562 degrees in course and five honorary degrees at the university's ninety-fourth annual commencement on Edwards Parade beginning at 4 P.M.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., June 13. --The Dodgers started their western trip with a defeat today, but fortunately it won't count in the National League standing.

The happiest, prettiest and proudest member of the Georgia delegation which arrived here yesterday to participate in today's Georgia Day program at the World's Fair was Mrs. Jill Taylor, wife of Lieut. Col. Jack Taylor, director of the Georgia State Girls' Military Band.
Major league baseball will get back into full swing on all fronts today, now that the Cooperstown celebration is over. At the Stadium the Yankees hope to pick up where they left off.

With the number of World's Fair visitors showing an alarming drop last week-end, members of the Hotel Association joined yesterday with Mayor La Guardia's Official World's Fair Housing Bureau in assuring out-of-town residents that there was ample accommodation in all classes of lodging available here at moderate rates.

Rules to supplement the prohibition of margin trading by partners in firms doing business directly with the public are expected to be presented today to the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange. Most of these are expected to deal with exemptions, notably for odd-lot dealers and specialists in the issues for which they are registered.

Justice Ferdinand Pecora disclosed yesterday in Supreme Court that several of the defendants and prosecution witnesses in the garment racket case had been killed and others had disappeared mysteriously within recent months. He said he knew of no prosecution attended by so many crimes of violence.

WASHINGTON, June 13.--A denial that the Workers Alliance had sought to dictate labor relations decisions of the Works Progress Administration was made before the House Appropriations subcommittee today by Colonel F.C. Harrington, WPA Administrator.
