WASHINGTON, June 13.--Assurance that the United States "stands ready at all times to renew its faith in the principle of complete liberty of conscience," was contained in a message of welcome from President Roosevelt to the Central Conference of American Rabbis, which opened its golden jubilee convention here today.

ALBANY, June 13.--Both Republicans and Democrats joined today in telling the Appellate Division of the Third Department, summoned to hear the suit over the constitutionality of the budget reductions made by the Republican Legislature, that every State budget since 1932 had contained invalid and unconstitutional "general provisions."
TRENTON, N.J., June 13.--The State Board of Tax Appeals was asked today by counsel for nine railroads to cut their 1937 and 1938 assessments by at least 45 per cent.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., June 13.-- Lasting and stable peace cannot possibly be gained through a policy of isolation, Francis B. Sayre, Assistant Secretary of State, today told the largest graduating class, 298, in the history of Lehigh University.

Remarking that he saw little reason for leniency, Federal Judge Charles C. Briggle yesterday imposed severe sentences on a couple and their nephew, who were convicted recently as officers of the Falstaff Press, Inc., for distributing obscene books and pamphlets through the mails.

SAINT JOHN, N.B., June 13.-- Lumberjacks in their corduroy breeches and high-laced boots stopped in their work today to shout a hurrah for King George VI and Queen Elizabeth as they motored through the sparsely settled timberland of New Brunswick. This was the seventh of Canada's nine Provinces to be visited in the royal tour.
LONDON, June 13.--After an extension of yesterday's general setback in the early dealings today, the stock markets here turned better near the close, although trading continued on a restricted scale.

A banking syndicate headed by the First National Bank of New York and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of $6,922,0000 of refunding bonds of Detroit, Mich., on a bid of 100.0023 for $2,884,000 due on July 15, 1940 to 1952, as 3 s, and $4,038,000 due on July 15, 1953 to 1962, as 3 s, or at a net interest cost to the city of 3.55758 per cent.

Sixteen men and four women members of the Workers Alliance, who staged a sitdown strike in a Brooklyn. Home Relief office last month were found guilty of disorderly conduct yesterday afternoon by Magistrate Jacob Eilperin in Bay Ridge Court.

With general rain in Alabama, where twenty-one of the twentyfour reporting stations had moisture and eleven of them more than half an inch, anticipation of another less favorable crop report today strengthened prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday.
The Department of Social Welfare exhibit in the New York State Building was dedicated yesterday after members of the Board of Social Welfare held their regular monthly meeting there.

LANSING, Kan., June 13.--A mutiny by 229 convicts at the Kansas State penitentiary today to back up demands for silk underwear and bedtime snacks in their cells ended after four hours with their capitulation.

Mrs. Mary Sullivan, 30 years old, of 42-17 Sixty-sixth Street, Woodside, Queens, and her son, Roger, 3, were killed by an automobile shortly after noon yesterday as they were walking along the sidewalk of Woodside Avenue near Sixty-seventh Street, Woodside. Another child was injured.

Magistrate Joseph D'Andrea in Coney Island Court, Brooklyn, re served decision yesterday in a case designed as a "test" of a Police Department order prohibiting street meetings on Kings Highway between Ocean Avenue and Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 14.-- All attention here is concentrated on the British-Japanese trial of strength, which opened in Tientsin today. Habituated by two years of reports of victories, the public has no doubt of the outcome.

Vice President John N. Garner's popularity with Democratic voters as a possible candidate for 1940 has leveled off slightly in recent weeks, while James A. Farley's popularity has increased sharply, according to the results of a new nation-wide survey of Democratic voters by the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is director.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13.-- American democracy is faced by the threat of economic collectivism and the only way to preserve democracy is through religion, Attorney General Frank Murphy declared today at the commencement exercises of St. Joseph's College.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 (AP).-- A suit demanding an accounting of $9,000,000 in addition to the action for $4,000,000 that was filed on March 30 last, was brought today against six estates and ten living directors of the Pennroad Corporation in United States District Court.

BALTIMORE, June 13.--The body of a well-dressed man found in the harbor today was identified at the Mercy Hospital as that of James Hamlin Gardner Soper, a portrait painter for whom a number of Baltimore residents sat during the last two years.
PARIS, June 13.--A gesture by French fishermen has brought their dispute with the British over Minquier Islands, off the Brittany Coast, before the diplomacy of the two countries.

Three centuries ago the Low Countries, as they were then known, the Netherlands and Belgium of today, earned the name of being "a common harbor of all heresies." They had established religious tolerance.

Frank Monmouth Chambers, magazine illustrator, painter and interior decorator, died of a coronary thrombosis in Kings County Hospital, Brooklyn, on Sunday after a brief illness. Mr. Chambers, who lived at 130 Hicks Street, was 73 years old.

Mayor La Guardia's cherished plan to have the position of Commissioner of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity made a competitive civil service job has been thwarted by the State Civil Service Commission, it was learned yesterday.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week amounted to 3,376,950 barrels, compared with 3,558,800 barrels in the preceding week, a decline of 181,850 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 114,050 barrels less than the calculated daily requirements of 3,491,000 barrels by the Bureau of Mines for June.

The Academy of Sports at the World's Fair is unique in one respect. This was evident yesterday when the sports center of the Fair was opened for a preview before the formal throwing open of the doors today.

WASHINGTON, June 13.--After a conference with Charles A. Edison, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, President Roosevelt expressed himself today as highly pleased with the rate of progress in the naval construction program as compared with that of a year ago.

Homer St. Gaudens, director of the Department of Fine Arts of the Carnegie Institute in Pittsburgh, returned on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania yesterday from his annual quest in Europe for paintings for the institute's annual international exhibition, which will be held this year from Oct. 15 to Dec. 10.

A committee of the League of New York Theatres meets tomorrow with Sidney R. Fleischer, attorney for the Dramatists Guild, with a view to learning the status of negotiations for a resumption of motion picture financing of Broadway plays.

The campaign of the Greater New York Fund received new impetus yesterday when J.P. Morgan, John D. Rockefeller Jr. and other financial and business leaders took on jobs as solicitors of contributions.

WASHINGTON, June 13.--Revival of reports that President Roosevelt might insist upon new taxes at this session as the price for approving the unbudgeted farm aid of about $400,000,000 recently voted by the Senate, added today to the nerve strain of Congressional leaders who are trying hard to end the session by July 15.

Executives who oppose the use of standards in business management were assailed yesterday by Dr. John Gaillard, consulting engineer, in a speech at the convention of the National Office Management Association at the Hotel New Yorker. Despite reports of spotty conditions in general business, projected industrial construction work in New York State is maintaining a level which indicates that many firms are anticipating trade improvement in the near future and are preparing to get their share of the increase.

ROME, June 13.--Another great merger of Italian business was authorized yesterday by Premier Benito Mussolini, thus bringing ever closer the apparently inevitable day when all Italian industry will be concentrated in a dozen or so great monopolies.

Ceremonies marking the 128th birthday of Harriet Beecher Stowe, author of "Uncle Tom's Cabin," were held yesterday in the Hall of Fame on the New York University campus at University Heights, the Bronx. Seventy-five pupils of the Harriet Beecher Stowe High School and Public Schools 89 and 139 participated.

An international Restaurant Conference--the first in the industry's history--began its four-day program at the Hotel Astor yesterday, with more than 500 restaurateurs of this country and Europe in attendance. Arranged by the New York State Restaurant Association, the conference will end on Friday when Restaurant Day is observed at the World's Fair.

The New Jersey anglers who have been waiting impatiently for the opening of the black bass season can get their tackle in shape for an early start tomorrow morning, for the season will be open at that time.

John F. Geis, dean of Brooklyn's newspaper reporters, died yesterday morning in Long Island College Hospital after a heart attack. Mr. Geis, who was 67 years old, was the City Hall correspondent for The Brooklyn Daily Eagle.

ROME, June 13.--Negotiations between Italy and Bulgaria for a new commercial agreement to intensify trade between them began today. It is reported Bulgaria desires to increase her exports to Italy so as to make her less dependent on Germany which buys nearly 80 per cent of her exports.

NEWTON, Mass., June 4 (AP).-- Mrs. Warr en Beard of Charles River, playing on her own course, won her second major golf title in as many weeks today by putting together a fifty-four-hole total of 241 to gain the women's Eastern golf championship.

LONDON, June 14 (AP)--Viscount Wimborne, former member of Parliament, Paymaster-General and Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, died todad after a month's illness. He was 66 years old. Lady Wimborne reached his bedside Monday, after hurrying home from a visit in the United States.

Plans for establishing a border of trees along Sixth Avenue were approved yesterday by the Sixth Avenue Association as part of a campaign to beautify the street that already has been made more presentable by removal of the elevated structure.

WASHINGTON, June 15.--In preparation for the forthcoming battle over revision of the Neutrality Act, twenty-one Senators have signed a declaration of principles which they believe must be followed. These ideas are, for the most part, in direct opposition to the wishes of the Administration.

Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that he would abandon his policy of being neutral in nothing and observe strict impartiality between the Police and Fire Department baseball teams when they hold their annual contest at the Polo Grounds Saturday afternoon.

He was already certain, beyond any question, of an outstanding place as one of the most influential thinkers of his time. He might have settled down to the tranquillity of complete leisure in the refuge from hatred, prejudice and intolerance to which England had welcomed him, in St. John's Wood.

Eugene Harkavy of 10 Monroe Street will walk tonight with his classmates in the procession at the ninety-third commencement exercises in Lewisohn Stadium to receive his second college degree-- just old enough to be taken for an accredited member of a high school graduating class.

TIENTSIN, China, Wednesday, June 21 (AP)--One hundred British women and children were evacuated from Tientsin's blockaded British Concession today as the second week of Japan's "siege" began. They began a 200-mile voyage to Peitaiho, a resort to the north on the coast.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., June 20.--One of those good old gashouse district brawls is shaping up for the gallery when Joe Louis and Tony Galento collide in the Yankee Stadium a week from tomorrow night. There may not be much of it, but it will be good while it lasts.

BERLIN, June 21 (AP).--The German Government announced today that it had asked Great Britain to recall her consul general at Vienna, Donald St. Clair Gainer.
LONDON, June 21.--News from the Far East created caution in the stock markets today, with the result that most sections receded in quiet trading.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 21.--To members of the American Library Association, in national convention, came the voice today of Jan Masaryk, former Minister to England from Czecho-Slovakia. Radio brought his plea nearly 7,000 miles, urging Americans to safeguard their thousands of book sanctuaries in the name of freedom and democracy.

WASHINGTON, June 21.--Cooperative efforts on the part of life insurance companies to minimize risks with respect to physical impairment of potential policyholders were described to the Temporary National Economic Committee today in the final presentation of insurance data by the Securities and Exchange Commission before the whole committee.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 21.-- The news here today once more centered on the Yale crew quarters at Gales Ferry when this morning it appeared that the string of bad luck had not yet left the Elis. When the varsity went out for its morning row.

Stagnation in the building industry resulting from restraints imposed by producers of materials, distributors, contractors, labor and local legislation will be attacked through the anti-trust laws in a nation-wide campaign about to be started by the Department of Justice, Assistant Attorney General Thurman Arnold declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 21.--Mayor La Guardia of New York came to the assistance today of the Congressional farm Group in its attempt to put through an unbudgeted increase of about $365,000,000 for agricultural aid against the opposition of President Roosevelt.

CANTON, N.Y., June 21.--Appeals by Canadian speakers to the United States to take over the world leadership which they said Great Britain seemed to be laying down were answered by American delegates to the Canadian-American Affairs Conference today with the statement that fascism must be checked in both Europe and Asia.

While a woman pleaded with him from the top-floor window of a tenement fifty feet away, John Roth, 70 years old, of 60-62 Putnam Avenue, Queens, dived yesterday afternoon to his death from the elevated structure at Fiftieth Street and Second Avenue. He was a retired painter.

Wendell L. Willkie, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, made yesterday an urgent plea to the joint conference committees of the House of Representatives and the Senate "to exercise the utmost of good-will" and

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 21. --Frankie Strafaci of Brooklyn and Richard (Dick) Chapman of Greenwich today resumed their rivalry where they left off on Saturday in the final round of the metropolitan amateur golf championship and the result was the same as it was then.
Business activity improved slightly in May despite further declines in a number of important durable goods industries, according to The Annalist.

It was "five-and-ten-cent day" yesterday for 25,000 New York public school pupils at the Fair. For seven hours, interrupted only by a short period for lunch, the youngsters visited the exhibits and set up a merry din in the amusement zone.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 21.-- Trinity Episcopal Church in Roslyn was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Beatrice R. Brown, daughter of Mrs. Henry B. Thompson Jr. and the late Lieut. William C. Brown Jr., to Edmund

Problems of the preservation of democracy and of the peace and safety of the United States in a chaotic world furnished the theme for speakers last night at the ninety-third annual commencement exercises of City College in Lewisohn Stadium. A record number of 2,351 degrees, diplomas and commissions were conferred.

A new challenge to the Occidental powers has come from the Japanese. Tokyo's naval commander at newly captured Swatow today ordered all foreign warships including an American destroyer and a British destroyer, to leave that seaport. [Page 1.]

STANTON, Del., June 21 (AP).-- Rioter, racing for Thomas Hitchcock, was a driving winner of the $6,000 added Indian River Steeplechase Handicap at Delaware Park today. The headliner, second steeplechase feature of the meeting, was over the stake course at about two and one-half miles.

Inclusion by the Senate Finance Committee in its Tax Bill amendments of a provision allowing a business to use the "last-in-firstout" method of computing inventory valuations in relation to sales in calculating profits for tax purposes was welcomed yesterday by proponents of this method among accountants and trade association executives. The Tanners Council of America has been principal sponsor of this proposal.
TOKYO, Thursday, June 22.-- What Seems to have been the first result of British protests was a conference of Japanese military and diplomatic authorities in Tientsin yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 21.--A series of four treaties and conventions with Panama, which have been hanging fire for more than three years after the Panama Congress had ratified them, were favorably reported today by the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations. Their ratification was recommended by a vote of 14 to 3.
WASHINGTON, June 21.--Testimony designed to show that all Southern cotton manufacturers are not opposed to the proposed minimum wake of 32 cents per hour for the cotton silk, rayon and linen

Acting on direct orders from the office of Mayor La Guardia, Inspector Michael J. Murphy of Police Commissioner Valentine's confidential squad yesterday afternoon raided three offices in the building at 11 West Forty-second Street where it is alleged that handbooks on horse racing were being operated. The raiders arrested a woman and four men on charges of bookmaking.

Mrs. George U. Harvey walked through the gates of the World's Fair yesterday without benefit of the pass so abruptly revoked by the treasury department of the exposition and spent half the day on the grounds.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 21.-- Before an audience of 2,700 persons in Woolsey Hall who rose as one to greet him with applause, Eduard Benes, former President of CzechoSlovakia, received the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws today from President Seymour of Yale University.

Retail sales of 321,614 passenger cars and trucks during May were 44 per cent above last year, the Automobile Manufacturers Association reported yesterday. Included in the month's total were 275,457 passenger cars and 46,157 trucks. The gain in passenger cars was 47 per cent, while trucks gained 30 per cent.

Sandy-haired Joe Burk, generally acknowledged the greatest sculler in the world, sailed aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary yesterday for England, where next month he will defend the Diamond Sculls championship at the 100th anniversary of the famed Henley regatta.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts made yesterday an award of $5,000,000 of short-term notes to the Second National Bank of Boston on a 0.064 per cent interest basis. The notes, dated June 27, will fall due on Nov. 23.

We brushed up on our Ogallala yesterday for a talk with Chief Philip-Returns-From-Scout, who heads a group of Sioux in John Krimsky's World's Fair and Wild West Rodeo. The chief, a wrinkled old chap who toured Europe-- years ago--with Buffalo Bill and

BERLIN, June 21.--A two-day conference at Friedrichshafen between the heads of the German and Italian navies ended today with "complete agreement on all issues," according to a communique. The German delegation was headed by Grand Admiral Erich Raeder and the Italian by Admiral Domenico Cavagnari, Under Secretary of the Navy.

A class of 116 students of the preapprentice course of the New York School of Printing received certificates of the State Department of Education last night at graduation exercises in the auditorium of the Textile High School, 351 West Eighteenth Street.

DENVER, Col., June 21.--Peace within the ranks of labor "within a few months" was predicted today by Secretary Perkins on the basis of "confidential" knowledge, which she said she had concerning the recent negotiations between the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the American Federation of Labor.
A number of large apartments in buildings in Park and Fifth Avenues were involved in the new residential tenancies reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 21.--The twenty-four Democratic members of the House of Representatives from New York State were summoned today to meet at 11 A.M. tomorrow for a discussion of the Bloom neutrality resolution, which probably will come before the House next Monday. The call was issued by Representative Gavagan, whip for the delegation.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 21. --Because he was beaten by Don McNeill in the French hard-courts championship final, Bobby Riggs of Chicago today had to take a back seat to England's Henry Wilfred (Bunny) Austin in the seedings for the All-England tennis championships which start Monday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 21.-- Harvard batted itself into a tie with Cornell for the championship of the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League today when it cracked out eleven hits in slightly more than six innings against Joe Wood Jr., son of the Yale coach, and routed the Elis, 8 to 1.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's office began an investigation yesterday into the finances of the American Federation of Actors. Robert H. Thayer, assistant district attorney in charge of the indictment bureau, subpoenaed the accountant's report in the investigation of the union by its A.F. of L.

SWATOW, China, Thursday, June 22.--The Japanese Naval Commander, following occupation of this Chinese port, today ordered all foreign warships, including the United States destroyer Pillsbury and the British destroyer Thanet, to leave the harbor by 1 P.M.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 21.-- Joseph Franklin Cannon, retired manufacturer, of Concord, N.C., and a leader in the Southern textile industry, died of a stroke today in a hotel at Hot Springs, Ark. Born in Concord on July 23, 1876, he was the oldest of the sons of the late J.W. Cannon and worked with his father in the early days of the Cannon textile empire.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., June 21 (AP)--Slowly and without emotion, the cook of the sunken submarine Squalus told a naval court today that he saw a solid sheet of sea water pouring from the main engine room ventilating duct as the undersea boat carried twenty-six of her crew to their deaths on the ocean bottom on May 23.

WASHINGTON, June 21.--Suspension of activities in connection with all new WPA public building projects has been ordered by Colonel F.C. Harrington, WPA administrator, pending final determination by Congress of the limitation on cost put into the $1,735,600,000 relief bill. The measure is now under consideration by a Senate subcommittee.

Raymond V. Ingersoll, Borough President of Brooklyn, praised yesterday the general plan for a coordinated network of new and existing express highways and parkways in the city as proposed by the City Planning Commission for its master plan of the city, but he questioned the feasibility of many express highways because of the high cost of adequate underpasses to take care of cross traffic.

BERLIN, June 21.--The official foreign-trade figures for Greater Germany, excepting the Protectorate of Bohemia-Moravia, for May are as follows: exports, 485,400,000 marks; imports, 439,600,000 marks; export surplus, 45,800,000 marks.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, June 22. --Admiral Harry E. Yarnell, Commander in Chief of the United States Asiatic Fleet, was said by reliable sources today to have rejected flatly Japanese demands that the United States destroyer Pillsbury and American citizens leave Swatow.
Graduates of Hunter College were advised yesterday, at the seventysixth annual commencement exercises in Carnegie Hall, to go out and organise actively to keep the nation out of war.

The mixing of small cargo shipments to form carload lots for ratemaking purposes constitutes a serious threat to wholesale cncerns, it was testified yesterday at the third day of a Maritime Commission

TRENTON, June 21.--With complete unofficial returns from yesterday's referendum showing a plurality of 156,99 votes for the parimutuel betting amendment, attention turned today to the problems the Legislature will face in effectuating the mandate of the voters.

The fast-growing Inwood section of Manhattan will add to its housing facilities as the result of the sale yesterday of a plot opposite Baker Field. The Harlem Savings Bank sold to Flapan Flapan a plot 52 by 117 feet on the south
Mr. and Mrs. A.J. Drexel Biddle of Philadelphia are at the Drake.

With all allowance for the rarity of the sight, that full-rigged Norwegian training ship just over here from Oslo and pictured in yesterday's TIMES, must be reckoned high in the gallery of New York beauties.

More than thirty hunting and fishing clubs from Westchester County, representing between 7,000 and 8,000 sportsmen, met last Tuesday night under the auspices of the Southern New York Fish and Game Association to form a county sportsmen's council.

WASHINGTON, June 21.--Japan was asked to respect the rights of Americans and their interests at Tientsin and to safeguard their welfare in representations made to the Japanese Consul General there by John K. Caldwell, the United States Consul General today.
BATON ROUGE, La., June 21.-- Governor Richard W. Leche announced tonight that, because of ill health, he would resign his office "before the end of next week."

HARRISBURG, Pa., June 21.-- Former Governor George H. Earle declared in court today that he did not approve a transfer of funds spent in connection with the alleged $1,000,000 payroll fraud in the State Highway Department in Luzerne County prior to the election last November.

HARRISON, N.Y., June 21.-- Roderick Gedney Horton of this village, assistant vice president of the Empire City Savings Bank of New York and manager of the branch at 2 Park Avenue, died yesterday in St. Agnes Hospital, White Plains, after an eight months' illness. He was 58 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 21.--House Republicans caught the Democrats unawares today and tentatively struck from the supplemental Army Aircraft Appropriation Bill funds for 1,243 planes, leaving the expansion program far short of President Roosevelt's goal of 5,500 planes by 1941.
Buoyancy of United States Government obligations and local traction issues stood out as features in the bond market yesterday in somewhat more active trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, June 21.--A Senate filibuster organized by the inflation-silver group threatened today to block three major bills on which Congress must act before midnight, June 30, or disrupt the government routine.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., June 21.-- Miss Kathryn Murtagh Anderson and Frank Billings Nichols had twenty attendants at their marriage here this afternoon, which was performed in St. Thomas Church by the Rev. William J. Drake.

Early days on lower Fifth Avenue, before it was an avenue at all, are recalled by the announcement of plans for a tall, new apartment house at the southwest corner of this thoroughfare and Ninth Street.

Ralph Pulitzer, former publisher of The New York World and eldest son of the late Joseph Pulitzer, left his residuary estate in trust to his widow, Mrs. Margaret Leech Pulitzer of 450 East Fifty-second Street, it was revealed yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogates' Court.

GREENVILLE, S.C., June 21. --J.E. Sirrine of Greenville, chairman of a committee on voluntary production control in the Southern print-cloth field, announced today that operators of more than 95 per cent of the Zooms on these fabrics had entered into an agreement to improve market conditions through a three-month reduction program.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., June 21.--Strong contenders for the last two years, the Williams sailors assumed the lead in the second session of the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association championships today.
The new city budget is a little smaller than the preceding one. The real estate tax rate, as fixed by the Council on Tuesday, is a little higher because valuations are a little lower.

ONE always comes to the reading of a novel by Thomas Wolfe with an invigorating feeling that one is about to grapple with the elements. One knows that there will be tornadoes of words in subtle and often dazzling variety, roaring cascades of scenes and ideas, earthquakes of strong emotion and fiery streams of inexhaustible cataloguing and thunderous megalomania.
LONDON, June 21.--Britain will welcome home King George and queen Elizabeth tomorrow from a journey that henceforth will hold a distinctive place in the annals of the Crown.
Store rentals for new units of chain-store organizations in various sections in the Metropolitan district were prominent among the leasing transactions reported yesterday.
CHICAGO, June 21 (AP).--The Cubs and the Bees had to suspend play at the end of eight and one-third innings on account of rain today, with Chicago ahead, 3 to 0, for its fourth straight triumph.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 21.-- Joining with thousands of other graduates in the general merriment of Harvard's picturesque annual Class Day today, President James B. Conant made a speech in which he defined State Governors as "judges holding a stop watch on the race between bankruptcy and taxation; or referees in the wrestling bout between a rugged individual and his social conscience; or umpires calling strikes on our favorite batters."

BUFFALO, June 21,--Mayor La Guardia flew to Buffalo today from New York to address a special general session of the National Conference of Social Work, before proceeding tonight to Washington to appear tomorrow before the Senate committee on appropriations on behalf of the WPA.

BOSTON, June 21.--Mrs. Eleanor Harriet Beebe, widow of Junius Beebe, Boston banker and merchant, and mother of Lucius Beebe, New York columnist, died here today at her home in the Back Bay. She celebrated her seventy-fourth birthday last Sunday.

Major Gen. John J. Phelan, chairman of the State Athletic Commission, today will watch the workout of Joe Louis, world heavyweight champion, as the Detroit Bomber goes through his paces at Pompton Lakes, N.J. This will be the first of Joe's last three hard drills before his title match next Wednesday night at the Yankee Stadium against the globular Tony Galento of Orange.

MILWAUKEE, June 21.--An explanation of the manner by which sulfanilamide produces its mysterious effectiveness against so many wholly diverse species of germs, in diseases as different as pneumonia and gonorrhea, was presented here today before the Summer meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

WASHINGTON, June 21.--Senator Wheeler of Montana, chairman of the Committee on Interstate Commerce, protested to the Civil Aeronautics Authority today against the proposed merger of Western Air Express and United Air Lines.

An almost forgotten Serbian patriot and statesman died on Wednesday during a political meeting in Ochrida, on the shores of a lake in South Serbia where the frontiers of Greece, Albania and Yugoslavia meet.

WASHINGTON, June 21.--The National Labor Relations Board announced today that it had amended its rules to permit employers to petition the board for an election to determine which of two or more rival labor organizations should be certified as representing a majority of employes for collective bargaining purposes in cases where no labor union had petitioned the board for such certification.

Emphasis on the statement that the public interest is paramount, dominated the code of ethics and business conduct of the Association of Customers' Brokers, released yesterday. It is believed to be the first code of its kind adopted by any group of employes of New York Stock Exchange firms.
The promotion of eighty-three members of the faculty and library service at New York University, effective in September, was announced yesterday by Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase.

SHELTER ISLAND, L.I., June 21.--A calm today was added to the assortment of weather that has prevailed on the American Yacht Club cruise when the joint regatta with the Shelter Island Yacht Club was to be sailed out in Gardiners Bay.

Mrs. Louise Slagle Todd of 16 East Ninety-eighth Street and Sewickley, Pa., and Frederic A. de Peyster of 149 East Seventy-third Street obtained a marriage license yesterday at the Municipal Building and will be wed on Monday at Mrs. Todd's home here. Only relatives will be ...

Samuel Greenberg, treasurer and a director of Louis Greenberg Bro., Inc., 520 Eighth Avenue, manufacturers of children's coats, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at his home, 5 Riverside Drive. Mr. Greenberg was vice president of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers and a member of its board of governors. His age was 64.

Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew signed yesterday a final order restraining the Board of Education from dismissing 934 kindergarten teachers and 178 kindergarten extension teachers in any revision of its budget occasioned by the $8,300,000 reduction in funds available to the school system for the next fiscal year.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 21.-- Luigi Costa, retired steamship agent and banker, who was decorated by King Victor Emmanuel and Premier Mussolini of Italy for distinguished service during the World War, died today at his home here. He was born in Palermo, Italy, sixty-six years ago.

Lou Gehrig, the robust Iron Horse whose baseball endurance record of 2,130 consecutive games may never be broken, is suffering from a mild attack of infantile paralysis, it was disclosed yesterday upon the return of the Yankee captain from a weeklong examination at the Mayo Clinic.

In a comprehensive examination of the consumer movement yesterday, members of the Advertising Federation of America learned that it was composed of several groups of diverse intelligence, motives and politics and that the advertising fraternity should cooperate wholeheartedly with those segments sincerely interested in improving the selling, labeling and advertising of goods in this country.

MOSCOW, June 21.--Soviet Russian quarters tonight declared that a two-hour conversation on a proposed British-French-Russian mutual assistance pact had failed to produce any progress in the longdrawn negotiations.

An old rabbit warren of a building in the "Bloody Angle" of Doyers Street, at 15-17, burned early yesterday morning with the loss of seven lives and injuries to Sixteen persons, including eight firemen. An investigation to fix responsibility and possibly to bring criminal charges was begun by Assistant District Attorney Jacob J. Rosenblum.
WOODMERE, L.L., June 21.-- Miss Norma Taubele of New York gained the semi-finals of the women's New York State tennis championships at the Woodmere Club today, a round ahead of the field.

Emphasizing the contributions already made to American life by sports and athletics, Postmaster General James A. Farley told a gathering of more than 1,000 persons at flag-raising ceremonies of the New York Athletic Club at the World's Fair yesterday afternoon that proper physical training for the youth of the country was one of the best guarantees of national defense.

New Hampshire day was celebrated yesterday at the World's Fair with the dedication by Governor Francis P. Murphy of the New Hampshire State Exhibit and with a costume pageant re-enacting that historic moment, 151 years ago almost to the hour, when New Hampshire became the ninth State to ratify the United States Constitution, and thus made it binding upon the whole nation.

Lefty Gomez, who would rather be lucky than good, was very lucky indeed yesterday. When he stepped on the Yankee Stadium pitching mound he had a pleasant smile, a ready quip and practically nothing on the ball. And so it was that he had yielded ten hits and six runs by the time he was waved to the showers in the fifth, and the White Sox led the Yankees, 6 to 0.

WASHINGTON, June 21.--Senators Guffey of Pennsylvania, Smathers of New Jersey and Hughes of Delaware declared today for the nomination of President Roosevelt. Mr. Guffey and Mr. Smathers said that the delegations from their States would cast their votes for the President at the Democratic National Convention next year.

RICHMOND, Va., June 21.--Miss Ann Nevin Beverley, who made her debut here the Winter of 1936, was married here tonight in Grace Covenant Presbyterian Church to Ezra Frantz Hershey Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hershey of Hershey, Pa. The

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP).--In a game which featured most everything except baseball, the Indians today nosed out the Senators, 9 to 8.

PRAGUE, June 21.--Baron Constantin von Neurath, Reich Protector for Bohemia and Moravia, tonight issued a twelve-point decree to establish a Jewish law in the protectorate, define a Jew and "Aryanize" Jewish industry.

WASHINGTON, June 21.--Sharp criticism of founders of investment trusts who have sold control of their companies to outsiders without informing their investors of the transfer of control is voiced by the Securities and Exchange Commission in another section of its study of investment trusts which was submitted today to Congress.

The 3,600 or more police hopefuls who passed their written examinations for the new patrolman's list will start taking their physical examinations July 5 before a blue ribbon jury of college coaches, Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, announced yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, June 21.--Speaking at the commencement exercises of John Marshall College here this afternoon, Attorney General Frank Murphy pointed approvingly to the Supreme Court's recent decision against Mayor Frank Hague on the free-speech issue in the course of an ardent defense of civil liberties as the bulwark of democracy.

A total of $600,000 was raised by the National Labor Committee for Palestine since the beginning of this year, it was reported last night at a meeting of the committee in the Hotel Astor, attended by more than 1,000 delegates and guests. The committee represents Jewish labor and fraternal organizations in the United States, with a membership of 500,000.

CHICAGO. June 21.--Heavy liquidation of long positions and stoploss selling, combined with early hedge sales, found the demand for wheat inadequate in late trading today on the Board of Trade and prices declined sharply for all deliveries.

Tentative awards totaling $l,594,437 were made yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin for land at Corlears Hook taken by condemnation for Federal and city low-cost housing projects. The awards are $170,563 less than the assessed valuation of the property.

BERKELEYY, Calif., June 21 (AP). --Pacific Coast track and field athletes demonstrated their superiority over Big Ten rivals late today by winning a 941-3-to-36 2-3 victory from the Middle Western stars in the third annual dual meet between picked teams of the two big Conferences.

ST. LOUIS, June 21(AP).--The work horse of the Cardinals, Curt Davis, made his twenty-first appearance of the season on the mound today and participated in eighteen-hit attack that netted a 14-to-2 victory over the Phillies.

CINCINNATI, June 21.--John Whitlow Wyatt, Dolf Camilli and Tuck Stainback wrote a new page in the history of baseball under lights tonight when their combined efforts gave the Dodgers a 2-1 triumph over Johnny (Double No-Hit) Vander Meer and the league-leading Reds.

PARIS, June 21.--In the midst of the receptions and other marks of cordiality and consideration extended to them by the French Government, press and aviation officials during their four-day stay in France, the eighteen American journalists who flew to Europe on board the Atlantic Clipper were received today by the Duke and Duchess of Vindsor at their Paris home.

The marriage of Miss Valentine Denhan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sergei J. Denhan of 1,200 Fifth Avenue and Roxbury, Conn., to Robert Bruce Wilson took place yesterday afternoon in the Chapel of St. James of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Bishop William T. Manning performed the ceremony.

VATICAN CITY, June 21.--With the arrival here of Mgr. Filippo Cortesi, Papal Muncio to Warsaw, the Vatican is now in possession of the replies of all five governments approached by Pope Pius XII with a view to bringing about peaceful solution of European problems, it was learned today.

LONDON, June 21 (AP).--Franjo Kukuljevic of Yugoslavia eliminated the Wimbledon favorite, veteran Henry Wilfred (Bunny) Austin, in the third round of the London grass courts tennis championships at the Queens Club today, 6--4, 6--4.

An annual pension amounting to $9,964,98 was approved for Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, by members of the board of the Teachers Retirement Fund, meeting yesterday for the last time until Fall in the Municipal Building. Dr. Robinson's retirement from his post as president will become effective on July 1.

TIENTSIN, China, Thursday, June 22 (AP).--Britain's Tientsin garrison was reinforced and the inflow of food was increased today as the Japanese Army took stronger measures to enforce its blockade of the British and French Concessions.
