PARIS, June 23 (AP).--Tragedy marred the Duke of Windsor's birthday party tonight when a man unofficially identified as Bedrich Benes, military attache of the Czecho-Slovak Legation in Paris, plunged 186 feet from the first platform of the Eiffel Tower, where the Duke and Duchess were celebrating.
Bill Holmes of Yonkers was clocked at 9:33.42 in beating a strong field in the feature thirtyfive-lap midget automobile racing event at the Castle Hill Speedway in the Bronx last night.

The sun was shining brightly at 3:15 P.M. yesterday when Myril Hoag of the Browns should have stepped up to the plate at the Yankee Stadium for a swing at one of Red Ruffing's pitches. In fact, the sun was positively beaming but several thousand fans were not, because the Yankees had called off the game.

CLEVELAND, June 23.--Sales of electric vacuum cleaners in May numbered 114,377, as compared with 99,542 units a year before, according to figures issued today by C.G. Frantz, executive secretary of the Vacuum Cleaner Manufacturers ...

BERNE, Switzerland, June 23 (AP).--Swiss authorities tonight said German officials had repudiated in writing attacks against Switzerland made in the Schwarzekorps, official organ of the Nazi Blackshirts. Nazi officials were said to have sent assurance "it would not happen again." Switzerland recently protested against attacks in the official organ of the German Storm Troops.

LENOX, Mass., June 23.--Miss Helen Louise Dannreuther of New York and Edward Livingston Coster of Katonah, N.Y., who will be married tomorrow afternoon in Trinity Church, Lenox, were honored at a dinner given tonight by Miss Dannreuther's uncle and aunt, ...

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP).-- President Roosevelt signed today legislation establishing a permanent minimum cotton acreage under the Farm Act at about 26,000,-- 000 acres, or not less than 10,000,000 bales.

Albert Francis Free, president of F.R. Triples Co., who sails today on the S.S. Britannic for England and Scotland, said yesterday that there has been a very decided upturn in the business since May 1 with the opening of the Fair. All departments are substantially ahead of last year, he added.

WASHINGTON, June 23.--Testimony aiming to contradict charges made by the American Federation of Labor against the National Labor Relations Board was put in the record of the Senate Committee on Education and Labor today by ...

WASHINGTON, June 23.--Department store sales during the week ended June 17 rose 6 per cent above the corresponding week last year and for the four-week period ended June 17 were 8 per cent more than for the like period a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
A Lutheran "Fouth Rally" will be held in the Transportation Area of the World's Fair tomorrow at 3:45 P.M.

CAMP TAMIMENT, Pa., June 23. --Speaking before the Tamiment Economic and Social Institute today, Dr. Leon M. Birkhead, national director of The Friends of Democracy, an organization formed recently to fight fascism and communism, assailed Tom Mooney as a Communist propagandist and a "disappointment" to the labor movement.

OTTAWA, Ont., June 23 (Canadian Press)--Baron Robert Silvercruys, Belgian Minister to Canada, and three other persons were injured today when the Minister's car crashed into a machine driven by Felix Bachanskas of Philadelphia on the Montreal road five miles east of here. Francois Vandenbosch, the Minister's chauffeur, and the Baron did not require hospital treatment, but Mr. and Mrs. Bachanskas were taken to a hospital with bruises and scalp wounds.

SUMMIT, N.J., June 23.--May be it was the heat. Or it may have been a sign of perfect fighting condition. But, whatever the reason, Two-Ton Tony Galento was in an irritable mood today as he went through four rounds of sparring.

MOUNTAIN LAKES, N.J., June 23 (AP).--Mace Gwyer of Pelham Manor, N.Y., unseeded, provided a first-round upset in the seventh annual Mountain Lakes Club invitation tennis tournament today by eliminating Jack Totten of Paterson, ranked fourth, 1--6, 6--4, 6--4.
ALBANY, June 23.--Governor Lehman's message to the special session of the Legislature was in the hands of the press and the legislators for hours before it was officially read in both houses tonight.

The World's Fair was described yesterday by Alfredo Santiago, publisher of El Heraldo Comercial of Havana and delegate of the Cuban Secretary of Agriculture, as a real picture of the world of tomorrow, free from propaganda, and as the best medium for promoting goodwill and trade between the United States and the participating nations.

WASHINGTON, June 23.--Industrial production, which receded on a seasonally adjusted basis in the first four months of this year, showed little change in May but increased considerably in the first three weeks of June, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System reported today.

TALLINN, Estonia, June 23.--The Estonian Victory Day, commemorating the republic's liberation from Russian domination, was celebrated today. Torch bearers were sent to all parts of the country with President Konstantin Paets's patriotic appeal.

The recent reconciliation of Robert Babian, 40 years old, proprietor of a tailor shop, and his wife, Rita, 31, ended in tragedy at 6:30 o'clock last night in their newly established home on the second floor of 615 West 189th Street. After a violent quarrel Babian got out a repeating rifle, wounded his wife critically, shot and killed his mother-in-law and then ended his own life.

A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Caldecot Chubb of 324 East Forty-first Street yesterday at the Leroy Sanatarium. Mrs. Chubb is the former Miss Edith Onions, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H.G.L. Onions of Somerset, Bermuda. The child will be named Russell Parsons.

SCRANTON, Pa., June 23 (AP).-- Disregarding a strong wind that affected Byron Nelson, national open champion, and most of the other contenders, Henry Picard of Hershey, Pa., took the first-round lead in the 72-hole $5,000 anthracite open golf tourney today with a record 65, five under par.

Former King Zog and Queen Geraldine, exiles since the Italian invasion of Albania, plan to vist the United States within two months, according to Baroness Suzanne de Strasser of Budapest, a friend of the royal exiles.

WASHINGTON, June 23.--The Civil Aeronautics Authority took action today to confine the services of Transcontinental and Western Air to the routes and stops which it was serving when the Civil Aeronautics Authority Act became effective. Both mail and passenger services of the line are affected by the decision.

The traditional Finnish folk festival, in which more than 200 FinnishAmericans participated, was held last night at the Randalls Island tSadium, where athletic events, folk dances and a beauty contest were the highlights. Park Commissioner Robert Moses welcomed the group to the island.

CHICAGO, June 23 (AP).--Shirley Olympius, a former business representative of King Features Syndicate and for many years an advertising representative for several Hearst newspapers, died in a hospital yesterday after a six months' illness. His age was 57.

An optimistic message from the Broadway Association to its members, some of whom have been complaining that the World's Fair has been ruining their business, was issued yesterday by H. Frederick Bright, managing director, who announced that, with a new influx of visitors, "the long-awaited good times" are now at hand.

Marjorie Hillis, who not so long ago in "Live Alone and Like It" told women how to be happy though single, is about to succumb to matrimony. Her engagement to Thomas Henry Roulston, president of the grocery store chain bearing his name, has been announced by her parents. The couple will be married in August.
MONTREAL, June 23 (Canadian Press).--The Scottish All-Star soccer team, unbeaten on its Canadian-American tour, sailed for Liverpool today aboard the liner Duchess of Atholl.

The Maritime Commission's investigation of rate schedules and conference practices in the intercoastal trade turned yesterday to the question of steamship rates for brandy and champagne cargoes. It was the second hearing on this topic, the first having been held in San Francisco late in May.

A group program, providing for more than 400 employes about $700,000 of life insurance, was one of the features marking the eightieth anniversary of the Rumford Chemical Works, Rumford, R.I., celebrated on June 23, according to the announcement of A.E. Marshall, president.

WINNIPEG, June 23 (Canadian Press).--Johnny Longden of Tabor, Alberta, leading jockey on North American tracks last year, rode three winners at Polo Park today and was second with his only other mount. Longden, suspended for ten days for rough riding at Aqueduct on June 12, rode for the first time since then. He will go to Chicago to ride at Arlington Park Monday.

ST. LOUIS, June 23 (AP).--George Sister Jr., son of the Browns' famous first baseman, signed a contract today with Youngstown, Ohio, of the Middle Atlantic League, a farm club of his father's old team. Sister, 21, was graduated last week from Colgate, where he had pitched on the team for three years. A brother, Dick, an outfielder, is with Washington of the Pennsylvania State League.
MONTREAL, June 23.--Following receipt by Mayor Camillien Houde of Montreal of a letter from the Bank of Montreal, La Banque Canadienne Nationale and the Royal Bank of Canada that they would ...
A schedule of recommended retail prices for cigarettes, to begin July 1, when the 2-cent State tax becomes effective, was issued yesterday by the New York Retail Tobacco Council.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 23.--The first dinner dance of the season at the Devon Yacht Club will be held tomorrow. Among those who will entertain there are Mr. and Mrs. Ivor B. Clark and Miss Elizabeth Jean Clark; Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Aquin Kelly, Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Reid, Mr. and Mrs. Dickson B. Potter and Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Bronaugh.
The tax rate for Jersey City for the present year, as announced yesterday by the Hudson County Board of Taxation, shows an increase of 84 cents per thousand valuation over 1938.

WINDSOR, Ont., June 23 (Canadian Press).--Bob Madden of Detroit, defeated Martin Buxby of Miami, Fla., 6--1, 7--5, 6--4, on the clay courts of the Windsor Tennis Club today to enter the men's singles final against Morey Lewis of Texarkana, Texas, in the Canadian championships.

BERLIN, June 23.--United States Admiral Harry E. Yarnell's defiance of Japanese orders to withdraw American warships from Swatow was passed over rather slightly in the German press in favor of continued and gleeful accounts of the alleged humiliation of the British Empire at the hands of the Japanese and the Russians.

Orders to wholesalers indicated this week that most merchants were preparing for an increase over 1938 in Fall sales, according to the weekly summary issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Forward buying of Fall items continued to gain, with house business and road orders reported equally satisfactory.
The demand for new money being limited to replacements, quotations for all types of loans were carried forward without change.
LOS ANGELES, June 23 (AP).-- Fight promoter Joe Levy said today he had wired Joe Louis a guarantee of $100,000 to meet Maxie Rosenbloom for the heavyweight title here in September.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 23.-- The Wollensak Optical Company will take over the old Hootz clothing factory, officials announced this afternoon.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, June 23.--The German Justice Commissioner, Dr. Hans Frank, today received an honorary degree from Sofia University. It had been conferred last month during the university's jubilee fete, but Dr. Frank was unable to come to Sofia then.

A brisk rise in New York City transit issues featured trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Definite progress in unification proceedings involving the Interborough Rapid Transit lines, as announced in the day, was the signal for the fresh advance in all the local traction loans.

DANZIG, June 23.--Nazi sources said today that British ships and one American merchantman, the Mormacport, have unloaded munitions cargoes at the Polish port of Gdynia. Included among the cargoes were said to be such war essentials as copper and zinc.

Jack Pearl, the comedian and one of the leading performers in "Yokel Boy," now trying out in Boston, is leaving the cast after this evening's performance. Mr. Pearl, it is reported, was not content with his...
WASHINGTON, June 23.--Herbert E. Gaston, who was a news editor on the old New York World, was sworn in today by Secretary Morgenthau as Assistant Secretary of the Treasury.

WASHINGTON, June 23.--Supply contracts valued at $3,428,348 were awarded during the week ended June 27 by twelve Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contract Act, the Labor Department announced today.

At a special meeting of the Federal Screw Works held yesterday to ratify certain changes in the articles of incorporation in line with terms of the recapitalization plan now being worked out under the Chandler act, stockholders voted to change each five shares of ...

LONDON, June 23.--King George today gave a personal report of his transatlantic tour in a speech to a brilliant welcoming assembly at London's Guildhall and to uncounted thousands of his people who listened in by radio.
PARIS, June 23.--After many weeks of negotiations, the FrenchTurkish treaty, handing back the Hatay Republic to Turkey, and a...

LIVERPOOL, England, June 23 (AP).--Walther Reinhardt, German Consul General at Liverpool, who was recalled Wednesday at the British Government's request, left for Berlin today by way of London. [In recalling Herr Reinhardt, whom Britain accused of having connection with an espionage case, Germany retaliated by asking that the British Consul General at Vienna, Donald St. Clair Gainer, be recalled.]
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 23.-- Walter Hampden has signed with RKO to play the archbishop in the forthcoming remake of "The Hunchback of Notre Dame" with Charles Laughton, the studio announced today.

STRATFORD, Conn., June 23.-- Alex Kerr of Beverly Hills, Calif., shot a perfect 100 to win the World's Fair Special, preliminary event of the eleventh annual Great Eastern skeet shoot that started here today.

The National Federation of Press Women's awards to radio stations and advertisers for meritorious programs will be announced Monday at a dinner of the organization at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Stations WEAF, WOR and WABC will broadcast the proceedings beginning at 10:30 o'clock.

DAYTON, Ohio, June 23.--A reduction of about 20 per cent in the price of the Frigidaire portable, self-contained RSA air-conditioning unit was announced today by H.F. Lehman, manager of commercial and air-conditioning sales of the Frigidaire division of General Motors Sales Corporation. The cut brings the suggested installed price, less wiring and freight, to $319.50.

LONDON, June 23.--The Far Eastern situation and the royal visit to the City reduced trading almost to a standstill in the stock markets today. Only a little selling sufficed to cause weakness, but, as yesterday, a better tone later developed and early losses in gilt-edge ...

LONDON, June 23.--While British resentment was mounting as the result of the latest incidents at Tientsin, Viscount Halifax, the Foreign Secretary, summoned Mamoru Shigemitsu, the Japanese Ambassador, to the Foreign Office to complain in no uncertain terms about what Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain earlier in the day had called "intolerable insults."

With defending champions in thirteen of the twenty-one events, the metropolitan A.A.U. track and field championships will take place at Lincoln Park in Jersey City this afternoon, starting at 1:30. Admission will be free and a crowd of 10,000 is expected.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 23.--More than five thousand social workers in public and private service were urged at a general session of the National Conference of Social Work tonight to go into politics to protect their operations from retrenchment.

BOSTON, June 23 (AP).--The Boston Globe says Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd informed it today that he would proceed with plans for a third voyage to the Antarctic Continent to map out, survey and claim territory definitely for the United States, even if Congress should reject plans for a government-supported expedition.

ACCRA, Gold Coast, West Africa, June 23.--Sixty-six people were reported killed and many others injured in violent earthquake shocks here and in other towns on the seaboard of the Gold Coast late last night and early today. No Europeans were among the casualties.

A closer cooperation between the United States and Canada to preserve the existing democracies and to resist any form of aggression by totalitarian States was stressed yesterday in brief addresses by the newly elected and retiring presidents of the International Kiwanis Clubs at the World's Fair.

About seventy-five women, representing nearly every South American country, gathered yesterday in the National Advisory Committee's Building at the World's Fair at a reception given by the Union of American Women in honor of "Women of the Americas Day" at the Fair.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP).-- The Tigers landed on Dutch Leonard with a big seventh-inning rally today to defeat the Senators, 7 to 4.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., June 23.-- For the second year in succession, Miss Charlotte Glutting of Rock Spring and Miss Alice Rutherfurd of Baltusrol teamed perfectly to win the Women's New Jersey Golf Association's two-ball best-ball tournament as they added a one...

SALZBURG, Germany, June 23 (AP).--Chancellor Adolf Hitler, who is having a fast four-motored plane built for him, soon will have his own airport, which is to be constructed one hour from his Berchtesgaden country home.
TOKYO, June 23.--Four reactionaries last night filed a petition praying Emperor Hirohito "to assert Japan's belligerent rights in the China affair."

Charges that the Welfare Department had failed to provide relief to World War veterans who qualified for it were made yesterday before the City Council committee investigating relief at a public hearing in City Hall.

Mrs. Lillian I. Schrein, testifying yesterday in her own behalf in General Sessions, repudiated a confession she had previously made admitting the theft of upward of $150,000 from Martin Beck, theatrical producer. She signed the document, she swore, to assist Mr. Beck, her employer and uncle by marriage, in winning a suit against the National City Bank.
RICHMOND, Va., June 23.-- Thomas Overton Moss, Richmond attorney, died today of a heart attack in his office. He was 45 years old.
Several hundred students, faculty members and alumni of the University of Iowa celebrated Iowa University Day at the World's Fair yesterday afternoon and last night.
PITTSBURGH, June 23.--The winners of ten $3,000 "work learn" George Westinghouse scholarships at the Carnegie Institute of Technology were announced today.

Twenty Federal Government and airline observers, including Stephen Early, White House secretary, and Major Gen. Delos C. Emmons, commander of the General Headquarters Air Force, will be aboard the Yankee Clipper today when Pan American Airway's opens ...

MOSCOW, June 23 (AP).--Vsevolod Meyerhold, for years one of the greatest names in the Soviet Russian theatre world and internationally famous for his stage technique, is under arrest, it was learned reliably tonight.
The Manufacturers Trust Company sold the six-story loft building with stores at 7-11 New Chambers Street and 251-53 William Street to I.A. Supervision, Inc., L.B. Carter, president.

The Rev. Dr. J. Hamilton Dawson has accepted a call from the Board of American Missions of the United Lutheran Church to take charge of the Lutheran Church of the Advent, Broadway and Ninetythird Street. He comes from Des Moines, Iowa, where for the last fourteen years he has been pastor of the Unity Lutheran Church, which he founded.

Legal action to disbar Louis S. Levy, head of the law firm of Stanchfield Levy, and Paul M. Hahn, vice president of the American Tobacco Company, from practice in the Federal courts was begun yesterday by United States Attorney John T. Cahill.
A charge of disorderly conduct against Cliff Wilson of the Hotel Paramount, Manhattan, owner of an animal exhibit at the World's Fair, who had been accused of...

OTTAWA, June 23 (Canadian Press).--The act to assist in the cooperative marketing of farm products other than wheat came into force today by proclamation. J.G. Gardiner, Minister of Agriculture, announced that the measure, passed at the recent session of Parliament, has been proclaimed.
PHILADELPHIA, June 23 (AP).-- One big inning, the seventh, gave the Indians a 12-to-5 triumph over the Athletics today and Bob Feller his eleventh victory of the season.
WARSAW, Poland, June 23.-- Danzig is to have a "Free Corps," a substitute for a regular army which the Free City is not allowed to have under the Treaty of Versailies.

A complaint accusing the Busch Jewelry Company and two affiliated companies of fostering a company union and of discouraging membership in Local 830 of the United Retail and Wholesale Employes of America, a C.I.O. organization, was issued yesterday by the State Labor Relations Board.

An important victory in the fight to eliminate a racket that has cost the government $1,000,000 annually was claimed by United States Attorney John T. Cahill yesterday when two men and an importing firm pleaded guilty to an indictment that had been pending for two years.

Adoption of the conference committee's report on the Agricultural Appropriation Bill by the House of Representatives in Washington brought yesterday another sharp advance in the price of cotton, and contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 12 to 15 points to ...
Marvin Greenwood, assistant general sales manager of the Celotex Corporation, Chicago, for the last year, has been appointed general sales manager, Henry W. Collins, vice president in charge of ...
LONDON, June 23.--Following is the text of King George's speech at the Guildhall today:
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 23 (AP).--Twenty-four miners were killed and twenty were injured today in the 500-foot fall of an elevator cage in a shaft of the Randfontein estates gold mine.

Seven members of the senior class of the School of Commerce of the University of Chile were guests of honor yesterday at a luncheon given by the Chilean Committee of the Pan American Society at India House, 1 Hanover Square.

Mrs. Carl Madison Worsham of Dallas, Texas, has announced to friends here the engagement of her daughter, Miss Carla Worsham, to Charles A. Bane of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Weller Bane of Springfield, Ill.

TRENTON, June 23.--Highway appropriations totaling $35,228,660 out of an estimated $39,281,490 available for the operation of the New Jersey Highway Department this year were approved by Governor Moore today when he signed the McClave bill.

Scores of children attending the forty-one elementary public schools on Staten Island were felled by ptomaine poisoning yesterday and last night, over 200 of them being treated at Staten Island hospitals and an undetermined number of others in their homes. No case was considered serious.
LONDON, June 23.--The Lancashire textile industry is about to begin a drive to improve its exports to the United States.

HONG KONG, June 23 (AP).--The British steamer Tsinan, escorted by the destroyer Scout, entered Japanese-occupied Swatow today as United States and British naval forces patrolled mission properties against possible disorder.
Just as President Roosevelt has an anonymous caller who threatens to balance the government's budget, and then backs down when he is asked ...

Net income of Canada Packers, Ltd., and subsidiaries for the year ended on March 31 amounted to $1,238,736 after charges, equal to $6.19 each on the 200,000 shares of capital stock, according to a report issued yesterday.
PORT JERVIS, N.Y., June 23.-- Establishment of classes in democracy and democratic ideals in the schools and colleges of the United States and Canada as a means of...

President Roosevelt's proposal for the extension of long and short term credits to foreign governments totaling $500,000,000 in the next two years, with $200,000,000 to be made available in the fiscal year 1939-40, was welcomed yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council here.
Britain's indignation over continuing incidents involving her nationals in the Japanese blockade of her concessions in Tientsin grew more intense yesterday.

WOODMERE, L.I., June 23.-- With play in the singles at a standstill, Miss Helen Germaine and Mrs. Tokuko Nakano reached the final sound of the doubles in the women's New York State championship today at the Woodmere Club. They defeated Miss Millicent Hirsh and Miss Florence LeBoutillier, 7--5, 6--4.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23.--Miss Joanna Wharton Biddle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Biddle of Springhead, Jenkintown, Pa., was married this noon to Lewis Johnson, son of Eads Johnson of Morristown, N.J., and of New Orleans. The ceremony was performed in the presence of relatives by the Rev. John W. Walker in the Huntingdon Valley (Pa.) Chapel.

To some casual observers there are certain aspects of the President's newest lending-spending plan that must seem like sheer magic. Here is a proposal to buy nearly four billion dollars' worth of new roads and homes and bridges and power lines and railway cars and other things.

WASHINGTON, June 23.--An omnibus enabling bill embodying the Congressional authority required to put President Roosevelt's new $3,680,000,000 lending program in force will be introduced in the Senate and House, probably next week, when it will be added to a list of "preferred" legislation which already threatens to hold Congress long after the adjournment goal of July 15.

Colonel William Hayward, organizer and World War commander of the old Fifteenth Infantry, a Negro regiment of the National Guard now known as the 369th, reviewed the regiment last night before 4,000 spectators at ceremonies in its armory, Fifth Avenue and 142d Street, observing its twenty-third anniversary.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 23.-- Harvard's class of '36, checking up on itself, discloses in its triennial report that the big thing in life is trying to get a job.
Mr. and Mrs. William Jay Schieffelin Jr. of 1,220 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Louise Schieffelin, to Cameron Bradley of Southboro, Mass.
ST. JOHNS, Nfld., June 23 (Canadian Press).--James Kent, Newfoundland Supreme Court Justice, died today at the age of 67.

WASHINGTON, June 23.--Proposed reductions in rail freight rates between the Harlem River, New York City, and Boston on the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad were suspended by the Interstate Commerce Commission today in view of a possible rate war with competitive motor carriers.

YORK HARBOR, Me., June 23.-- Billions of dollars are idle in this country because large investors, fearing "inevitable price inflation," are avoiding long-term commitments, Dr. Lewis H. Haney, economist, of New York University, told delegates to the quarterly meeting of the New England Council today.
CHICAGO, June 23 (AP).--Residents of western suburbs were awakened today when an estimated $50,000 stock of fireworks blew up in a retail sales depot in Leyden Township.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 23.-- The Harvard Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa voted "wet" at its annual meeting today.

DENVER, June 23.--The biennial convention of the American Association of University Women ended today with an appraisal of the week's sessions which showed the members more united than ever before in efforts to promote social welfare and raise the standards of education for women.

WASHINGTON, June 23.--The Maritime Commission called for bids today for the construction of three cargo vessels for the Seas Shipping Company, Inc., of New York, which operates the Robin Line between New York and South and East Africa.

The Tennessee Corporation announced yesterday that it had called its $3,500,000 of 6 per cent bonds due in 1944. Refinancing of the bonds has been arranged through bank loans and serial notes with interest rates varying from 2 to 4 per cent and maturing over a period of ten years.

SEA GIRT, N.J., June 23.--Lieutenant Frank J. Jury of Newark, a former Essex Troop officer, shooting under the colors of the 302d Cavalry, shot a perfect score of 100 today in the second day's events of the annual tournament of the Old Guard of New York at the State rifle range here. Lieutenant W.B. Bean of the Gate City Guard, Atlanta, was second with 98.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 23.-- Little Frankie Strafaci, protege of Whiffy Cox while he was at the Marine and Field Club in Brooklyn, continues on his winning ways.

WASHINGTON, June 23.--The first gesture of compromise in the Senate deadlock over silver which has created a stalemate on the monetary bill came late today when the Administration offered to the silver inflation group an agreement to peg the price of domestic silver at 64.64 cents an ounce for six months after June 30.

Those who plan to do any fishing in the neighborhood of the town of Indian Lake and Lake Pleasant in Hamilton County should obtain information on the new regulations affecting certain fish in this area.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., June 23.-- Miss Myra Stout Watson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Ewell Watson of Morristown, was married to Nathaniel Randolph Reyburn, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Randolph Reyburn of Fairfield, Conn., here this afternoon in the rectory of St. Margaret's Church by the Rev. John J. Sheerin, rector of the church.

A large play area in the Washington Heights section of Riverside Park and another in Inwood Hill Park were formally opened to the public yesterday. Park Commissioner Robert Moses presided at exercises at both sites, with Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs, ...

LONDON, June 23.--Creation of an American war reserve of rubber was begun today with the signing of an Anglo-American agreement exchanging about 85,000 tons of rubber from British Malaya for 600,000 bales of surplus cotton from the United States.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 23.-- The twenty-seventh annual convention of the National Council of Young Israel opened tonight at the Hotel Clarendon Brunswick here, with 300 delegates registered for the meeting. The final session will be held Monday evening in the Court of Peace at the World's Fair.

HAVANA, June 23.--Fifty-two Jewish refugees who have been held at the Tiscornia immigration station since their arrival May 15 on the Hamburg-American liner Iberia will be returned to Germany on the Orinoco of the same line, which is scheduled to sail from Havana July 4.
VATICAN CITY, June 23.--Pope Pius has decided to spend a much quieter Summer at Castel Gandolfo than was originally planned, it was announced today.

The number of prominent American families residing abroad this year has dropped to 477, as compared with 758 last year and 826 in 1937, according to figures shown in the Summer Social Register for 1839, now being distributed to subscribers.

Defendants in a $79,000,000 action against forty-three shareholders of the Climar Molybdenum Company declared yesterday that the charges were false and that they intended to fight the case on its merits.

The names of nineteen American Protestant clergymen who will preach in European churches this Summer, and of nine British and Canadian Protestant ministers who will preach and address conferences this Summer in the United States, were made public yesterday ...
CHICAGO, June 23.--Miss Minnie E. Howe, director of nursing and principal of the School of Nursing at the Children's Memorial Hospital for the last ten years, died today in Presbyterian Hospital.
The stock market continued yesterday to show a marked lack of enthusiasm for the $3,860,000,000 recovery program announced by President Roosevelt on the previous day.

MONTREAL, June 23 (Canadian Press).--Frank Calder, president of the National Hockey League, announced today that league governors will meet in New York next Wednesday to consider reports of the committee which has discussed agreements with the InternationalAmerican League and the Canadian Amateur Hockey Association.

The five-story apartment house for fifty-three families, known as 2,081-5 Morris Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by Isadore B. Geller, operator and builder, for cash above a first mortgage of $135,000.

Ten blind children carried the appeal of the Greater New York Fund into the hearts of more than 6,000 persons at a fund rally yesterday on the steps of the General Postoffice, Eighth Avenue and Thirty-second Street.

Imbedded in a 600-pound lead cylinder, four grams of radium worth $100,000 were transferred yesterday under a police escort from Memorial Hospital at 2 West 106th Street to the institution's new building at 444 East Sixty-eighth Street.

RED TOP, Conn., June 23 (AP).-- Robinson Stevens of Warwick, R.I., was elected captain of the 1940 Harvard varsity crew tonight at a dinner at the Crimson training camp here celebrating the clean sweep over Yale in the seventyseventh annual regatta.

WASHINGTON, June 23.--AntiAdministration Senators who think that President Roosevelt is a candidate for a third term are quoting Postmaster General Farley as saying that his survey in the West, made some time ago, showed that "Roosevelt could be renominated but could not be re-elected."

WASHINGTON, June 23.--Encouraged by the Federal Government, industrial activity in Australia is expanding rapidly, the Commerce Department reports. Construction of a large number of plants for the manufacture of steel tubing, aluminum, chemical products, rubber insulated cables and radio valves soon will begin. Proposals also are before the government in connection with the early production of automobiles and tin plate.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 23.--A change in the present system of national party conventions for Presidential nominations was urged by Herbert Agar in an oration today at the Phi Beta Kappa literary exercises held at Harvard.
ROME, June 23.--The death penalty will be decreed for grave infractions of the foreign exchange regulations, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 23.--The Brown Sharpe Manufacturing Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment stating that its 34,000 shares of $50 par value common stock would be offered publicly at $99.50 a share on or about June 27.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP).--A spokesman for Southern cotton mills demanded today that Elmer F. Andrews, administrator of the Wage and Hour Law, force the textile unions of the A.F. of L. and C.I.O. to disclose their membership distribution by States.

The suicide of a seaman, Hoyt Phillips, 20 years old, who was making his first voyage, was reported yesterday when the United States liner Manhattan arrived at Pier 59, North River, from the Channel Ports.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 23. --Sixteen students of the Academy of Our Lady of Good Counsel here will be graduated at exercises tomorrow in the chapel of the school. Mgr. Joseph A. Breslin, pastor of St. John's Church here, will present the diplomas.
WASHINGTON, June 23.--Congress sent the Tax Revision Bill removing "business irritants" to the White House after swift disposal of the measure, which was reported to the House a week ago today.

LISBON, Portugal, June 23 (By Wireless.)--The Atlantic Clipper, poised for its return trip across the Atlantic, has been held here today for what would seem to a layman a ridiculously simply thing. But it is actually a serious matter.
LONDON, June 23.--"If you want war you can have war."

WILMINGTON, Del., June 23.-- John Richardson Jr., chairman of the board of the Security Trust Company, and former president of the National Bank of Delaware, died today at his home after a three-month illness. He was 76 years old.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., June 23 (AP).--Unstinted praise for men whose lives swayed in the balance while they rescued thirty-three members of the crew of the submarine Squalus was put in the record of a naval court of inquiry today by Rear Admiral Cyrus W. Cole, commandant of the Portsmouth Navy Yard.

PITTSBURGH, June 23.--Pitching the first complete game any member of Pie Traynor's staff has turned in since June 8, Russ Bauers today scattered seven singles as the Pirates beat the Dodgers, 2 to 1, and pulled them down within a game of sixth place.

A trade paper campaign, a monthly newspaper for bureau members and a more elaborate bulletin dealing with new ideas, treatments and techniques for newspapers are among the objectives of the research and promotion division of the Bureau of Advertising of the ...

Consumer purchases of men's Summer clothing in the last six weeks have been so unusually heavy that a definite shortage of the most popular types has developed, and within another week or two will be acute, according to reports here yesterday by manufacturers, retailers and resident offices.

MADISON, N.J., June 23.--Merritt Lane, prominent New Jersey attorney, an authority on equity and a former State Vice Chancellor, died today of a heart ailment in his home on Shunpike Road. He had suffered a heart attack on June 11. He was 58 years old.
LEAVENWORTH, Kan., June 23 (AP).--Tom Pendergast, former boss of Kansas City's Democratic machine, may become a yardman at the Federal penitentiary.
SYLVAN BEACH, N.Y., June 23 (AP).--Four persons drowned in Fish Creek, about a mile from this Oneida Lake resort, early today when their automobile failed to make a curve and overturned in the water.

BOSTON, June 23.--Nestor Wilbur Davis, private secretary to John D. Rockefeller Sr. for fifteen years and secretary to other leading business executives for nearly fifty years, died at his home in Winchester at the age of 70.

WASHINGTON, June 23.--Large quantities of food are near the foreign concessions at Tientsin, according to a report today from John K. Caldwell, United States Consul General there, but the Japanese blockade continues and permission for landing of the food is being withheld.
CHICAGO, June 23.--Albert Mitchell, Bell Ranch, New Mexico, was elected chairman of the National Livestock and Meat Board at its closing session here today.

WASHINGTON, June 23.--Published reports that a large number of visitors' visas had been issued by American consular authorities in Central European countries were characterized as "exaggerations" by George S. Messersmith, Assistant Secretary of State, in testimony made public today by the House Appropriations Committee.
WASHINGTON, June 23.--A series of informal conferences, inspired by Administration leaders for discussion of Neutrality Act revision by groups of Democratic members of the House, has shown...
Morris Adelsberg, former Cornell ace and seeded No. 4, yesterday gained a semi-final bracket in the twelfth annual Richmond County singles championship at the Clifton Tennis Club in Arrochar, S.I.

WASHINGTON, June 23.--Presiident Roosevelt let it be known today that the status of Latin-American loans made in this country in the Twenties would not be allowed to exert an adverse influence on Federal loans to those nations for development and reconstruction.
ST. LOUIS, June 23 (AP).--Bill Klem, veteran National League umpire, entered St. John's Hospital today suffering from hernia and will undergo an operation.

BURLEY, Idaho, June 23 (AP).-- Deputy Sheriff George Bray of Cassia County said that Charles W. Quigley, 30, had admitted he was responsible for the death of his mother fourteen years ago, in Mount Holly, N.J.

The A.E. Nettleton Shoe Company soon will introduce a line of women's shoes, entering the women's field with a regular shoe line for the first time since it was founded in 1879, it was announced yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, June 23 (AP).-- Joseph Curran of New York, president of the National Maritime Union, was detained by police today in a raid on a local office of the union after a disturbance in which one man was injured.
BELMAR, N.J., June 23.--Welson Newman, 71 years old, of West Belmar, was killed instantly and his daughter, Elizabeth, 11, was injured critically here today when an...

BROOKLINE, Mass., June 23 (AP). --Wet courts forced postponement today of the final in the girls' national intercollegiate tennis championship until tomorrow. Miss Louise Raymond, Smith College senior from Scarsdale, N.Y., will meet Miss Elaine Fishel of the University of California at Los Angeles.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., June 23.--Finishing in the final twosome with a par-shattering 70, Tommy Goodwin of Winged Foot today captured the qualifying round medal in the sixth annual Briar Hills Golf Club invitation tournament.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 23.-- Members of the government party believe the Cabinet will revise parliamentary rules to prohibit the wearing of party uniforms in both houses. Such a measure would be aimed at the Nazis.
WASHINGTON, June 23.--The Securities and Exchange Commission and Department of Justice announced today the sentencing in District Court here of B. Edwin Lang, who was indicted under the ...

The necessity for analysis and classification of the present methods of teaching criminal law was emphasized at a meeting of representatives of local law schools and social service agencies yesterday afternoon during a round-table discussion on criminal law and its administration.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 23.-- In a bonfire of approaching sunset that spread toward the finish of the Yale-Harvard rowing race course this evening as the varsities strained on their way was a gathering of floating objects from the million-dollar floating luxury to the fifty-dollar rowboat.

WARSAW, Poland, June 23.-- Profoundly impressed by the appeal from Ignace Jan Paderewski for voluntary subscriptions to a National Defense Fund, hundreds of prominent persons have declared that they will tax themselves voluntarily for the duration of the crisis in order to facilitate the government's task in organizing resistance to German imperialism.
The New Deal Democratic Club of the Seventeenth Assembly District, West, which is backing Samuel Kantor for Democratic leader against William Solomon, announced ...

MILWAUKEE, June. 23 (AP).--Vibration of a protoplasmic jelly inside the "sinews" of muscles is the secret of strength, according to Dr. Eben J. Carey, dean of the Marquette University School of Medicine, an authority on muscles, nerves and bones, who reported his discovery today to the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

THAT is New York as Thomas Wolfe dramatized it in his novel "The Web and the Rock," reviewed here on Thursday. His words make an interesting overture for guide to the city's even more fabulous realities we are reviewing this morning.

More than 19,000 applicants will take the written test for special investigator in various city high schools this afternoon under the eyes of 2,000 monitors named by the Municipal Civil Service Commission to insure a smooth-running examination.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP).-- The House Banking Committee approved today an amendment to the Home Loan Bank Act which would permit building and loan associations to underwrite first mortgages up to $100,000 on real estate used principally for homes.

CHICAGO, June 23.--Leroy Staunton, for the past three years advertising manager of Celotex Corporation, has resigned, it was learned here today. He was previously with Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company as advertising manager.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 23.-- Julian Gillespie, who served the United States Department of Commerce in Turkey for nineteen years and was commercial attache in Turkey for thirteen years, died suddenly today of a heart attack while working in his office.
ALBANY, June 23.--The State Banking Department announced today it had received from the Savings Banks Trust Company an application, pursuant to Section 14 of the Banking Law, for authorization ...

MORRISTOWN, N.J., June 23.-- Three Pequannock Township residents who were convicted last Saturday in Quarter Sessions Court here on charges of conspiring to change the result of the Pequannock Board of Education election in February, 1938, were sentenced to prison and fined today by Morris County Judge Albert H. Holland.

The State Federation of Labor called on Senator Robert F. Wagner, author of the National Labor Relations Act, and Senator James M. Mead yesterday to vote in favor of amendments to the act sponsored by the American Federation of Labor.

Verdi's "Aida" received its repeat presentation at Lewisohn Stadium last night, drawing an audience estimated at 6,000 persons. Although an occasional cloud crossed the skies, the weather conditions were ideal for an outdoor performance of the kind, with a brilliant half-moon adding to the attractiveness of the al fresco setting.
If President Conant of Harvard departed from practice by substituting for the annual report on the academic year a brief and intimate talk on the aim of universities, it was a happy departure.

BOSTON, June 23 (AP).--The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The market for wool is definitely quieter both on Summer Street and in the country. Prices, on the average, are a cent a pound lower, in the grease, and on some descriptions fractionally more, compared with the recent peak prices.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 (AP).-- A sectional division split the seventieth annual convention of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners wide open today and prevented accomplishment of most of the aims of a group of Eastern leaders.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 23 (AP).-- Middle-aged and elderly men and women, gathered from the entire nation in the interest of Dr. Francis E. Townsend's pension plan, heard more speech-making today. Delegates of Townsend clubs had plenty of cheers for the days speakers, among whom was Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota.

The annual game between the New York Police and Fire Department nines will be staged at the Polo Grounds this afternoon with Mayor La Guardia scheduled to open festivities by throwing out the first ball.

BERLIN, June 23.--Apparently as a counter-demonstration to the Polish "Festival of the Sea" to be observed throughout Poland and especially in Gdynia next Thursday, the National Socialist authorities in Danzig have named Sunday as "Navy Day," the central feature of which will be participation by a substantial delegation of the German Navy.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23.--This city was proposed today as the site for both the Republican and Democratic National Conventions in 1940 and plans were announced by the Chamber of Commerce for a financial canvass having as its objective the raising of guarantees "exceeding those of any other city."

Within a few months a nonprofit plan operated by 16,000 physicians in seventeen counties in Southern New York State will offer to insure an individual against S150 to $300 in annual doctor's bills for $12 to $24 a year, it was learned yesterday.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

The program for today is complete. For other days, outstanding events are given; they are subject to change by Fair authorities. Complete programs appear daily in THE TIMES. Below, boldface numbers in parentheses refer to white numbers in black circles on map to the right, and show where events take place.
Percy J. King of 901 Lexington Avenue, president of the United States Catholic Historical Society, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital after a brief illness.

A daughter, their fourth child, was born to Mr. and Mrs. Gene Tunney of Stamford, Conn., yesterday at the Harkness Pavilion, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. Mrs. Tunney is the former Miss Mary Josephine Lauder, daughter of Mrs. George Lauder of Greenwich, Conn., and of the late Mr. Lauder, and a grandniece of Andrew Carnegie.
LONDON, June 23.--Foreign Secretary Viscount Halifax saw Ivan Maisky, the Russian Ambassador, tonight about what is now openly admitted to be the disappointing lack of progress in the Moscow talks.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 23.-- Left-hander Al Stevens of Yale struck out ten Harvard batters on Mercer Field today, but he lost his ball game, 5 to 4. For six innings he held the Crimson hitless while Yale enjoyed a 3-to-0 lead against Harvard's sophomore pitcher, Charley Brackett.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 23.--The government's latest pumppriming proposal, the insuring of private and public bank loans to small businesses, was assailed tonight by Colonel Leonard P. Ayres, banking statistician of Cleveland, is a "most ingenious political device ...

Members of the New York Press Association, an organization of publishers and executives of weekly newspapers in New York State, yesterday opened a five-day special Summer session in New York with a series of receptions at the World's Fair to celebrate New York Press Association Day.
GENEVA, June 23.--Warning that there is no escape from the fact that economic events and conditions in one country affect those in others, John G. Winant, American...

FORT LEE, N.J., June 23.--Peter Cella, former member of the Board of Bergen County Freeholders and proprietor of Cella's Park Hotel here, died this morning in Englewood Hospital after a heart attack. He was 70 years old.

Motorists entering the city through the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels and the George Washington Bridge may obtain immediate information on living accommodations from attendants who will be stationed in information booths at those points on Monday.

LONDON, June 23.--Baron Gottfried von Cramm, Germany's handsome ex-Davis Cup star, thrashed America's No. 1 player, Bobby Riggs, 6--0, 6--1, in a fantastic semi-final match of the London grass courts tournament at the Queens Club today.

MANHASSET, L.I., June 23.-- The marriage of Miss Hedwig Ridder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Ridder of Old Court House Road, to Orin Tuck Leach, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Leach of Red Bank, N.J., took place this afternoon in the rose gardens of the Ridder home here.

CHICAGO, June 23.--The wheat market here showed today a decided reversal of trend, closing strong, with substantial gains, after an irregular trend in the forepart of the session, when there were several sinking spells. Short covering was a factor, but there was also a moderating of hedge selling and some absorption by commission houses which took the slack out of the pit temporarily.
The contract for construction of a new two-story-and-mezzanine postoffice building in Great Neck, L.I., has been awarded to the George F. Driscoll Company, according to Brown's Letters, Inc.

ALBANY, June 23.--Governor Lehman recommended to the special session of the Legislature today the restoration of full State aid for education and for highways, and called upon the Republican majority to take up the consideration of other budget reductions, the method...
A new policy of "minimized obsolescence" in the production of service test equipment was announced yesterday by the Radio Corporation of America.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP).-- President Roosevelt nominated Louis G. Dreyfus Jr. today to be American Minister to Iran, thereby taking a step toward resumption of normal diplomatic relations with that country.
The production of lead in the United States in May amounted to 46,006 tons, compared with 39,250 in April and 32,977 in May, 1938, according to the American Bureau ...

If a thing can be done brutally and offensively, that, to the Nazi mind, is apparently the way to do it. Consider the case of Mme. Eleanor Heinsdorf, a Pole of Jewish origin, who for over ten years represented two Polish newspapers in Berlin.

Holding that no culpable or criminal evidence had been proved and that in addition the defendant had the traffic lights in his favor, Magistrate Louis Brodsky yesterday in Jefferson Market Court dismissed a simple assault charge against David B. Knott Jr., 26-yearold son of the hotel executive.
WASHINGTON, June 23.--The national birth rate in 1938 showed an increase for the second consecutive year, according to preliminary tabulations, the Census Bureau stated today.
The Home Owners Loan Corporation sold to P. Caucci and A. Gianunzio, painting contractors, the houses at 501 Center Street and 34 Fayette Street, Mamaroneck, N.Y.

Bertha Damon, author of "Grandma Called It Carnal," has retired to her Summer home in Alton, N.H., where she is working on a semi-humorous, semi-idyllic book on gardening. It will be entitled "A Sense of Humus."

WASHINGTON, June 23.--The United States Army is to be "streamlined," the War Department announced today, with the "streamlining" to apply to all components of the service--infantry, artillery, cavalry, engineers and other arms.
MONTERAL, June 23 (AP).--Silver futures closed firmer, 35-40 points up. No sales. June 40.95b, July 40.40b, September 39.90b.

Replying to critics of the recent increase in the city's basic tax rate to a record high, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that the New York rate was "lower than that of most large cities in the country."

As a parting gift from his associates in the division of jurors of the county clerk's office, where he has served for thirty-two years, Deputy County Clerk Frederic H. Cahoon received a motor boat yesterday. He is retiring July 1 and plans to spend the Summer in Maine, where he has a camp and goes fishing.

BERLIN, June 23.--The conclusion today of a British-American exchange deal was accepted here as a vindication of the barter methods adopted by Germany to bolster her foreign trade and exports. President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull are mildly chided for deserting economic principles they have stoutly defended for years.

RUMFORD, R.I., June 23.--Between 300 and 400 food distributors from all sections of the country were guests today of the Rumford Chemical Works at a triple celebration, the eightieth year of the start of the manufacture of baking powder, the eighty-fifth anniversary ...

SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 23 (AP).--Agreement to appropriate $35,000,000 as a temporary unemployment relief measure enabled the California Legislature to end its longest biennial session in State history, 175 days. The fund will serve relief needs until a more permanent plan can be worked out later in the year. The Legislature adjourned last night after weeks of bitter dispute over relief.

The report of the National Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on May 31, issued yesterday, showed a consolidated net income of $7,976,538 after all operating expenses and charges.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 23.-- Miss Marion LaDue Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robcliff Vesey Jones of this place, was married to Thomas Harris Hawks, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Haywood Hawks of Rochester, N.Y., this afternoon in the Reformed Church here by the Rev. Dr. John Henderson Powell Jr., the pastor.

LEWISBURG, Pa., June 23 (AP).-- Behind the red-brick walls of Northeastern Penitentiary, Ellis H. Parker, New Jersey detective, and his son, Ellis Jr., began today adjusting themselves to a new life in which they will be known only as prisoners 8633 and 8634.

Criticizing what he termed "financial operations and bookkeeping manipulations," Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the New York State Public Service Commission, declared yesterday that the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, ...

DETROIT, June 23.--The Rev. Dr. William H. Phelps, editor emeritus of The Michigan Christian Advocate, official weekly publication of the Detroit and Michigan Methodist Conferences, died today at his home in Royal Oak. He was 66 years old.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 23. --A cloudburst and lightning storm, the worst since last Autumn's floods, swept Westchester County late this afternoon, inundating streets and hindering traffic but bringing relief to lawns and gardens that had suffered from the drought.

NEWARK, N.J., June 23 (AP).-- Jersey City kept pace with Rochester in the first-place race by handing the Bears a 6-to-4 defeat tonight before a ladies' night gathering of 12,467. The setback was the fifth in a row for the fourth-place Newark club.

TOKYO, Saturday, June 24.--The Mongols' hunger for Spring pastures, of which they are deprived by Manchukuo's now sacrosanct Japanese-guaranteed frontier line, has apparently caused another outburst of air fighting during this week.
Mrs. Charles W. Clinton of Tuxedo Park and her granddaughter, Miss Margaret K. Clinton, are sailing Wednesday on the Aquitania to pass the Summer in England.

About 100,000 Spanish children who are homeless are now awaiting "adoption" in the French concentration camps in southern France, Walter Bluh, treasurer of the Foster Parents Plan for Spanish Children, reported last night at a dinner in his honor at La Casita Restaurant, 49 Grove Street.

Claude G. Bowers, former United States Ambassador to Spain, arrived yesterday on the United States liner Manhattan after spending several weeks at St. Jean de Luz, France, where the Embassy had its bureau during the Spanish civil war.

The Management Division of the Real Estate Board of New York announced here yesterday that it had extended to the National Association of Building Owners and Managers an invitation to hold its 1940 convention in this city.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Alice Ann Davenport, daughter of Mrs. William Rufus Davenport of Cambridge, Mass., and Newport, R.I., and the late Mr. Davenport, formerly of Rye, N.Y., to Willard Weaver Ransom, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry L. Ransom of Lockport, N.Y.
RENO, Nev., June 23 (AP).--Elizabeth Ann Tuttle of Colusa, Calif., who changed her mind after sending out 400 wedding invitations, married her second choice today.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., June 23.-- With the sweat of his Scotch brow and the aid of a freight-train caboose, vintage of 1903, for which he has paid $560, Cameron Blaikie Jr. of 41 Lincoln Street, Englewood, hopes to save the Northern Railroad of New Jersey from the demise that threatens it.

More than 1,000 employes of the Underwood Elliott Fisher Company yesterday celebrated a day at the New York World's Fair. For the occasion, the company closed its offices at 1 Park Avenue, Manhattan, and supplied the entire staff with admission tickets.

PLYMOUTH, Wis., June 23 (AP).-- Cheese quotations for the next week: Wisconsin Cheese Exchange, daisies 12 , dry basis cheddars 12. Farmers' call board, flats 12 , daisies 12 , commodores 13, horns 12 , cheddars 12.
LOS ANGELES, June 23 (AP).-- Professor E.A. Fridell of the Berkeley Baptist Divinity School at Berkeley, Calif., was nominated today as president of the Northern Baptist Convention.

With the arrival of the new Mauretania today the mind drifts back to her old namesake, to speed records broken time and time again and held for twenty-two years, and to the dark days of the World War.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $40,519,054, to be represented by sixty-six municipalities, compared with $41,025,748 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date stands at $26,460,202.

Massimo Freccia will conduct the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium tonight. Renzo Rossellini's "Preludio all' Aminta del Tasso" will appear as a novelty on a program also containing Schumann's Fourth symphony and works by Bach-Weiner and Richard Strauss.

WASHINGTON, June 23.--In the first three days for which the Securities and Exchange Commission has ever published figures on short sales for total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange, short sales by members for their own account represented 54 per cent ...

PHILADELPHIA, June 23.-- Nearly 6,000 persons, attending tonight's concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra in Robin Hood Dell, Fairmount Park, gave Josef Hofmann, the pianist, an ovation as he made his final appearance here before moving his family from Philadelphia to California.

WASHINGTON, June 23.--The House passes an "urgent" deficiency bill today carrying $2,629,377 needed by several agencies to complete the year and $1,838,175 for the Federal Communications Commission for the next fiscal year.

LIVERPOOL, June 23 (AP)-- Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 700,000 bales, against 733,000 a week ago, 778,000 two weeks ago, 782,000 three weeks ago and 1,153,000 a year ago; of which American 234,000 bales, against 251,000 a week ago, 273,000 two weeks ago, 285,000 three weeks ago and 742,000 a year ago.

DUBLIN, June 23.--With the announcement by radical Republicans that they proposed to hold a big parade to the grave of Theobald Wolfe Tone, Protestant apostle of Irish republicanism, on Sunday, the government took swift action tonight under the recently enacted Offences Against the State Act to suppress the Irish Republican Army.

The New York Roverettes defeated the Jax Girls of New Orleans, 8--5, in the feature contest of the softball double-header at Madison Square Garden last night before a crowd of 4,000. In the preliminary encounter the Manhattan Beach Girls Club won from the Elizabeth Girls Club, 4--3, in a Metropolitan Girls League game.

DENVER, June 23 (AP).--Colorado bears are killing stock and the chief game warden, John D. Hart, blames the dry weather. Flowers do not pollenize well, and bees do not make much honey. Bears miss their supply and go berserk, he said.

Miss Martha Scott Clayton, daughter of Mrs. August Zinsser, gave a dinner dance last night in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, for her house guest, Miss Rosemary Perks of London, daughter of Sir Robert Malcolm Mewburn Perks, Bart., and Lady Perks.

Measured by the accelerated timetable of today, when a week is as eventful as a year used to be, it took a long time for France and Turkey to reach the agreements signed yesterday in Paris and Ankara.

Mayor La Guardia admitted responsibility yesterday for shutting Park Commissioner Robert Moses and other speakers off the air on a WNYC broadcast on housing from the American Museum of Natural History on Nov. 22, 1938.
The nineteen banks that comprise the New York Clearing House Association will remain closed on Saturdays during July and August, the Clearing House announced late yesterday afternoon.

ST. JOHNS, Mich., June 23 (AP).-- A daylong search by Michigan State Police and Sheriff's officers led to the finding of the body of George G. Hall, 50 years old, Detroit oil promoter, in a clump of bushes beside a lonely country road near Laingsburg late today.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 23.--A strike of all American Federation of Labor members employed on county projects in Nassau County will become effective Monday morning under an order issued here today by William C. DeKonning, ...

NASSAU, Bahamas, June 23.-- The Legislature has created a home defense force to supplement the air force at the field that is now under construction. Last year, after Lord Beaverbrook and Lord Forbes had flown extensively in Lord Beaverbrook's plane through the West Indies and along the Florida coast, Lord Forbes advocated that Nassau be made an air base in war time.

A banking group headed by the Bankers Trust Company won yesterday the award of $17,000,000 of City of Memphis, Tenn., generalobligation bonds on a bid which represented a net interest cost to the city of 2.1938 per cent.

Mortimer Fishel, once the attorney for the old theatrical firm of Klaw Erlanger and in later years a recognized authority on prison labor laws, died yesterday of a heart ailment in his home at 136 West Seventy-sixth Street. He was 61 years old.

Anti-Christianity and anti-Semitism were denounced as contrary to the moral law by Dr. Patrick A. Scanlan, managing editor of The Brooklyn Tablet, speaking last night at a dinner of the Catholic Press Association at the Columbus Club, 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn.

With four detectives trailing fifty feet behind, two hold-up men, known to police only as the "Mutt and Jeff," seized a $975 payroll from a shoe manufacturer at 40-46 West Twentieth Street during the noon hour yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 23.--Between July 1 and July 20, a total of 64,267 men will be enrolled to fill vacancies as of June 30 in the Civilian Conservation Corps, Robert Fechner, director, said today. Of the July enrollees, 60,162 will be juniors in the 17 to 23 year age group and 4,105 will be war veterans.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 23.-- Miss Tina N. Appleton, daughter of Mrs. Johnston King of New York and of William H. Appleton, was married here this morning in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church to Denis Hendricks, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Hendricks.

Although the horizon is still dark with snarled budget problems that are giving administrative officials a headache, all will be bright and sunny for 1,210,000 public school children when the long-awaited tenweek Summer vacation begins next Friday afternoon.
CHICAGO, June 23 (AP).--A fumble by Heinie Mueller in the ninth inning permitted Stan Hack to score the winning run today and give the Cubs a 4-to-3 victory over the Phillies.
The A.C.F. Motors Company has received orders for eight motor coaches from the Cincinnati Street Railway Company, and two from the San Diego Electric Railway Company.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 23.-- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. A.E. Silver of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Silver, to Walter O. Johnson of Amherst, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Magnus Johnson of Haverhill, Mass. Miss Silver was graduated from Mount Holyoke College this year. Mr. Johnson was graduated in 1935 from Massachusetts State College, where he is a member of the faculty.

On bay and sound and inlet hereabouts, and onmany a good-girt lake among the hills, sailboats seek the Summer breezes. Hardy water men along the coasts know the thrill of double reefs and a buried lee rail as tallmasted sloops and schooners bowl along "outside." The season of regattas is under way.

GILLETTE, N.J., June 23.--Gil bert M. Cornish of this community, Newark lawyer and former president of the Morris County Bar Association, died suddenly of a heart attack yesterday afternoon while fishing with a party of other Newark lawyers at Shongum Lake, Morris Plains.
WASHINGTON, June 23.--President Roosevelt named Jesse H. Jones and John M. Carmody today to head the key units around which the proposed $3,860,000,000 lending program will revolve.

No one should be startled at the network of new express highways and parkways which the City Planning Commission tentatively offers as part of the "master plan" which the charter requires it to prepare.

Janet N. Erlanger has extended her holdings in Lawrence, L.I., by the acquisition of eight lots comprising a plot 164 by 110 feet, on the corner of Sutton Place and Broadway. The newly acquired parcel will be landscaped and converted into a garden fronting along Broadway. Lewis H. May Company was the broker.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, June 23. --Blanket Indians won over "dash string" Indians in the selection of the next convention city of the Reserve Officers Association at the closing session today. Oklahoma City was selected over Panama for next year's meeting place, the Oklahoma delegation offering real American Indians with blankets as an attraction.
Mrs. Elizabeth Brown Archbold, wife of John D. Archbold, died yesterday of a streptococcus infection in the Regent Nursing Home at 115 East Sixty-first Street. She was 25 years old.

LIMA, Peru, June 23 (AP).--The Peruvian electorate apparently has voted overwhemingly in favor of ten constitutional amendments, proposed by President Oscar R. Benavides, concentrating wider powers in the executive branch of the government and limiting the legislative.

TIENTSIN, China, June 23 (AP).-- The British Consul General sent a new protest to the Japanese today against undressing and searching of British subjects at Concession barriers, but a fresh incident of that kind was reported almost immediately thereafter.
Police mechanics began yesterday the installation of Diesel engines to generate electricity at Police Headquarters in Manhattan and at four police stations, two in the Bronx and two in Brooklyn.
PARIS, June 23.--Following is the text of the French-Turkish mutual assistance pact signed here today:

Crucible Steel Company of America ten-year sinking-fund 4 per cent debentures, Series A, due Aug. 1, 1948, and first mortgage bonds 4 per cent series due Sept. 1, 1963, of the Michigan Consolidated Gas Company, will be admitted to dealings today.

A new six-story apartment house will rise on the north side of Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, where a plot 100 by 116 feet, 100 feet east of Underhill Avenue, has been purchased by the Fifty-five Eastern Parkway Corporation, Leon A.

BRATISLAVA, Slovakia, June 23. --The new Slovak constitution was laid before Parliament today. It provides for the election of President by Parliament for seven-year periods. Provision is also made for a National Council in which minority groups will be represented and for a Parliament of eighty members elected for five years.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP).--The Works Progress Administration reported today that its recreation projects cost $11,881,196 in the quarter ending March 31. SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 (AP).-- A threat to "pull the crews off the ships and tie up the Coast" if employers "insist on their present position" came today from Ed Whalen, vice president of the Shipping Clerks Union, as the major part of San Francisco Bay shipping remained idle for the eighth day.

JERSEY CITY, June 24.--The Rev. Joseph Petraitis, pastor of St. Michael's Catholic Church of Bayonne, N.J., died yesterday in St. Francis Hospital, at the age of 55. Father Petraitis was pastor of St. Michael's Church for ten years, going there from Paterson.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 24.-- Rains which interrupted the harvest of small grains over the Southwest this week were not an unmixed evil. Row crops were benefited greatly and pastures and water for stock were helped to such an extent that one of the hazards of livestock production-- forced marketing of grass-fat cattle in the late Summer--should be overcome this season.

Subject to the approval of the Court of Chancery of Delaware, the directors of Loft, Inc., have accepted an offer of settlement in the company's long drawn-out legal proceedings against Charles G. Guth. A hearing on the proposed offer of settlement is scheduled for July 6 at Dover, Del.

ABOUT 120 years ago an unusual vessel slipped out of Savannah harbor bound for Liverpool, England. That was the Savannah, the first American ship to use steam in crossing the ocean.
