WASHINGTON, July 3.--Despite the government holiday today Secretary Hull spent the entire morning at the State Department poring over diplomatic reports telling of increased tension in Europe and, to a somewhat lesser extent, in Asia.
For the second time in a year members of the New York Curb Exchange are starting a concerted drive on the problem of reciprocal business. Last Fall, on the basis of ...

A new statement of the old American principle of tolerance, framed as a pledge to be taken by all citizens, will be presented to the United States today from its two World's Fairs, at countless community celebrations of Independence Day, from the pulpit and the stage and over the radio.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., July 3.-- Dr. James Monroe Smith, former president of Louisiana State University, and his wife were brought back to the United States tonight under guard of Louisiana officers, who are returning the educator to Baton Rouge to face $100,000 embezzlement charges.

TOKYO, July 3.--A statement issued tonight by the War Office declares that the forthcoming conference here is concerned not only with the maintenance of order in Tientsin, but with Britain's whole China policy.
The city of Philadelphia, Pa., school district will be in the market on July 26 with an issue of $3,750,000 of bonds, for which bidders ...
BOSTON, July 3--Trustees of the Old Colony Railroad filed today a $17,000,000 suit in Suffolk County Superior Court against the Bankers ...
GENEVA, July 3.--World unemployment figures for the second quarter of this year, which the International Labor Office published today. showed, compared with the ...
Fairgoers who envy Mr. Whalen his rich mahogany tan would never suspect that the Great White Father of Flushing wears a mask; but he does.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 3.--Two men who had reported they saw a meteor explosion at the time Portland and the surrounding countryside was jolted yesterday provided a clue today in the search for fragments.
MANCHESTER, Vt., July 4.-- That the saying "You can't keep a good man down," holds as true for golf as for other pursuits was proved today when Richard (Dick) Chapman, brilliant young Greenwich ...
CHALONS-SUR-MARNE, France, July 4.--United States Ambassador William C. Bullitt today dedicated a plaque here at the spot where America's Unknown Soldier was chosen eighteen years ago.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 4.--A spectacular three-hour fire destroyed an entire block of stores on the Boardwalk here this morning while a crowd of some 50,000 holiday visitors thronged the beach and near-by rooftops to witness the event.
ROME, July 4.--Italy is in a state of watchful waiting over Danzig. Far removed from the scene, she can do nothing directly except demonstrate her full support of Germany's activities.
TOKYO, Wednesday, July 5.--Another fantastic Japanese-Mongol air battle, in which fifty Soviet-type planes were shot down occurred yesterday according to the Asahi correspondent at the front.

Demon A. Mullin, former hockey star and coach who developed many amateurs into professional stars, leaped or fell to his death yesterday morning from the sixth floor of the Hotel Imperial, his body landing on the marquee at Thirtysecond Street and Broadway. He was 39 years old.
TORONTO, July 4 (Canadian press).--Freed of New York's leadership for one day, the Toronto market moved ahead today to register wide gains.

Giuseppe Garibaldi's effort to establish liberty in Italy was compared with the fight in this country for the preservation of American democracy by Representative Vito Marcantonio in an address yesterday at a rally in Washington Square to celebrate the 132d anniversary of Garibaldi's birth.
Something will just have to be done about that former Dodger, Emil (Dutch) Leonard, who seems to have cast a spell over the worldchampion Yankees.
WASHINGTON, July 4.--The National Labor Relations Board, summarizing its work from the Fall of 1935 to June 1, 1939, reported today that it had handled 21,933 cases involving 5,045,561 workers.

LONDON, July 4.--Still another hitch in the negotiations in Moscow became apparent today just as the stock markets here and in Paris were responding joyfully to rumors that a three-power alliance between Britain, France and Russia was about to be signed at last.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 (AP).-- The Red Sox staged a holiday hit parade to club the Athletics into submission in both ends of a double-header today, beating them, 17 to 7, in the opener and, 18 to 12, in the nightcap.

BOSTON, July 4.--The Giants spent more than four and one-half hours this humid afternoon trying to declare their independence of the Bees in what is quaintly known here as "The Hive"--and wound up squarely behind the eight ball.

WASHINGTON, July 5.--Senator Barkley of Kentucky, Democratic leader, ridiculed tonight those who have accused various Administrations in Washington of seeking to ally the United States permanently with foreign nations.

In a pamphlet called "Religious Liberty in the United States Today" the American Civil Liberties Union has assembled the facts in regard to the present protection of and restraints on religious freedom.

WARSAW, Poland, July 4.--The Polish warning to the Danzig Senate to cease military preparations in the Free City, it is understood, will not be delivered before the week-end, not until diplomatic discussions for concerted action between Warsaw, London and Paris have been concluded.

WASHINGTON, July 4.--The slum-clearance program of the United States Housing Authority was described today by Nathan Straus, Administrator, as a new development in the independence program of the country.
In holiday observance, the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra presented three American works--two of recent date--last night at Lewisohn Stadium under the baton of Alexander Smallens.

GLEN COVE, N.Y., July 4.--After a battle of two hours and a quarter under a blazing sun Wayne Sabin of Portland, Ore., added his name to the list of winners of the Nassau Country Club Challenge Bowl today, defeating Ernest Sutter of New Orleans, 6--8, 6--4, 7--5, 6--4.
WASHINGTON, July 4.--A halt in the "alarming growth of interstate trade interference" is chronicled by the Department of Agriculture.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 4. --Jim Bruen, 19-year-old Irish amateur, with the greatest display of consistent golf the ancient St. Andrews course has seen since the days of "R.T. Jones, Esquire," today shot his second 69 in two days to lead 129 qualifiers for the British open championship.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 4.--An all-time record for the number of starters in an Independence Day regatta on Long Island Sound was established today at the Larchmont Yacht Club when 183 craft went into the competition.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 4.-- Varied events took place today for out-of-town guests at estates throughout the colony. One of the largest parties was the buffet luncheon given today by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Murray Jr. at Wickapogue, their place on the ocean, to celebrate the nineteenth birthday of their son, James Bradley Murray.

WINNIPEG, July 4 (AP).--Little change was registered by wheat futures on the Winnipeg Grain Exchange today as buyers and sellers remained on the sidelines throughout most of the session. Final quotations were unchanged to cent a bushel higher, with July at 58 7/8 bid, October 60, November 61 bid and December 61 cents.

WASHINGTON, July 4.--Representative Harry W. Griswold of Wisconsin died of a heart attack this afternoon while at the wheel of his car. His wife was with him. A Republican serving his first term in the House, Mr. Griswold was 53 years old.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, July 4.--One of the most interesting features of the celebration of the United States' Independence Day throughout Latin America and one ...

LONDON, July 4 (AP).--A blunt suggestion that the "real cause" of heavy loss of life in the Thetis submarine disaster was "dilatoriness in sending ships to the rescue" was advanced at a board of inquiry hearing today by Reginald Paget, representing relatives of one of the ninety-nine victims.
The number of persons injured by firecrackers and fireworks in celebrating the Fourth totaled 1,258 throughout the city, according to hospital reports last night.

BERLIN, July 4.--Spectacular propaganda activities of the German fighting forces--which began with Chancellor Adolf Hitler's highly publicized tour of Germany's western forts in May--will continue this week with a series of test manoeuvres by technical troops.

Five members of the American Social Action Mission to Venezuela headed by the Rev. John O'Hara, president of Notre Dame University, returned yesterday on the steamship Santa Rosa of the Grace Line. The group had conferred for a week in Caracas as adviser to the Venezuelan Government on a social program for the country.

WASHINGTON, July 4.--The long-awaited hearings to determine whether Harry Bridges, West Coast longshoremen's leader and regional director of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, should be deported on charges of being a Communist alien, will begin in San Francisco Monday, with James M. Landis, former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, acting as trial examiner.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 4.--Colonel Louis A. Johnson, Assistant Secretary of War, in an address delivered tonight before the University of Virginia Institute of Public Affairs, said that in defense of its freedom the United States must be prepared to prevent the seizure and occupation of any additional territory on the Western Hemisphere by a European or Asiatic power.

When the Temporary National Economic Committee was formed it was widely advertised as a body that would examine the problem of monopoly with an open mind and give all interests an opportunity to be heard.
KANSAS CITY, July 4 (AP).--William Allen White, Emporia editor, told Americans today that this was a land "where to be brave we must be free, where the free must be ever brave."

As millions of Americans joined yesterday in celebrating the 163d anniversary of our independence, a new note of anxiety for the nation's future was sounded in pronouncements by leaders representing many points of view.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 4.--Accused of sabotage and anti-government measures, Mauricio Hochschild, manager and owner of one of the most important mining and tin-ore buying firms operating in Bolivia and Chile, was imprisoned at the central police headquarters for forty-eight hours, it was disclosed today officially.

BERLIN, July 4.--The resettlement on German territory of former Austrians of South Tyrol who did not become Italian citizens in 1920 and other Reich subjects there has become the subject of formal negotiations between Germany and Italy.
Sales by institutions predominated in the Manhattan realty trading reported yesterday, when business and residential parcels passed into new ownership.

IT was different at St. Andrews back in 1933. That was a Ryder Cup year over there and the United States had the full squad entered in the British open, including the defending champion, Gene Sarazen.
The Guaranty Trust Company of New York in its statement of condition as of June 30 reported total resources and deposits at the highest levels shown on any statement in the bank's history.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt and Maxwell Howard were present yesterday at Empire City, along with about 12,000 others, to see their horses Now What and The Chief annex the day's featured races after they had gone up in the betting.

With seven of the eight New York newspapers registering a linage gain last month, total advertising for the group in June advanced 5.6 per cent, according to a compilation based on Media Records figures. The total for last month was 8,459,059 lines as against 8,006,796 for the corresponding period of 1938.
PALO ALTO, Calif., July 4.-- World famous authorities on three vital life substances agreed today on the close connection between vitamins, plant hormones and enzymes in explaining growth, as a ...
Heavy engineering construction awards for the five weeks of June had an aggregate value of $262,395,000, or an average of $52,479,000 per week, according to The Engineering News-Record.

WINNIPEG, July 4 (Canadian Press).--Instead of following Great Britain's foreign policy, Canada should immediately form an independent one and define the Dominion's constitutional position with regard to the empire and other nations, declared a resolution approved last night at the fourth Canadian Youth Congress.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 4.-- Westchester County celebrated today a "safe and sane Fourth," with only forty persons requiring hospital treatment for minor powder burns and with public fireworks displays tonight on a larger scale than ever before.

BRIELLE, N.J., July 4.--The school of tuna had been supplying quite a bit of sport for the anglers fishing out of this port. They had been until we put out this morning, then they decided to look over broader waters. A few were taken, but they were small.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 4.--Taking "Foreign and Domestic Foes of Freedom" as the subject of its Fourth of July general session in the War Memorial Opera House tonight, the convention of the National Education Association heard widely different points of view expressed by members of the Dies Committee and the La Follette Civil Liberties Committee.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 4.-- Pare Lorenz, who produced "The Plow That Broke the Plains" and "The River" under government auspices, has arrived in Hollywood to complete the technical work on Paul De Kruif's "Fight for Life."

WHAT the average American doesn't know about the State of New Jersey would, as the saying goes, fill a large book; and, as a Jerseyman born and bred, and now necessarily languishing in exile, I have had many opportunities to reflect thereupon.
NEWPORT, July 4.--Governor and Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt had quite a display of fireworks at Oakland Farm in Portsmouth tonight for the amusement of their daughters and holiday guests.
PASADENA, Calif., July 4.--Dr. Walter Baade and associates have found evidence of exploding stars which reach a brilliance 1,000,000,000 times that of the sun.

Former Deputy Police Commissioner Joseph Faurot, father of finger-printing in the United States, told us long ago how skeptics tried to confound him with sets of prints taken from the fingers of identical twins but never did.

BERLIN, July 4.--The ReichsKredit-Gesellschaft, a leading Berlin bank, today issued its semi-annual survey of Germany's economic situation, which is regarded as the most authoritative summary published in Germany.

Mr. and Mrs. William Tredick McIntire of Englewood, N.J., and Fishers Island, N.Y., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Miller McIntire, to Hudson Ashley Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Frederick Smith of Syracuse.

The new liner America, the largest ever constructed in the United States, will be launched on Aug 31, earlier than expected, it became known yesterday. The United States Lines has made no announcement ...

WESTBURY, L.I., July 4.--A spectacular goal by Bobby Gerry late in the final period defeated the Hurricanes, 7 to 6, today and enabled the Aknusti polo quartet to finish in second place in the Meadow League division of the Meadow Brook Club cups tourney.

Despite cloudy, threatening weather a large crowd turned out yesterday for the Fourth of July celebration at the World's Fair. Nearly 250,000 persons watched a day and night of waving flags, marching troops, playing bands, sparkling fireworks and patriotic meetings and parades that began at 11:30 A.M. and lasted until late at night.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 4.--A crowd estimated at 18,000 persons, the largest number on record, attended the fifteenth annual Cowal Games, held under the auspices of the Round Hill Scottish Games Association, at the estate of Charles A. Moore in Round Hill today. Nine States and Canada were represented.

LONDON, July 4.--The welcome King George and Queen Elizabeth received in the United States "made me feel very proud as an Englishman," the Duke of Kent declared at the annual Fourth of July dinner of the American Society in London tonight.
Former President Herbert Hoover asked yesterday for a formal declaration by our government that we will not go to war with any European nation unless the Western Hemisphere is attacked.

Japan was labeled "public enemy No. 1 of international security" in an Independence Day address broadcoast yesterday to the United States from Chungking, China, by Dr. H.H. Kung, Premier of China and president of the Sino-American Association for Cultural Relations. The address was heard here over a nation-wide network of the National Broadcasting Company.

PARIS, July 4.--In a rousing speech emphasizing the complete cooperation existing between the French and British Governments and their high commands, Leslie Hore-Belisha, British War Secretary, tonight exalted in Paris the military and moral strength of the Western democracies.
MEXICO CITY, July 4.--Conclusion of an $18,000,000 deal with the Mexican Government Petroleum Agency was announced today by Santo Vahlis, representative of the Brazilian firm of Correa Castro.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 4. Miss Helen Jacobs's hope of staging a comeback in the All-England tennis championship was blasted today when she was beaten in the quarter-finals by Miss Kay Stammers, 6--2, 6--2.
With eleven holiday matinees, the same number as last July 4, business yesterday was generally disappointing. There was the usual crop of alibis, including the following:

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 4.-- Joseph Fishbach, St. John's University ace, who is the defending champion, and Gerard Podesta, Princeton's captain this season and last year's runner-up, joined three other seeded players in the quarterfinals of the annual Eastern intercollegiate singles tennis championship tournament today at the Montclair Athletic Club courts.

WASHINGTON, July 4.--Secretary of Commerce Hopkins presented today an optimistic picture of the country's business position in a review of developments in June. Business activity expanded in the last six weeks, he said, with June industrial production rising above the March level.
BATON ROUGE, La., July 4.-- Behind the bars of the East Baton Rouge Jail, Dr. J. Monroe Smith, who is under indictment for embezzlement of the funds of Louisiana State University ...
Two vast holiday throngs, one returning to New York City from shore and country resorts, the other leaving the World's Fair, poured through the metropolitan area last night.
Mayor La Guardia was mildly booed yesterday when he spoke to 1,500 persons at the official opening of the $13,000,000 Red Hook housing development in Brooklyn, and promptly squelched his hecklers.

ANDOVER, N.J., July 4.--New Jersey's law which prohibits the wearing of uniforms similar to those used in a foreign nation and barring the Nazi method of saluting was ignored here today as seventy-five members of the Ordnungsdienst, attired in their grey and black "storm trooper" uniforms ...

The American Youth Congress, which on Monday refused to include in its official creed a declaration placing communism on a level with nazism and fascism as contrary to American ideals, adopted by a unanimous vote yesterday a resolution condemning all forms of dictatorship and including communism among them.

Formal celebration of Independence Day at the World's Fair began before noon yesterday with exercises at the foot of the heroic statue of George Washington on Constitution Mall. The colors were presented and the flags of the fortyeight States, each carried by a uniformed Boy Scout, were paraded.

Dr. C.C. Carstens of 16 Middlemay Circle, Forest Hills, executive director of the Child Welfare League of America since 1921, died yesterday of coronary thrombosis in New York Hospital. He was 74 years old.

CHICAGO, July 4.--Strong measures to protect wheat producers' income were being taken today throughout the Grain Belt as the flow to market of the 1939 crop reached high tide with prices lower than on any Indepedence Day since 1932.

PITTSBURGH, July 4 (AP).--Pittsburgh and Cincinnati split their holiday double-header today before 41,937 fans, the season's largest crowd here, the league-leading Reds taking the first, 7--4, and the Pirates the second, 4--3.

LONDON, July 4.--The stock markets brightened today on reports-- subsequently disproved--of imminent signature of an Anglo-Russian pact. Gilt-edge issues were prominent in the general advance. Transatlantic shares also went ahead, but business was restricted because the United States markets were closed.
ELMIRA, N.Y., July 4.--Lieutenant Robert M. Stanley of the naval air base at Pensacola broke his own altitude record at the soaring meet today, and established a new American high mark.
Determined to smear the City Hall reporters to a fare-thee-well in their annual baseball game on July 13 at Travers Island, members of the City Council gleefully announced ...

Millions of city folk, lured by perfect Fourth of July weather, passed the holiday yesterday at beach resorts, where not a single drowning had been reported late last night. Casualties were confined for the most part to the usual cases of sunburn and aches induced by overindulgence in hot dogs, soda pop and strenuous exercise.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., July 4.-- President Roosevelt called on the Senate today to reverse the House action to forbid shipments of arms and munitions to nations at war, and said that he was prepared to see Congress remain in session until September, if necessary, to accomplish that result.

Fireworks colored the sky with the red, white and blue of the nation's colors over the World's Fair Grounds last night as two spectacular and elaborate displays of fire, water and music were set off, first from the Lagoon of Nations in the exhibit area and a short while later from Fountain Lake in the amusement area.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, which arrived here Monday and tied up at Pier 90, at the foot of West Fiftieth Street, proved to be one of the major attractions yesterday for out-of-town visitors, of whom a crowd estimated by the police at 10,000 paid 25 cents each to go aboard the super-liner.

Last year was a banner year in public recreation. More communities provided themselves with public recreation under leadership, employed more full-time year-round recreation leaders and served more of the population than ever before.

GENEVA, July 4.--The Economic Committee of the League of Nations recommended in its report to the Council, published today, that the League's economic and financial organization be requested to make a full study of "the economic repercussions of armament production, including its influence on the living standard."

LONDON, July 4.--"The People of the State of New York" lost their case before the British Empire's highest court today in another attempt to recover $312,000 deposited in Canada of the $3,405,449 lost in the Queens sewer fraud of a decade ago.

JERSEY CITY, July 4.--The Jersey City Giants and Newark Bears divided a double-header before 17,243 fans at Roosevelt Stadium today. The Bruins captured the first contest, 2 to 0, but finished on the short end of a 5-to-1 count in the nightcap.

LONDON, July 4 (AP).--Sir John Simon, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said today that the British Government had no intention of complying with demands of Japanese spokesmen that it cease supporting Chinese currency.

WASHINGTON, July 4.--Administration leaders who remained in the capital over the holiday were vague about plans for neutrality legislation, which, with the Monetary Bill, makes the date of adjournment of Congress a problem.

LINCOLN, Neb., July 4.--A spiked shoe bombshell dropped into the middle of Lincoln's Fourth of July celebration at the University of Nebraska Stadium today when little-regarded Blaine Rideout won the national 1,500-meter championship, one of the most stunning surprises in the fifty-one-year history of the A.A.U.

VIENNA, July 4.--Theodor Cardinal Innitzer, Archbishop of Vienna, was brutally assaulted in Koenigsbrunn on Sunday following a series of Nazi demonstrations while he was making a tour of rural districts northwest of Vienna, it was learned today.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 4.--Pan American Airways' Dixie Clipper landed here at 8:49 A.M. today to complete the first round-trip airplane crossing of the North Atlantic with paid passengers.

An increase of approximately 9.9 per cent in freight carloadings in the third quarter of this year over actual loadings in the same quarter of 1938 is estimated by the thirteen Shippers Advisory Boards. The estimate was made public yesterday by the Association of American Railroads.

LENOX, Mass., July 4.--One hundred and ninety members and guests were present at the seventyfifth annual Independence Day luncheon at the Lenox Club here today. Tables were set on the verandas and lawn beneath the elms and maples.

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP).--The Cubs, although getting only 10 hits off four St. Louis pitchers, broke even with the Cards today in a holiday double-header before 26,409 fans, winning the second, 3 to 2, in 10 innings, after losing the first, 6 to 4.

To witness the army of young amateur photographers, armed with everything from box cameras to telescopic movie outfits, swarming over the World's Fair yesterday, shooting pictures instead of firecrackers, one would almost think that the camera had replaced the cannon cracker as a Fourth of July institution.

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 4.--More than 5,000 spectators enjoyed the second day's Grand Circuit card at Historic Track today. Most of the heats were so closely contested that the crowd disagreed in some cases with the decisions of the judges. Fast times were made, although favorites were beaten in three of the four events.
NEWARK, N.J., July 4.--More than 125,000 persons attended today Newark's Independence Day celebration in Weequahic Park.

Average fixed charge coverage of principal water works operating companies in the United States declined slightly last year to 1.92 per cent from 1.96 in 1937 and 1.95 in 1936, according to R.E. Swart Co. in its ninth annual edition of "Water Works Securities."
BAR HARBOR, Me., July 4.--A huge fireworks display in the harbor tonight culminated the Independence Day celebration in which members of the Summer colony and permanent residents participated.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP).--President Roosevelt's proposed $3,860,000,000 lending program to spur business won support today from Senator Adams of Colorado, a leader of the Senate economy group, on the eve of the introduction of the plan in Congress.

PRAGUE, July 4.--More than 380,000 Czechs of the protectorate of Bohemia-Moravia will be put under purely German local administration through a decree issued last night by Baron Constantin von Neurath, the Reich Protector, dissolving town councils and appointing German commissioners in four Moravian towns and one Bohemian.
In perhaps as colorful and dramatic a pageant as ever was enacted on a baseball field, 61,808 fans thundered a hail and farewell to Henry Lou Gehrig at the Yankee Stadium yesterday.

Notables leaving today for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary include the Duke and Duchess of Roxburghe, Sir William Wiseman, Lieut. Gen. Sir Geoffrey Howard, Sir Ness N. Wadia, Sir James Paget, Sir Mark and Lady Sheldon, Baron and Baroness Carl von Seidlitz, Baron and Baroness Kerchova, Baron Leopold Buffin and Baron Jean Buffin.

MOSCOW, July 4 (AP).--An electrical "disease meter" constructed by Russian scientists is proving successful in the early diagnosis of cancer, Izvestia, the Soviet Government newspaper, reported today.
If grass hasn't been growing in the streets of this and other cities since Friday afternoon it isn't because any one really cared whether it did or not.
There is disagreement in Washington regarding the situation that has been created by the defeat of the Administration's monetary bill.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 4 (AP).--Engineers were making ready today a short wave "Big Bertha" for action against Germany and Italy in the "war" for control of the South America radio lanes.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., July 5 (AP).--Thomas Jefferson Newbold, president of a Boston electrical engineering company, died of a heart attack at midnight last night at the age of 53.
COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, July 5. --A new kind of prohibition started in Iowa today. As a result, before long, cigarettes may cost some Iowa consumers "who try to" avoid the State tax $50.12 a package.
CHICAGO, July 5 (AP).--The largest daily double pay-off of the year was registered at Arlington Park today as the combination of Hard Loser and Bluefield paid $3,835.20 for $2.
The United States Maritime Commission's investigation of rates and practices in the intercoastal steamship industry continued in its third week yesterday at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn.

SUSSEX, N.J., July 5.--Dr. W. Spader Willis, retired principal and one of the organizers of the Newark Normal School, now known as the Newark State Teachers College, and former vice president of the Institute of Arts and Sciences, now Newark University, died at his home here this morning of a heart attack. He was 77 years old.

The first of a series of medical and physical tests compiled by the Municipal Civil Service Commission for candidates for the police force was held yesterday at New York University's Intramural Field on the uptown campus in the Bronx. Two hundred and fifty applicants, who previously had passed a written examination, took part in the strenuous exercises.

LINCOLN, Neb., July 5.--Messrs. Glenn Cunningham, Chuck Fenske and Louis Zamperini should have spent last night reading and rereading the old fable of the tortoise and the hare. In that, you will remember, the hare dozed by the wayside and the tortoise won the race.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,463,000 barrels against 3,452,800 in the previous week, an increase of 10,200, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. This was 28,000 barrels under the calculation of 3,491,000...

Expecting increased use of bicycles on the streets and highways of the State during the vacation months, Motor Vehicle Commissioner Carroll E. Mealey made public yesterday safety regulations that apply to bicycle riding.

WASHINGTON, July 5.--President Roosevelt returned from a week-end at Hyde Park, called in the party's congressional leaders and urged action at this session on revision of the Neutrality Act and his new self-liquidating lending program.
SHANGHAI, July 5 (AP).--Wang Ching-wei, former Chinese Premier, is reported to be attempting to form a new political party to undermine China's Kuomintang, the government party.

John Harlan Amen, special Assistant Attorney General investigating charges of official corruption in Brooklyn, revealed yesterday that he had been requested by Governor Lehman to submit a report covering his inquiry into the judicial affairs of Kings County Judge...

MOSCOW, July 5 (AP).--Soviet Russian camera men are filming spectacular battle scenes on Russia's western frontier for a new screen feature, "The First Cavalry Army," portraying episodes in the struggle of the young Soviet republic against foreign invaders during the civil war and intervention period.

With a note of sorrow in his voice, Henry William Jeffers Sr., 68-yearold inventor of the rotolactor (cow merry-go-round) at the World's Fair and an internationally famous dairyman, who also is the greatgreat-grandnephew of a pirate who was hanged at Ellis Island in 1831, declared yesterday that the artificial moo, installed to liven up his rotolactor, was all wrong.

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 5.--Cousin Hal, bay colt son of Hal Dale owned by Thomas Thomas of Cleveland and driven by Jay Douglas, won the Village Farm Stake for 2-year-old pacers at Historic Track today. The Purse was $3,115.

With the opposition giving an impressive exhibition of how the game of baseball should not be played, the Dodgers batted robustly and fielded perfectly for Freddy Fitzsimmons yesterday at Ebbets Field, subjecting the Phillies to a 7-1 setback, their ninth in a row.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 5. --The British Empire dominated the British open golf championship today as Bobby Locke of South Africa and three Englishmen, J.H. Busson, Dick Burton and Max Faulkner, set the pace for 129 entries with 70s for the first round of play.

The calm assurance of an 80-yearold retired policewoman, combined with the subtle allure of beef stew, kept Elbert Vivian Smith, 33 years old, from leaping to his death yesterday from the roof of a four-story Brooklyn building.

A new low death rate for New York City was set last week for the second week in succession, it was reported yesterday to Dr. John L. Rice, city Health Commissioner, by Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records in the Health Department.
Mr. and Mrs. Newell J. Ward Jr., who had been at the Madison for several days after their marriage in Middleburg, Va., have sailed for Europe. Mrs. Ward is the former Miss Bettina Belmont.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $2,224,592,081 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price a share of all listed stocks on June 30 was $28.70 compared with $30.29 at the end of May.

BERLIN, July 5.--Leading Nazi party organs today accuse the British Foreign Office of having summoned the diplomatic correspondents of British newspapers to a conference last Saturday and having instructed them that "a Nazi Putsch was imminent and the situation was very grave" in Danzig.
A fortune in fur garments in the latest styles was shown three times at the World's Fair yesterday as part of the celebration of Custom Furriers Day.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 5.--Closer organization of teachers, Federal aid for education and a recurring note of demand for harder work and more discipline for students stood out today among the manifold phases of the annual convention of the National Education Association at forty meetings attended by 15,000 teachers.

Six thousand five hundred men obtained applications yesterday for city jobs as auto enginemen paying $1,200 to $1,500. Several hundred spent all night outside the office of the Municipal Civil Service Commission at 96 Duane Street in the belief that the early applicants would get the first jobs. More than 1,000 were in line when the doors opened.

A stronger tone was evidenced yesterday in the bond market. Trading was 63 per cent greater than Monday's small turnover, but activity was at the second slowest pace since May 18 none the less. Advances were scored in all groups on the Stock Exchange except the industrial, where the average price declined slightly.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP).--The Senate Labor Committee heard conflicting demands today for revision of the National Labor Relations Act and for retention of the law in its present form.

CHICAGO, July 5 (AP).--Eddie Smith, who for three years had been trying to southpaw his way to victory over the Indians, did it today in his tenth attempt--a two-hit performance which gave the White Sox a 2-to-1 triumph in the series opener.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 5.--The fourth serious spill on Meadow Brook polo fields this season occurred today when C. Mott Woolley, captain and star of the Yale University team that won the intercollegiate championship last month, went down on Waterbury Field in the third period of the Meadow Brook Club Cups tournament match between Broadhollow and East Williston.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 5.-- Larry Dee of Stanford University, one of the best Pacific Coast players to invade the East in many years, will oppose William Umstaedter of Louisiana State for the Eastern intercollegiate freshman tennis singles title Saturday afternoon at 1 o'clock at the Montclair Athletic Club.

Three thousand happy children initiated yesterday the Summer program of the Educational Alliance, the social, recreational and educational center of New York's lower East Side for more than a quarter of a century.

Yesterday was designated as Thomas Cook Day at the New York World's Fair in honor of the man who ninety-eight years ago to the day started a travel-for-pleasure business that has carried thousands of men and women on tours throughout the world and to all the world's fairs of the last century.

Basil James, leading rider in New York, narrowly escaped serious injury at Empire City yesterday when Scotch Flower, on whom he had the mount in the fourth race, ran away for a mile going to the post and then dashed into a fence. James was thrown and knocked out for a few minutes.

WIMBLETON, England, July 5.-- The way was cleared today for an all-American final in the men's singles of the Wimbledon tennis tournament when Elwood Cooke defeated Henner Henkel of Germany, 6--3, 4--6, 6--4, 6--4, and Bobby Riggs swept through Ferenc Puncec of Yugoslavia, 6--2, 6--3, 6--4.
J.P. Morgan, the banker, sailed on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary yesterday for his regular annual visit to London and the grouse lands of Scotland where he shoots each year.

Lew Brown, whose last production was "Calling All Stars" in December,1934, tonight unveils "Yokel Boy," the third musical of the Summer season, at the Majestic. Mr. Brown is responsible for the book, suggested by the life of the late Jack Donahue, the dancer, and...

WASHINGTON, July 5.--Several States and many subdivisions united today in an attack on the Treasury's proposal to eliminate the tax exemption on future issues of securities, their speaker declaring it would produce "a terrific fiscal upheaval" and would tend to make the States "vassals" of a "central" as distinguished from a "federal" government.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 5.--The keel for the 35,000-ton battleship South Dakota was laid today at the yard here of the New York Shipbuilding Company. Four years will be required to complete the craft, at a cost of $52,794,000.
ROME, July 5.--The forthcoming visit of Count Galeazzo Ciano to Spain, announced in this morning's Spanish newspapers, is regarded as of considerable importance here.

Thousands of WPA construction workers here and throughout the nation refused to work yesterday in protest against the decision of Congress that they would have to put in longer working hours for their monthly relief checks.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 5.--Miss Aerielle Frost Frazer, who will be married to the Hon. Michael Strutt of England in an out-of-door ceremony on July 15, entertained a group of her younger friends at Bailey's Beach today.

Scathingly denouncing bribe givers who corrupt legislators, Judge James Garrett Wallace in General Sessions yesterday sentenced Edward S. Moran Jr., former Democratic Brooklyn Assemblyman, to a Sing Sing term of two and a half to five years for accepting $36,000...

WASHINGTON, July 5.--The United States today imposed countervailing duties on silk importations from Italy, effective Aug. 13, to offset the amount of bounties, or subsidies, that the Italian Government pays to shippers of such merchandise.

Jan Bata, head of the great shoe manufacturing industry in CzechoSlovakia, which in recent years has branched out into other fields of production all over the world, arrived yesterday on the French liner Ile de France accompanied by his wife, four daughters and a son.

Crown Prince Olav of Norway showed his sailing skill by taking the helm of a twelve-meter racing yacht in Long Island Sound yesterday and finishing second in an informal contest of twelve miles. For two-thirds of the distance he showed the way to the American skippers.

Grover A. Whalen, president of the World's Fair Corporation, predicted in a statement last night that there would be a big influx of visitors to the Fair from other parts of the country during the Summer vacation months. PARIS, July 5.--How well France is weathering the present international strain was told by Finance Minister Paul Reynaud today at the weekly luncheon of the British and American Correspondents Association.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 5.-- Plans are going forward rapidly for the dog show to be held July 22 on the grounds of the Southampton Golf Club under the auspices of the Southampton Kennel Club, of which Harry Pelham Robbins is president.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5.--As an answer to a reported challenge from "gambling lords," the biggest police shake-up in this city in eight years was ordered today by Andrew J. Emanuel, Director of Public Safety.

Wang Ching-wei had already reached Shanghai secretly before this writer left China late in May, and was living there quietly under Japanese protection. He was finding it slow and heavy going in his efforts to attract reputable and influential Chinese support.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP).--A Republican charge that Administration forces were attempting to convert the AAA into a political agency for the 1940 campaign enlivened Congressional controversy today over the Hatch bill to curb political activities of Federal officials.

MOREHEAD, Ky., July 5.--Thirtythree persons are known to have been drowned today when swiftly rising Eastern Kentucky mountain streams, following cloudbursts late last night, rushed down creeks and rivers to inundate communities along their banks. PARIS, July 5.--The British Cabinet decided today to reject the demand of Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff, Soviet Premier and Foreign Commisar, for a guarantee against "indirect aggression" on the Baltic States--aggression that takes the shape of political changes in those States.

A decision in a minority bondholders' suit which may force the Lehigh Valley Railroad into bankruptcy if upheld on appeal and if the Wheeler-Chandler Railroad Reorganization Bill fails of passage in Congress was filed yesterday in Supreme Court. It was handed down by Justice Aaron J. Levy.

WATERBURY, Conn., July 5.-- Simon J. Alderman, New Haven accountant, and three of his assistants testified today that they returned all city records to the vault in the Controller's office after using them in December, 1937.

BOSTON, July 5.--The Giants left here tonight with much to be thankful for. They finally made the grade against Casey Stengel's Bees, bagging their first victory in Boston since last September and breaking a Stengel winning string after six straight. The count was 11 to 7, alter two and one-half hours of play before 3,032 fans.

SANTA ANA, Calif., July 5 (AP).-- Newton W. Gilbert, former Acting Governor General of the Philippine Islands, died in a hospital today of injuries received in an automobile accident on March 26. He was 77 years old.
Mrs. Marie Hubert Frohman, oldtime star of the theatre and widow of Gustave Frohman, theatrical producer, died Tuesday at her home, 7 Merestone Terrace, Bronxville, N.Y.

NEW ORLEANS, July 5.--A Gulf district delegation walked out of a preliminary session of the National Maritime Union's biennial convention here today when the credentials committee reported that its leaders were not qualified to be seated.

While New York retailers reported yesterday that cigarette sales had fallen off sharply since the 2cent State tax became effective Monday, merchants in Jersey City and Newark noted a spurt in purchases that in some instances doubled their cigarette business.

DETROIT, July 5.--The longthreatened strike of tool and die, engineering and maintenance employes of the General Motors Corporation began at 10 o'clock this morning when 800 workers in these departments pulled the switches in Fisher Body Plant 21 at Piquette and Hastings Streets and walked out. A picket line was formed in front of the factory.

Twenty entries had been received yesterday for the New York Athletic Club's sailing race out to Block Island, which will start at 8 P.M. tomorrow off Execution Lighthouse in Long Island Sound, and F.W. Horenburger, chairman of the race committee, said he expected several more.

EDITORS here and there have been considering the fact that a single well-aimed meteor, dropping somewhat closer to the earth than did the one that exploded over Oregon the other day, would settle a municipality's problems for some time to come. HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 5.-- William Cameron Menzies has been engaged by Alexander Korda to direct "The Thief of Bagdad," which will be made in color in London this Summer. Mr. Menzies, who has been lent by Selznick-International, will leave for New York tomorrow.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 5.--Tabor Academy won in the first heat in its quest for the Thames Challenge Cup as the one hundredth Royal Henley Regatta opened today, defeating the Quintin Boat Club exactly as it pleased in 7 minutes 52 seconds.

Brother Leo the Great, F.S.C., principal and director of De La Salle Academy, Newport, R.I., and former provincial of the New York Province of the Brothers of the Christian Schools, died yesterday morning of a cerebral hemorrhage in the Newport Hospital. He was 58 years old.

ALBANY, July 5.--The revised $390,000,000 1939-40 budget, continuing the $25,000,000 reductions in State expenditures, will be passed on Monday afternoon and the special session of the Legislature will be brought to an end, Senator Hanley and Speaker Heck, Republican leaders, stated today.

We received a telegram yesterday from Bill Sharpe of North Carolina reporting that Hugo Rutherfurd "did it again." This time it wasn't Hugo that took the fish, but Marshall Dana of Cincinnati. Fishing on the former's new cruiser Maco Bark, Dana brought in a 593-pound blue marlin.

Officials of Atlantic City, N.J., announced yesterday that sealed bids would be considered on July 26 for $2,740,000 of refunding 3 per cent bonds. The issue will be dated Aug. 1, 1939, and will mature in 1940 to 1959.

Feeling the time at hand when something definite should be done about Bucky Harris and his annoying Senators, Marse Joe McCarthy had his Yankees bear down with all they had in their series final at the Stadium yesterday against the only American League entry that has been able to hold them even this year.

LONDON, July 5 (AP).--The failure of a test cock to show the flooding of a torpedo tube of the submarine Thetis and the jamming of a bulkhead door contributed to the June 1 disaster in which ninety-nine lives were lost, it was indicated today in testimony before a court of inquiry.

TRENTON, July 5.--"Every indication of an improved economic condition" is noted by Arthur Mudd, State Relief Director, in reporting today that New Jersey's relief costs declined during May, the fourth consecutive month in which the cost was lower than the preceding month.

A luncheon was given yesterday by Mrs. Frederic F. de Rham in the Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton. Her guests included Mrs. James P. Vogel, Mrs. J. Victor Onativia and Miss Dorothy Shepard.

CHICAGO, July 5.--For the first time in its history Chicago has two billion-dollar banks. Mid-year bank reports released today disclosed that the total deposits of the First National Bank of Chicago amounted to $1,012,665,000, the highest ever reported by that seventy-five-year-old institution.

WASHINGTON, July 5.--The French national defense program has had a stimulating effect on industry, and the country, as a result, has experienced a revival of business optimism, according to the weekly review of trade developments...

PALO ALTO, Calif., July 5.--Two new theories which may solve mysterious problems of cell division and cell structure were presented today at the symposium in which sixteen biological researchers undertook to summarize all known data about cells and protoplasm.

WASHINGTON, July 5.--Ambassador Carlos Manuel Pereira of Brazil officially told the State Department today of his government's initial payment of $1,000,000 made on July 1 on Brazil's $359,000,000 debt to United States investors.

WASHINGTON, July 5.--President Roosevelt returned to the White House early today from a week-end visit to his family home on the Hudson to resume his fight for passage of Neutrality Act amendments and the $3,860,000,000 lending program.

WASHINGTON, July 5.--The Senate, by the vote of 43 to 39, approved today the conference report on the monetary bill continuing the President's control over the dollar until June 30, 1941.

George H. Howard, president of the United Corporation, disclosed yesterday in a formal report to shareholders that the utility holding company had invested an aggregate of $2,446,712 in the securities of non-utility companies in the period from March 17 to June 30.

Efrem Kurtz, who has often been heard here as director of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, made his local debut as symphonic conductor last night at Lewisohn Stadium with the Philharmonic-Symphony. He chose a Russian program consisting of the "Capriccio Espagnole" of Rimsky-Korsakoff, the Shostakovich First symphony and the Tchaikovsky "Pathetic."

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, July 5.--Co-medalists Ed Overton of Staunton Military Academy and W. Mitchell Jennings, a Princeton undergraduate, moved into the semi-finals of the Westchester junior golf championship at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today.

SHANGHAI, July 5.--Foreigners arriving from Manchukuo said today that hospitals in Harbin were "filled to overflowing" with Japanese soldiers wounded in fighting Soviet Russian and Mongolian forces along the border between Manchukuo and Outer Mongolia.

So far this year there have been 1,093 cases of food poisoning reported to the city Health Department, whereas there were only 780 cases in New York during all of 1938, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 5.--The Federal Government compromised today tax claims against the Associated Gas and Electric System for $8,700,000, ending several years of controversy over how much, if anything, that utility holding company system should pay in income and excess profits taxes for 1927 through 1933.

Although the volume of trading continued extremely small, the course of prices in the stock market yesterday seemed to reflect returning confidence. Quotations were firm all day and there was an overwhelming preponderance of gains over losses.
