I. Lincoln Seide, real estate auctioneer and appraiser in this city for more than twenty-five years, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 115 East Ninety-second Street. He was 51 years old.

A review of the coffee crop year, which ended on June 30, shows that Brazil, the world's largest producer of coffee, expanded her markets, especially in the United States, but was unable to obtain prices much..

For a score of Summers Americans have met at Williamstown, Mass., to discuss their political, economic and social relations as citizens. The Williamstown Institute is proverbially a marriage of education and citizenship. This August the doors of Williams College will..

A pair of impressive victories yesterday sent Dick McKee of Miami, Fla., into the fourth round of the New York State clay-court tennis championship at the Seminole Club, Forest Hills, where he was joined by little Nat Goldstein, Brooklyn public parks champion and net captain at Brooklyn College.

HE'S a marvel, surely, that little Hugh Duffy with the Boston Red Sox. He hits to the infielders during batting practice and he goes out on the coaching lines--and how old do you think he would be now, little Hughey?

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 9.-- "February Hill," a novel by "Victoria Lincoln published in 1933, has been acquired by RKO as Ginger Rogers's next vehicle, to be produced and directed in the Fall by Gregory La Cava. Miss Lincoln's novel was staged in New York last season by George Abbott under the title, "Primrose Path."

The appointment of Major Gen. Frank Ross McCoy, U.S.A. (retired), as president of the Foreign Policy Association, was announced yesterday by the board of directors. General McCoy will take over his new duties in September, succeeding Raymond Leslie Buell, who resigned on July 1. Mr. Buell will continue as a member of the board.
The Republican leaders at Albany are reported to be set to re-enact the Budget Bill today with the original cuts intact.

LONDON, July 9.--Last week's further increase of 6,742,000 in note circulation of the Bank of England brings it within 3,594,000 of the record of 509,316,000 reached at Christmas, 1937, while a new record seems certain if demand between now and the August holiday season equals that of the same period last year.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 9 (AP).-- Getting fine pitching, Newark swept a double-header with the Chiefs before 5,000 fans today, 6 to 0 and 3 to 2.

RENO, Nev., July 9.--The police continued today their investigation of the fatal shooting at her home Saturday night of Mrs. Caroline Roebling Hagner Walters, a granddaughter of the builder of the Brooklyn Bridge.

In an attempt to save the American whaling industry, threatened with extinction by a high excise tax on whale oil produced with the aid of foreign-registered killer and chaser ships, a joint resolution has been introduced in the House of Representatives to postpone the effectiveness of the excise law for five years to June, 1944.

Boris Thomashefsky, who first introduced the Yiddish theatre to America and who for many years was a familiar personage on the East Side, died yesterday afternoon in Beth Israel Hospital, where he was taken Saturday after suffering a heart attack. He was 71 years old.

SAN JUAN, P.R., July 9.--President Roosevelt's interest in creating a Pan-American cultural center at the University of Puerto Rico is credited by thirty of this year's Law School graduates with being responsible for their being compelled to take bar examinations.

LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J., July 9.--Jack Cooper gave a convincing lesson in speed boat racing to his 225-class rivals, at least one a college youth a third his age, in winning the New Jersey State championship today.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP).--A campaign to organize former Democratic members of Congress in a drive to nominate a "sensible Democrat" for the Presidency next year was started today by former Representative John J. O'Connor of New York.
NORTH CONWAY, N.H., July 9.--The name of Wayne Sabin will be the first to be engraved on the gold racquet emblematic of the Eastern Slope tennis championship.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 9.-- Variety chain sales and earnings declined last year, but total expense rose to a new high level, according to the annual study, "Expenses and Profits of Limited Price Variety Chains," issued by the bureau of business research of the Graduate School of Business Administration of Harvard University.

PITTSBURGH, July 9 (AP).--Hitting his sixteenth and seventeenth home runs of the season and a pair of doubles to drive in five runs, Johnny Mize staged a one-man show today as the Cardinals and Pirates split a double-header, the Cards winning the first, 7--3, and losing the nightcap, 8--6. Mize's big bat boomed out a homer in each game.
Western Union in the World of Tomorrow got a telegram the other day for a Mr. Corbin in the A. T. T. exhibit. It was turned over to one of the brighter couriers.
The first sit-down strike in the history of championship golf took place yesterday at the Pomonok Country Club in Flushing,...
Sweltering temperatures continued throughout the East for the sixth successive day yesterday, but balmy breezes developing at the approach of nightfall gave hope for at least temporary relief.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 9.-- Fire partly destroyed a building just before noon today on the property of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad at Cos Cob,...
ALBANY, July 9.--Legislators will return to the Capitol at 3 P. M. tomorrow for what the Republican chiefs hope will be a brief session to pass the revised $390,000,000 budget.

WASHINGTON, July 9.--President Roosevelt's power over Congress, strengthened by a close victory on monetary legislation last week, is expected to be tested on at least two points--neutrality and lending legislation--this week, with speedy or long-delayed adjournment of the legislative body depending upon the outcome.

Joe Cronin certainly takes a lot of convincing. About the only one in organized baseball who wasn't convinced the Yankees were a shooin for the American League flag, the lantern-jawed Californian yesterday took steps that were more than adequate to demonstrate his skepticism.

In the comparatively deserted confines of Ebbets Field, the Giants yesterday struggled through to a 3-2 triumph over the Dodgers, gaining an even break in the fourgame series and holding second place, five and one-half games behind the league-leading Reds.

President Roosevelt, Secretary of Agriculture Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes and 136 public officials, eminent scientists, writers and educators sent messages of greeting yesterday to Professor Franz Boas of Columbia University, dean of American anthropologists, on his eighty-first birthday.

Argentina and the United States, inspired by a common love of freedom and spirit of democracy, have developed along lines so nearly parallel that the two nations may truly be called sister republics, Commissioner General Juan A. De Marval of Argentina said yesterday at the observance of Argentine Independence Day at the World's Fair.

ORILLIA, Ont., July 9.--Dr. Stephen Leacock, noted Canadian author and former lecturer at McGill University, played a prominent part in the rescue early tonight of Percy Bartleman, 21, of Orillia, whose sailing canoe capsized on Lake Couchiching.

BATON ROUGE, La., July 9.-- With investigating agents of the Federal Government swarming over Louisiana, the State's Attorney General, David Ellison, whose efforts to "coordinate" his inquiries into politico-financial scandals with the Federal action were rejected by Frank Murphy, United States Attorney...

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 9.--Harold T. White Jr.'s Muskeget in the International Class and Freeman L. Meinertz's Bobkat among the Atlantics were the chief winners today in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's special regatta, held under conditions that made the International skippers, at least, consider forsaking yacht racing for horseshoe pitching.

Alexander Eisemann Co. have announced the following additions to their staff: Edward E. Gross and Louis L. Maltz in the Paramount office, Martin A. Negersmith in the Fordham office, Samuel Stern in the Brooklyn office and George J. Voight in the main office.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 9.--To record the standout surprise of the current polo campaign, the undefeated Sands Point four, headed by peerless Thomas Hitchcock Jr., trounced Texas by 11-5 on International Field today in the final of the Meadow Brook Club Cups tourney for twenty-goal combinations.

Declaring, in his annual report, that "there is no escaping the conclusion that speed continues to hold the deadly distinction of being the chief highway killer, directly or indirectly breeding more violent deaths than any other driving error," Motor Vehicle Commissioner...
BOSTON, July 9.--Dai Buell, concert pianist and wife of Audley Earl Greenidge of Newton Center, died suddenly today.

Unless the Legislature restores the $5,300,000 cut in State aid to education, or votes to alter the existing salary schedules, there will be no alternative but to carry out the threatened drastic curtailment of the New York City school system, Board of Education members warned yesterday.

MOBILE, Ala., July 9.--With the arrest of thirty-five union seamen and sympathizers, some of them having Communist literature in their possession, as the result of the presence here of the Merchant Marine training ship American Seamen to enlist students for sea training, the situation was quiet tonight.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 9.--Regulations applying the new mining decree, effective next Sunday, were published today. Under its provisions the entire output of the mines must be marketed through the Central Bank.
The Goldman Band, Edwin Franko Goldman conductor, opened its twenty-second season of outdoor concerts last night at the Central Park Mall before one of the largest audiences seen at these events.
CHICAGO, July 9.--Seldom has the prospect for the corn crop at this time of year been so favorable as it is now. According to some statisticians, if this prospect is...

Major Gen. Pedro Aurelio de Goes Monteiro, Chief of Staff of the Brazilian Army, who has been visiting this country with his party since June 20, will arrive by plane from Washington at Newark Airport at 10:30 A.M. today for a five-day stay in the metropolitan area.

BRIELLE, N. J., July 9.--Two members of a tuna fishing party and a member of the crew were injured, the latter seriously, in an explosion this morning aboard a chartered fishing boat thirty miles southeast of Manasquan Inlet.
WASHINGTON, July 9.--As a possible means of increasing sales abroad, Secretary of Commerce Hopkins has suggested that all brushes made in this country be conspicuously marked "Made in U.S.A."

Fires have raged, feuds have flared and a dozen other types of minor calamities have enlivened the atmosphere out on Flushing Meadows since the World's Fair started, but there has been nothing quite to compare with the botanical pandemonium that was raging yesterday at the Heinz Dome,...

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 9.--Ken Sheldon of Nassau, a 40-year-old player, whose chief claim to golfing fame thus far has beem his victory in the 1934 Bermuda championship, today won the Long Island amateur title by defeating 20-year-old John Humm of Rockville, 4 and 3, in the eighteenhole final at the Sands Point Club.
The steadily increasing use of copy-testing preliminary to national campaigns is reflected in the sharp rise in the number of tests in newspapers since the start of the year, according to agency men.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 9.--Governor and Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt entertained Summer colonists and other friends at luncheon at Oakland Farm today. There were eighty in the company.

The first back-to-work movement among the WPA workers who are striking throughout the nation to compel Congress to restore the prevailing rate of wages in the new Emergency Relief Act was reported yesterday from Washington.

Parents of school children were urged by Mayor La Guardia yesterday to give particular attention during the vacation months to the continued training of their children in traffic safety habits. He said the absence of regular training given to the children in school places a special responsibility on the parents.

BERLIN, July 8.--No fundamental change in opinion concerning the probability of war has occurred in German financial and business circles, where the firm conviction now, as heretofore, is that, whatever appearances might suggest, there will not be war either next Autumn or subsequently.

The present building of the Supreme Court of Kings County "is wholly unsuitable for the proper conduct of the business of the supreme court," according to the report of Supreme Court Justices Edward Riegelmann and Charles C. Lockwood, members of the Committee on Calendar Progress, made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 9.--National officers of the Workers Security Federation advised members of local, city and State federations today to return to work tomorrow rather than oppose the five-day ultimatum of Colonel F.C. Harrington, WPA Administrator.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 9.--The long-delayed hearing on the deportation of Harry Bridges, the West Coast C.I.O. leader, will begin tomorrow morning on Angel Island, which is reached in a thirty-twominute boat ride in a small government steamer from San Francisco.

Women leaders of bizarre cults virtually rule the lives of 400,000 natives in the jungles surrounding Bahia, Brazil, it was reported yesterday by Dr. Ruth Landes of Columbia University's Department of Anthropology, who has just returned from a year's expedition into the region.

WASHINGTON, July 9.--With President Roosevelt expected to appoint this week a new Secretary of the Navy to replace Claude A. Swanson and also a head of the new Federal Security Agency, the impression grew in the capital today that the appointments would be made with 1940 political prospects in view.
The Rev. Walter P. Kellenberg, preaching yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, urged recourse to the blood of Jesus Christ to prevent "spiritual hardening of the arteries."

PHILADELPHIA, July 9.--Measures to repeal features of the new relief bill, against which the American Federation of Labor has called strikes, will be introduced in the House tomorrow by Representative Michael J. Bradley, Democrat, of this city.
MANILA, July 9.--This young democracy has obtained President Manuel L. Quezon's assent to the first changes in its constitutional structure.

PITTSBURGH, July 9.--Because of shutdowns for Independence Day, which in some plants amounted to twenty-four hours and in others extended to as much as three days, and because some steel producers utilized the holiday week for mass vacation periods, the output of steel ingots throughout the nation last week, based on a normal week's capacity, declined 15 points from the level of the week before to 39 per cent of capacity.
BERLIN, July 9.--Dr. Adolf Rohrbach, German airplane and motorboat designer, died yesterday at Kampen, on the north seacoast, at the age of 51.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 9.-- A. Wallace Chauncey, president of the Maidstone Club, with other officers, Juan Terry Trippe, James B. Skidmore and Russell Hopkinson, and members of the board of governors, gave a reception this afternoon in honor of the season's new members of the club.

PARIS, July 9.--A more optimistic feeling prevailed last week in financial circles here. On Monday the stock market simply showed steadiness, but Tuesday saw quite a sharp upward movement which continued next day, although more moderately.
BOSTON, July 9.--Dr. Donald Clinton Barton, noted petroleum research geologist, who formerly lived in Cambridge, died yesterday in Houston, Texas. His age was 50.
LAHORE, India, July 9.--A plea for Indian support of Britain and France in any struggle with the Axis powers is made by The Tribune, influential pro-Congress newspaper.
CHICAGO, July 9.--Weather conditions last week were almost ideal for the rapid growth of corn, high temperatures and ample moisture prevailing over the greater part of the large producing States.

AUBURN, Mass., July 9.--A stolen car being pursued by State police at a 70-mile-an-hour clip crashed head-on into another machine near here today, taking a toll of four lives and causing injuries to four other persons. Three of the injured are in serious condition.

John Albert, Bronx builder, will undertake an apartment house operation on the West Side where he has purchased a plot 54 by 100.11 feet at 163, 165 and 167 West Ninetyseventh Street, between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues. H.I. Feldman, architect, is preparing plans for a six-story elevator building with small suites.
DANZIG, July 9.--Nazis of Danzig at two rousing mass meetings today thundered defiance at Poland and pledged blind faith in the leadership of Chancellor Adolf Hitler.
CHICAGO, July 9.--Although about half of the Winter wheat crop has been harvested, there has been a lack of heavy hedging pressure on the market so far this season.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 9.--A strong warning that the Federal Government might be compelled to provide legal services for persons who could not pay the present charges of lawyers, came today from Robert H. Jackson, Solicitor General of the United States, as 3,000 members of the American Bar Association prepared to meet tomorrow in annual convention.

PARIS, July 9.--The attention of the people of France has been diverted, momentarily at least, from foreign problems to the improvement in the internal situation, an improvement which is shown by various tokens.
No one called on 7-year-old Charlotte Brauer, a patient in the orthopedic ward at Bellevue Hospital, yesterday.

In his long career as soldier-diplomat and "trouble shooter" for the United States the activities of Major Gen. Frank McCoy, now retired, carried him around the globe. He was as much at home in Tokyo as in France or Armenia.

WITH JAPANESE TROOPS, on the Mongolian Frontier, July 9. --A Japanese "suicide corps," prepared today for an attempt to drive 2,000 Soviet-Mongolian soldiers across the Khalka River in the sixth day of hostilities on the vast Mongolian plain.

MONTREAL, July 9.--Battered by other International League teams for most of the season, the Montreal Royals today turned on the Jersey City Giants and knocked them out of the league lead with a 7--4 and 9--0 double defeat.

An eventuality that probably was not expected--even by Park Commissioner Robert Moses--when the scows started dumping sand fill along the shores of Little Neck Bay for the new Belt Parkway has given the surprised community of Bayside, Queens, something it never had or dreamed of having--a sand beach.
ST. LOUIS, July 9 (AP).--The Indians swept a double-header with the Browns today. The scores were 14 to 2 and 5 to 1.

PARIS, July 9.--Speaking on the theme, "It is on ourselves, above all, that our destiny depends," Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet at Toulouse today emphasized what he meant two weeks ago at Arcachon when he said that if the United States clearly indicated that it would support the Anglo-French alliance from the first day of war all danger might be removed at once.

TOKYO, Monday, July 10.--The British-Japanese conference on Tientsin is expected to open Wednesday or Thursday. The delays are due to the importance the Japanese attach to the conference and to the thoroughness with which their demands are being prepared.
Failure of a feeder line that supplied current to about one-third of the lights in the amusement area of the World's Fair darkened a number of concessions just after 9:40 o'clock last night.

Since the deficit in the State budget for the fiscal year that ended June 30 was $4,284,869 less than had been expected, James Marshall, President of the Board of Education, recommended yesterday that State aid to that amount be restored to the city school system to prevent "shocking" curtailment of educational services.

VENTNOR CITY, N.J., July 9.-- Olaf Ulvestad of Seattle, Wash., opened his account on the score table of Ventnor City's invitation chess tournament by defeating Harold Burdge of Atlantic City in the third round on Municipal Pier tonight.

The United States would profit from increased sales abroad during a European war, according to Dean John T. Madden, director of the Institute of International Finance of New York University, who says that a European war in which the United States was not involved could not affect this country adversely to any appreciable extent during hostilities.
In the markets as in the streets and in the news, last week's was a midsummer atmosphere. A touch of midsummer madness came perhaps in some Congressional proceedings.

DETROIT, July 9 (AP).--The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin declared in his weekly broadcast today that a proposal had been made "that a group of union laborers will militarize themselves and establish an independent army within this republic."

DETROIT, July 9.--A "progressive" group which supported Homer Martin when he broke with the C.I.O.-United Automobile Workers repudiated him today as "irresponsible" and advised its adherents to affiliate with the C.I.O. auto affiliate led by R.J. Thomas.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 9.-- Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred J. Funk gave a large buffet luncheon today at Cobble Court, their place on the Ocean, for Miss Helen H. Wing, who was introduced to society last night at a dinner dance at the Southampton Beach Club, and for Miss Helen Allen, who is visiting her uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Basil Harris, at Wyllys House.

CHICAGO, July 9 (AP).--The White Sox twice defeated the Tigers today before 30,000 fans, winning the first game on Detroit's ragged fielding and the second on their own timely hitting. The scores were 4 to 3 and 6 to 3.
KANSAS CITY, July 9.--Vigorously yet methodically, career women of the country launched tonight a diagnosis of their composite professional status.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 9 --On the site where General Abner Doubleday laid out the first diamond in 1839, representatives of forty-one minor leagues wrote a new chapter in the game's history today when they met in a game arranged as part of the sport's national centennial celebration.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 9.--Turkey's determination to resist aggression was reaffirmed by Foreign Minister Shukru Saracoglu in an enthusiastically applauded speech at the end of the National Assembly session at Angora last night.

WASHINGTON, July 9.--Bills dealing with the difficult problem of officer promotion in the army and navy will be before Congress this week and may be the last important national defense legislation considered at this session.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., July 9.-- Miss Nancy Estile Holton, daughter of Mayor and Mrs. Charles William Holton of this place, has chosen Sept. 9 for her wedding to Thomas Chase Homan of Chatham, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Van Ness Homan of Forest Hills, L.I. The ceremony will be performed in the garden of the Holton home.
The giant tuna season is now getting under way in northern waters, and the first fish of the season were taken at Bailey Island, Me., and Wedgeport, N.S.
ROME, July 9.--Escorted by units of a famous naval squadron, Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister, left today for Spain aboard the cruiser Eugenio di Savoia.

Prices of cotton futures last week recovered the declines of the previous week and made net gains to new high levels for some current deliveries. Advances on the New York Cotton Exchange ranged from 12 to 18 points, with the nearer deliveries gaining the most.
The annual Gershwin Memorial Concert, to take place tonight at Lewisohn Stadium, is expected to draw a large audience.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 9.-- Overcoming a one-set deficit caused by an erratic start, Robert Peacock, University of California senior, swept the next three sets against Marvin Wachman of Northwestern University, to capture the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championship at the Montclair Athletic Club today, before a large crowd. Peacock won by 3--6, 6--2, 6--2, 6--3.

TIENTSIN, China, July 9 (AP).-- Relations between British and Japanese military forces here were further strained today when the Japanese commander in Tientsin refused to receive the visiting commander of British troops at Hong Kong.
PRAGUE, July 9.--Prague's German University has been put under the control of a commissioner. Rector Ernst Otto has been retired and in the Autumn Nazi District Leader Rudolf Jung will replace him.

OTTAWA, July 9 (Canadian Press).--Free use of coast-to-coast networks for broadcasting political arguments in general election campaigns will be allotted the established national parties on a proportionate basis, it was announced here today by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation.

LONDON, July 9.--The only satisfaction which the silver market here can possibly derive from the passing of the Monetary Bill in Washington comes from the knowledge that the United States Treasury will continue to buy foreign silver.

LONDON, July 9.--A "go ahead" signal has come from Warsaw, with the result that Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain is expected to deliver his long-awaited pledge about Danzig in the House of Commons tomorrow.

Reproaching his fellow-ministers for their custom of prescribing large general doses labeled "How I Think You Should Live Your Lives," the Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Norwood, English evangelist, declared yesterday morning that the ministry should point out that good is latent within every one, but that it is the individual's task to bring it into play.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 9.--Miss Barbara Shove Palmer, daughter of Mrs. Shove Palmer of Princeton, whose marriage to Joel Addison Hayes Webb of Colorado Springs, son of Dr. Gerald B. Webb and the late Mrs. Webb, will take place in the Shove Memorial Chapel at the University of Colorado on July 25, has announced the plans for her wedding.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 9.-- Twelve hundred up-State infantrymen of the New York National Guard, forming a section of the Fifty-fourth Infantry Brigade of Buffalo, commanded by Brig. Gen. Ralph K. Robertson, took over the Camp Smith cantonment here today after a sweltering journey by train from the home armories.

LONDON, July 9.--The stock markets here remain entirely political in thought and outlook; they continue faithfully to reflect every move or expected move in the struggle between the dictatorships and the democracies.

The Rockefeller Foundation has released funds for the second year of scholarships for young playwrights. A leading candidate for the first of the second group of awards seems to be David Belasco Howard, a native of Vermont, whose parents named him for the late David Belasco, a close friend of the family.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., July 9.--An eager army of 15,000 to 20,000 persons rolled eastward from the city today in 3,000 cars, eightytwo chartered buses and two special trains to take possession of the late Otto H. Kahn's estate at Woodbury, near here, in the name of the Department of Sanitation Welfare Honor Relief Fund.

WHITE PLAINS, July 9.--The embattled locals of the International Hod Carriers Union, at war over jobs on the Delaware River aqueduct being constructed from the Catskills into New York City, held separate meetings today and voted to continue the fight.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 9.--At a banquet tonight after the close of the fourteen-day soaring contests, Chester J. Decker of Glen Rock, N.J., was declared for the second time national soaring champion. He scored 3,020 points.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 9.-- Although all nine motor boats in the New York Athletic Club's run here from the western end of Long Island Sound were snugly berthed today and their performance cards were checked, the winner was not determined, and may not be for a day or two.

Masses were celebrated for the first time yesterday within the main sanctuary of the new Roman Catholic Church of St. Andrew, Duane Street and Cardinal Place, in the shadow of the Municipal Building. Mgr. William E. Cashin, pastor of the church, which has replaced the historic little red brick edifice that was a Manhattan landmark for 129 years, celebrated the first Mass at 12:45 A.M.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., July 9.-- Plans for the fifty-third annual Tuxedo Autumn Ball were completed today. Mrs. F. Meredith Blagden will be chairman of the ball, which will be held in the Tuxedo Club on Oct. 21. The event will be in honor of the four local debutantes, and, as usual, the leading debutantes of the metropolitan district will attend.

The spirit of venturesomeness is an indispensable element of life and it has been a primary factor in the development of America, Dr. Samuel H. Prince, Professor of Economics and Sociology at King's University, Halifax, N.S., declared in a sermon yesterday morning at St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church, 128 West Sixty-ninth Street.

Poland is apparently to be the chief beneficiary of the new export credits which the British Government is to grant to the smaller members of the anti-aggression bloc for the purchase of munitions and other war supplies. But of the total of about $280,000,000 to be allotted in such credits, smaller sums are also to go to Rumania, Tur key and Egypt.

The latest reports from London indicate that the British may make their expected declaration on Danzig today. This declaration has been held up on Colonel Beck's advice that the situation is not urgent.

MONTAUK, L.I., July 9.--Lemuel Ladd of Boston, driving a Ford special which he built from the spare parts of three other cars, today won the inaugural running of the Montauk Grand Prix automobile race over a two-mile course that wound through the sand dunes between Montauk Lake and the golf course.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP).--Six modern cargo vessels of the C-2 design will be added to the American Hampton Roads-Yankee Line, the Maritime Commission announced today.
ABOUT as gentle and able a little novel as the Summer will show is "Black Narcissus," by Rumer Godden, a young Englishwoman who has spent much of her life in India.
It was an inspiriting address that Governor Lehman made to the Christian Endeavorers, thousands of whom were gathered from all of the States, in Cleveland, Ohio, on Saturday.

The present difficulties of the WPA flow in large part out of the fact that it is neither normal employment nor normal relief, but a peculiar sort of hybrid. If it gave normal employment, even normal Government employment, then it would be confined to projects that needed to be done, rather than finding projects for the number or kinds of workers that needed jobs.

It is ten years since Fred E. Beal, a leader in the Gastonia textile strike, was convicted of conspiracy in the killing of Police Chief O.P. Aderholt. Much has happened both to Beal and to North Carolina since that time.

CINCINNATI, July 9 (AP).--The Reds turned on the power today and routed the Cubs, 13 to 1, with a 17-hit attack. Bucky Walters, scheduled to do some pitching in the All-Star game Tuesday, scored his thirteenth victory and set Chicago down with five safeties.

A lull in general buying activity was noted in the wholesale markets last week. Lower-end dresses were requested in good quantities for July promotions and there were calls for popular-priced dark midseason sheers, while the medium and better markets were occupied with preparations for the Fall buying season.

Under the stimulus of world-wide attacks on democracy, constitutional guarantees in this country have received "unprecedented support" in the last twelve months, the American Civil Liberties Union declared in its annual report, made public yesterday.
Sophie Tucker, heading a delegation of lawyers and officials of the American Federation of Actors, of which she is president, stalked out
MONROE, N.Y., July 10.--The other day we heard that two of the small lakes near this town were producing some nice bass, so we decided to make a personal check-up this morning.
The three-story building on a plot 46 by 100 feet at 313-15 West Fiftyninth Street has been leased to the Ennis Desk Company.

WASHINGTON, July 10.--Paul V. McNutt, high commissioner to the Philippines and active candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1940, was chosen today by President Roosevelt to be Federal security administrator.
PHILADELPHIA, July 10.--James L. McDevitt, president of the Pennsylvania Federation of Labor, advised WPA workers today to "stay on the job" until the July 20 strike deadline.

WASHINGTON, July 10.--The Navy Department will probably ask Congress at its next session for two more 45,000-ton "superships."

Thousands of men and women from both sides of the footlights passed before the bier of Boris Thomashefsky yesterday as his body lay in state at the Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Avenue, near Ninth Street.
More than 1,200 buyers registered at three trade shows here yesterday, and laid down orders more freely than they had at previous
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 10.-- Mrs. Charles Banks Belt gave a luncheon today at the Southampton Beach Club for Miss E. Mary Steers, who has joined Mr. and Mrs. Belt

BERLIN, July 10.--Official German reaction to Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's statement on Danzig is summed up in these words: "It might be advisable for British statesmen is the future to label their speeches since they are turning them out, so to speak, on a conveyor belt."

KANSAS CITY, July 10.--By vote of the delegates representing 71,000 members of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, the biennial conven
